summary: [/INST] Participant recruitment will take place for the duration of the research. All women who are able to consent to the participation in the study will be screened after the signing of informed consent in order to examine inclusion/exclusion criteria. There are three groups of women defined according to inclusion/exclusion criteria and a 4th group of control women representing the general population with no history of chronic pain conditions.

[/INST] This was a randomized controlled trial that aimed to compare the effects of a massage mattress with a cube/block system to a standard pressure sore prevention device in reducing pressure ulcers for bedridden patients with a high risk of developing pressure ulcers.

[/INST] The Effect of Exercise on Metabolic Parameters, Anthropometric Measurement Values and Quality of Life aims to determine the effect of augmented reality exercise on the quality of life of children with Type 1 diabetes. Children who meet the age and type of diabetes criteria and are without health problems are randomly divided into control and exercise groups. In the exercise group, children were trained for 60 min every other day for twelve weeks, with the trainer monitoring the activity and heart rate of the children throughout the exercises.

[/INST] Background: The study was conducted to reduce preoperative anxiety in patients who will undergo abdominal surgery. Aim: To investigate the effects of virtual reality using glasses on preoperative anxiety in abdominal surgery. Method: We planned to make two groups of intervention and control. Virtual reality will be applied to one group. The anxiety levels will be measured in both groups. The data will be compared. Results: The data will be shared after the study is completed.

[/INST] The study, titled “Clinical Performance and Safety of Suture-TOOL for Abdominal Wound Closure in Men and Women Patients Undergoing Elective Open Abdominal Surgery,” is a single-arm prospective interventional study aimed at evaluating the performance and safety of the Suture-TOOL device in closing the abdomen after laparotomy, specifically when used in midline incisions during elective open abdominal surgery. The inclusion criteria are male or female patients aged 18 years or older who require elective open abdominal surgery through a midline incision of at least 12 cm, who are physically capable of complying with the study procedures and providing informed consent, and who can co-operate with the investigator and comply with the requirements of the entire study. The exclusion criteria are known or identified at surgery disseminated cancer disease, abnormal physical findings that preclude the conduct of the study, pre-operative findings identified by the surgeon/investigator that may preclude the conduct of the study procedures, significant history of renal, hepatic, gastrointestinal, cardiovascular, respiratory, skin, haematological, endocrine or neurological diseases, pregnant or breastfeeding women, and individuals unable to fully understand all aspects of the study that are relevant to the decision to participate, or who could be manipulated or unduly influenced either because of a compromised position or expectation of benefits or fear of retaliatory response. Suture-TOOL is a suture-binding device designed for fast and standardized closure of fascia following laparotomy.

[/INST] The study, titled Immune Biomarker Study for Salivary Gland Carcinoma, is a prospective cohort study that aims to investigate the relationship between the immune system of patients with salivary gland cancer and various biological markers. The estimated study duration is 4 years. The study involves three participant groups, which include a group of patients with a primary diagnosis of salivary gland carcinoma, a group of patients with a benign salivary gland tumor, and a group of patients with functional diseases of the nose and ear. The primary aim of the study is to investigate changes in the patients' immune matrix, systemic immunophenotyping, cytokine/chemokine levels in peripheral blood, patients' metabolic state, and patients' microbiotic state. The study will use several methods to analyse these parameters, including LIPS, 16S rRNA deep sequencing of microbiome, untargeted metabolomic, and electrochemiluminescent MULTI-ARRAY measurement. The secondary aim is to identify new biomarkers that may help clinicians to select patients with good prognosis. The study will analyze patient-reported outcomes, such as the effects of radiotherapy, and other outcomes of clinical importance. By participating in this study, patients may receive a treatment plan that is more tailored to their specific needs and that considers the effects of radiotherapy.

[/INST] This study is a prospective non-randomized trial conducted to evaluate the relationship between compliance with Mediterranean diet and quality of life, walking, and multiple sclerosis-related problems in multiple sclerosis patients. The primary outcome measure of this study is Mediterranean diet compliance, assessed by the Mediterranean Diet Adaptation (PREDIMED) scale. The secondary outcome measures include multiple sclerosis-related problems, assessed by the 12-item MS Gait Scale, quality of life in multiple sclerosis patients, assessed by the Multiple Sclerosis International Quality of Life Scale, and disability status, assessed by the Expanded Disability Status Scale. Recruited participants will be assessed at baseline and at 1-year, 3-months, and 2-months follow-up intervals. This study aims to improve the health and quality of life of individuals with multiple sclerosis to increase their awareness, prevent diseases related to this patient group, and reduce their negative effects on their lives. The study will be conducted in accordance with the International Conference on Harmonization Guidelines for Good Clinical Practice (E6). The ethical approval was obtained from the Bioethics Committee of the Hacettepe University, Faculty of Medicine, Ankara, Turkey (Ethical approval number: GO 2018/154).

[/INST] The study, titled "Efficacy and Safety of Selective Intensive Induction Therapy Based on Ustekinumab in Patients With Crohn's Disease" (SIIT-CD Study), was a multicenter, prospective, randomized controlled study. The study aimed to examine the efficacy and safety of selective intensive induction therapy based on the clinical decision-making tools of ustekinumab in patients with Crohn's Disease (CD). The study enrolled participants with diagnoses of CD, who were in the active phase of the disease, aged between 18 and 75 years old, and had a moderate or low responsive activity by UST-CDST scores. The exclusion criteria were subjects had undergone extensive colectomy, subtotal colectomy, or total colectomy, subjects with significant liver, kidney, endocrine, respiratory, neurological, or cardiovascular diseases, subjects with fibrous stenosis and prestenosis dilatation, or subjects with UST contraindications. The study used a randomized design with an open-label model where treatment was administered to the experimental group at weeks 0 and 8 through intravenous infusions (based on body weight), then the UST regimen was administered through intravenous infusions or standard subcutaneous injections according to CRP values at the discretion of the treating physician. The primary outcome measure of this study was the difference in the clinical response rate at week 24 between the intensive induction regimen and the standard induction regimen.

[/INST] Authors: Smith, Brown, and Jones; Title: The Preference of a Culturally and Linguistic Diverse (CALD) Population for Second Line OAB Therapy: a Discrete Choice Experiment; Setting: NSW, Australia; Conditions: overactive bladder (OAB) and CALD; Interventions: SNM and BTX; Study Design: randomized controlled trial (RCT) and DCE; Participants: adults with OAB and CALD; Methods: DCE, RCT with a 12-week follow-up period. A patient's questionnaire will be given to choose between the two fictional therapies' characteristics. Each option comes with a SNM and a BTX. Authors aim to test a hypothesis that both CALD and patients who are willing to accept BTX agree to SNM. The study will find the most effective OAB therapy as well as the most preferred treatment by CALD patients.

[/INST] Three-arm Pragmatic Randomized Study on the Effectiveness, Feasibility, Acceptability, and Cost of the Use of Continuous Glucose Monitoring Devices Among People Living With Type 1 Diabetes in South Africa

[/INST] This is a two-center, phase I, single-arm, non-randomized clinical study assessing the safety and efficacy of SBRT with focal dose escalation of the dominant intraprostatic lesion (DIL) in treating localized prostate cancer. Patients aged 18 to 80 years with adenocarcinoma of the prostate, cN0 and cM0, intermediate or high-risk disease according to NCCN 2023, an ECOG PS of 0-1, with a minimum of 18 points on the International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS) and signed a written informed consent were eligible. The study is completed, and the results will be published (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT02559074).

[/INST] This study evaluates the impact of using a serious game (SG) to support the asthma treatment plan in young people with neurological or respiratory disorders. The game will help children to exercise their lungs and control their asthma symptoms. The SG is projected with a 4K projector and controlled by the child's movements, which will be tracked with a Kinect sensor. The child will play while watching an imaginary avatar, who will show him/her the right movements to perform in order to collect rewards.

[/INST] Title: Pavlovian to instrumental transfer (PIT) as a mechanism by which substance-related contextual cues influence relapse. PIT effect occurs when exposure to a substance-related cue leads to increased likelihood of subsequent drug-seeking behavior. The PIT paradigm assesses cognitive control over PIT effects.

[/INST] Flow and Grow is a clinical trial that aims to determine if a standardized weaning CPAP protocol is more effective at reducing weaning time, morbidities, and inpatient days compared to their control management. Flow and Grow includes a standardized NIS protocol where infants are weaned off CPAP at 32 or 34 weeks CGA, if gestational age at birth is <30 weeks or between 28 and 30 weeks, respectively. The control management weans off of CPAP based on each hospital or assigned team's individual practices. The study aims to determine if Flow and Grow is associated with a reduction in the number of weaning failures and other neonatal morbidities.

[/INST] Frexalimab (SAR441344) is a humanized monoclonal antibody that binds to apoptosis antigen 2 (ANXA2), an abundant protein on the surface of myelin sheath-making oligodendrocytes . The purpose of the study is to assess the efficacy and safety of IV infusions of Frexalimab compared to placebo in adults with non-relapsing SPMS. The primary outcome measure is time to cCDP (confirmed clinical disability progression) . Participants will also have a pre-study MRI scan to measure T2 lesions and brain volume. The study is expected to complete in 2023.

[/INST] To compare the effectiveness of two surgical techniques, the modified Millard technique and the Mishra technique, for the surgical correction of unilateral cleft lip in children aged 3–6 months.The primary outcomes are vertical lip height, horizontal lip length, and philtrum length.
[/INST] Endoscopic Management Of Controlled Colo-cutaneous Fistula As A complication of Acute Diverticulitis: A Randomized Controlled Trial

[/INST] The trial, "Multidisciplinary Approach for High-Risk Patients Leading to Early Diagnosis of Canadians in Heart Failure"  is a randomized, un-blinded pilot study that compares usual care to an intervention group receiving early heart failure testing using an algorithm based on inclusion and exclusion criteria, NT-proBNP, AI echocardiogram, electrocardiogram, and study AI echocardiogram. The trial aims to early diagnose HF in high-risk patients to prevent further decline in these patients. The trial will use a screening algorithm based on the inclusion and exclusion criteria for pre-existing cardiac disease, such as coronary artery disease, diabetes, and chronic kidney disease, along with heart failure symptoms. Patients who meet the criteria will be invited for an appointment with a physician, advanced nurse practitioner, or nurse where they will undergo tests such as electrocardiogram. The trial plans to screen 1,000 patients over the course of two years and to investigate whether it is feasible to pilot screen and enroll patients for a larger RCT that will estimate the primary outcome of rates and cost-effectiveness measures.

[/INST] Lean propofol dose, calculated according to lean body weight, can be determined by applying routine anesthesia through intubation conditions with adequate depth of anesthesia to patients below BMI 35. This observational study aims to evaluate whether lean propofol dose has lower anesthetic side effects.

[/INST] Letermovir is a new drug for preventing CMV and has been demonstrated to have higher potency than ganciclovir. In order to study the efficacy and safety profile of this novel drug, the research team is seeking to recruit heart or lung transplant recipients for a study. Participants will be either exposed to letermovir or standard valganciclovir prophylaxis as per local practice. All eligible participants who receive prophylaxis on study entry will have periodic collection of blood and a few stool samples for analysis. The study will follow its participants for a duration of 1 year from the time of study entry. The results obtained will assist in understanding the efficacy and safety of this drug in comparison to the standard valganciclovir drug and thus aid in guiding clinical practice in CMV management.

[/INST] This trial, titled Development and Validation of the PHYSIOSCORE, involved phase 1, phase 2, and phase 3 clinical trials. In phase 1, the development of the PHYSIOSCORE questionnaire was conducted by ten physical therapists with more than ten years of experience in hospital environments. In phase 2, the validity and interrater reliability of the questionnaire were investigated using Delphi technique and online calculator, respectively. Finally, in phase 3, the agreement and reliability of the questionnaire were analyzed compared to the assessment performed by the other professionals. The findings of this trial may contribute to the development of a new method for assessing the complexity of care in hospitalized patients.

[/INST] The trial is a single-arm phase 2 study evaluating the prognosis of patients with head and neck cancer (specifically p16-positive oropharyngeal cancer) who undergo TORS surgery based on their ctDNA levels after TORS.

[/INST] The proposed clinical study examines the effectiveness and safety of ultra-hypofractionated whole breast irradiation (WBI) compared to partial breast irradiation (PBI) for breast cancer treatment. The study includes a single-institution, prospective, phase II trial. The WBI group receives an ultra-short course of radiotherapy with 26 Gy in 5 fractions, administered to the whole breast, while the PBI group receives 26 Gy in 5 fractions, administered only to the part of the breast where the tumor was located. The primary outcome measure is the assessment of acute and late toxicity associated with the two radiotherapy regimens. Acute toxicity will be examined within 6 months after radiotherapy, and late toxicity will be assessed within 6-60 months after radiotherapy. The results have the potential to reduce the treatment duration from 5 weeks to 1 week, making ultra-hypofractionated radiotherapy a more feasible option for many breast cancer patients.

[/INST] The study involved the implementation of a digital health coaching program in the PRO and Wearable Data Insights From Individuals With R/R Multiple Myeloma from PRO IN VIDA platform. The objective was to investigate the feasibility of PRO and wearable data insights, captured in a digital coaching intervention, which might reduce the burden of disease in individuals with R/R multiple myeloma. PROs and wearable data was collected at baseline and monthly thereafter. Physical activity and step count data was collected from Fitbit activity trackers provided to the patients, and PRO data was collected using the Patient Reported Outcomes Management System (PROMOS). The digital coaching was implemented by trained health advisors via phone calls, emails, and text messages. The implementation strategy and participant demographics are not specified in the abstract.

[/INST] Summary:  Rare Diseases Clinical Research Network (RDCRN) Symposium, June 2020. Dried Chicory Root Supplement Intervention in IBD Clinical Trial, United States. The Dried Chicory Root Intervention in IBD Clinical Trial is a 16-center pilot phase clinical trial that explores the efficacy of a prebiotic, dietary fiber intervention in inflammatory bowel disease with an emphasis in patients of high disease activity. The study will enroll 41 participants with a diagnosis of Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis who reside within a 30-minute drive of the study center. The study will include a 2-week run-in period where participants will be required to make a dietary change to a low-fiber diet. Participants will be randomized to take either 10 g/day of dried chicory root supplement or placebo for 4 weeks. The primary endpoints are a change in fecal calprotectin levels (a marker of inflammation) and change in IBD symptoms. This study will use a data set collected in a preliminary study and generate information to guide future trials of this intervention in specific to IBD patients.

[/INST] The trial tested the efficacy of Porcine Acellular Dermal Matrix (PADM) in combination with coronally advanced flap (CAF) versus CAF alone for treating gingival recessions. The trial compared PADM combined with CAF with CAF alone in reducing the gingival recession height and increasing the thickness of keratinized tissue. Recession reduction and thickness of keratinized tissue were measured at baseline, 6 and 12 months. The patients were randomly assigned to the two groups. PADM is a human-derived tissue manufactured from cellular and extracellular components that may potentially prevent gingival recession. The trial also evaluated the efficacy of a new soft tissue graft, Osteo-Graft-3D, compared to Connective Tissue Graft (CTG) in localized gingival recession.

[/INST] This clinical trial aims to compare the differences in changes in heart rate variability modulation between chronic renal patients who undergo conventional physical exercise before and during hemodialysis sessions and those who participate in virtual environment exercises. Two groups of participants will take part in the study, and each one will participate in 10 sessions of exercises, either in virtual reality or using traditional exercise equipment. The group that participates in the virtual reality sessions will use a Virtual Reality (VR) device to perform exercises in virtual environments for 5 minutes per session, while the other group will perform traditional stationary exercise on a cycle ergometer for 15 minutes per session. After the initial 10 sessions, participants will switch exercises to the next group. The measures taken for this study will be blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, heart rate variability indices, and laboratory tests, as well as a questionnaire for the quality of life of the patients and their anxiety and depression symptoms in response to their participation in the study. All of these measures will be taken before and after each session, for a total of 20 measurements (10 pre vs. 10 post) by the study groups. The data collected will be statistically analyzed after the completion of the study, which will allow comparisons between the two groups regarding the behavior of changes in heart rate variability indices, blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, and the score of the quality of life and anxiety and depression of the patients. The outcomes of this study will potentially lead to new ways of implementing effective exercise training programs for patients undergoing hemodialysis.

[/INST] The study entitled "Analysis of the relationship between ventilatory variability and dyspnea in patients under invasive mechanical ventilation during a weaning test" (NCT number: 00321185) is a non-blinded interventional study conducted at Centre hospitalier Valida. The primary objectives of the study are to determine the relationship between ventilatory variability and dyspnea during a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) and to determine whether airway flow, respiratory muscles, and other physiological variables correlate with dyspnea in these patients. Participants included in the study are patients aged ≥ 18 years old who are on invasive mechanical ventilation and are able to perform a SBT. Patients are monitored for ventilatory variability, dyspnea, and other variables using a chest strap, airflow sensor, and surface electromyography. Primary outcomes include clinically significant dyspnea using a Dyspnea visual analog scale (D-VAS) > 30 mm and Mechanical Ventilation Respiratory Distress Observation Scale (MV-RDOS) ≥ 2.6. Secondary outcomes include intensity of dyspnea using D-VAS/MV-RDOS scores, the success of the SBT, mechanical ventilation respiratory distress using MV-RDOS scores, the maximum amplitude and area under the envelope curve of the EMG signal of the extra-diaphragmatic respiratory muscles indicating dyspnoea, and mechanical ventilation respiratory drive measured by TI/TE and VT/TI ratios.

[/INST] The title of this manuscript is “Comparing a Modified Mini-incision Approach Versus the Conventional Approach for Carpal Tunnel Release” . The authors conducted a controlled trial and compared a modified mini-incision surgical approach versus the conventional surgical approach for carpal tunnel release. The objective of the study was to assess the effectiveness and safety of these two surgical techniques in the management of CTS.

[/INST] This study proposed to compare the effectiveness of action observation therapy in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) who observe the therapist and those who observe patients with MCI without cognitive impairment, and a control group that are not involved in any treatment plan. To measure the effectiveness, the research used a mixed-methods approach that included the administration of questionnaires and the use of observational instruments. The main outcome measures were the patients' cognitive and daily functionality, in addition to their gait, balance, and upper limb dexterity. The study intended to create a more comprehensive understanding of the effectiveness of action observation therapy in patients with MCI through the use of these outcome measures.

[/INST] The study presents a randomized controlled trial on the effectiveness of central line placement using an ultraportable ultrasound device. The study included adult patients who were scheduled for a central venous line placement preoperatively or in the ICU for central venous line placement. The objective of this study was the determination of the procedure time. Length of venous procedure was measured from the beginning of the ultrasound scan after the placement of sterile protection to the beginning of the catheter fixation to the skin through ultrasound verification, confirming the correct positioning of the catheter.

[/INST] This study evaluates the therapeutic efficacy of non-invasive Er:YAG laser treatment for episiotomy-related pain in postpartum patients. The lasers used are two different handpieces, the R11 micropulsation and PS03 modes, with different energy and power levels. These handpieces were applied to episiotomy scars to induce laser energy absorption and stimulate the production of collagen, leading to scar healing and pain reduction. The key findings of this study suggest that Er:YAG laser treatment can significantly reduce vulvar pain and improve scar tissue healing, while not causing adverse effects. Furthermore, the use of this laser treatment may also improve sexual function in patients with episiotomy.

[/INST] The research objective is the evaluation of the effects of a somatosensory therapy program on upper limb sensorimotor outcomes in children with a spastic hemiplegic cerebral palsy (CP) compared to a traditional motor therapy program. The study will be conducted in children with CP between 7 and 15 years of age. The primary outcome will be the changes in the functional use of the impaired hand within bimanual movements. The effects of somatosensory therapy will be compared to the effects of traditional motor therapy. The impact of the therapy on tactile perception skills, sensorimotor ability, and other motor functions (e.g., self-perceived occupational performance and self-care, leisure, and productivity activities) will also be evaluated. To be eligible for the study, children must also present a confirmed impairment in tactile functions and have a sufficient motivation and ability to understand and participate in the interventions. Patients who have undergone recent Botulinum toxin treatment or with other central nervous system disorders like genetic or metabolic abnormalities will be excluded from the study.

[/INST] The study titled “Understanding Changes in the Gut Microbiome in Patients with Gallstone Disease and Its Impact on Patient Outcomes” aims to investigate the gut microbiome of patients with gallstone disease and its impact on patient outcomes. The study will recruit adult patients diagnosed with gallstone disease through imaging confirming the diagnosis and collect blood, stool, and anthropometry, at admission and post-operatively at 6 months. A food card will be collected at each timepoint. Outcomes of interest will include complications of gallstone disease, short and intermediate post-operative outcomes.

[/INST] Elevated initial AST/PLT ratio index (APRI) value was associated with the occurrence of sepsis-associated liver dysfunction (SALD) in adults during hospitalization. The risk of SALD increased by 84% for every point increase in APRI. Other significant predictors of SALD included hypoxemia, age, and severe liver disease. The authors suggested that APRI could be a simple and useful prognostic tool for the identification of patients at risk for SALD. These findings should be validated in a larger cohort and implemented as a component of sepsis severity scores, such as the new modified Sequential Organ Failure Assessment.
[/INST] Clinical Study of Omicron BA.4/5-Delta Strain Recombinant Novel Coronavirus Protein Vaccine (CHO Cells)

[/INST] Analyse Of Early Skın To Skın Contact's Impact Upon Maternal-Infant Bondıng And Perceptıon Of Traumatıc Bırth. After a detailed description of the research, including inclusion and exclusion criteria and other relevant study procedures, it then clearly outlines the primary and secondary outcome measures.  The title states the name of the study, while the summary provides a concise and accurate description of the key aspects of the trial.

[/INST] The abstract presented a randomized, prospective, controlled, double-blind, single-center study conducted in patients undergoing elective lumbar discectomy. The patients were divided into two groups, and standard general anaesthesia was followed by either a bilateral sacral erector spinae plane block or nothing. The blocks were performed at the end of the operation, with patient-controlled analgesia and visual analogue scales used to measure pain for 24 hours. The authors found that patients who received a sacral erector spinae plane block had lower VAS scores and total morphine consumption. Tramadol PCA consumption, time to first analgesia, patient satisfaction, and nausea-vomiting did not differ between the two groups. Pre-anaesthetic and intraoperative data were not provided, as there were no statistical differences between the two groups. Therefore, further evaluation of the impact of erector spinae plane block on patients undergoing elective lumbar discectomy is needed.

[/INST] We summarize this clinical trial by Ultrasound Imaging for Myofascial Pain about multimodal ultrasound imaging to develop a practical and inexpensive biomarker for lumbar myofascial pain, which shows sensitivity to change in relation to treatment. The researchers plan to study the echogenicity of latent and active trigger points, thoracolumbar fascia-muscle deformation, and viscoelastic properties of the muscle and fascia measured by ultrasound. The investigators will recruit 10 subjects per age decile from ages 30-39 up to 90-99 (10 in each group). The trial also involves participants with no chronic pain over a three-year timeframe, along with those with myofascial pain without trigger points, myofascial pain with latent trigger points, and myofascial pain with active trigger points. The primary outcome measure is diagnosis of one of four mp-related categories. The secondary outcome measures are the presence of substantial mp.

[/INST] Pain Video Intervention Trial: The Pain Intervention Via Video Optimization Trial (PIVOT) is a two-armed, randomized controlled trial that investigates the effect of a telehealth video intervention on pain recovery and opioid use among patients with acute musculoskeletal pain who visited the ED or urgent care center. The intervention is a 15-minute educational video delivered to patients after discharge from the ED or urgent care; during the video, patients will watch and respond to several multiple-choice questions. The video encourages patients to engage with providers regarding treatment options. The primary outcome is combined pain severity and interference scores assessed using the Brief Pain Inventory-short form. The primary outcomes are evaluated at 3-months after discharge. PIVOT employs a two-stage cluster randomization process based on 10-month periods and two age groups. The cluster allocation is revealed following the inclusion of the last participant of the baseline period. The trial is currently recruiting participants.

[/INST] The trial aimed to evaluate the impact of the neuro-linguistic program on schoolchildren's academic performance. NLP is a technique used to improve communication skills, self-awareness and confidence, and academic performance. The study compared 45-minute group NLP sessions to a wait-list control group on various parameters and measures. To be included in the study, participants had to be school children between the ages of 5 and 11 and enrolled in primary school.

[/INST] “Emergency Structured Clinical Examination Training bOX” is a randomized clinical trial that examined the impact of using an ECOX teaching tool on the scores of emergency medicine students on emergency Structured Clinical Examination (SCE) compared to the ECOX learning tool and other learning approaches currently practiced. The toolbox contained 30 grids to be completed over 10 weeks. The primary outcome was the comparison of the average score of the students who used the ECOX tool to those who did not for SCEs. The secondary outcomes were comparisons of the degree of anxiety, behavior, and level of knowledge of those who used ECOX to those who did not.

[/INST] In this study, patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH) were randomized to receive either a web-based health care program (experimental) or usual care (control) interventions. The web-based health care program is designed to ameliorate social support, self-care ability, and active tolerance and improve symptoms, depression, and quality of life in patients with PH. The study will use the pulmonary arterial hypertension symptoms interventions scale (PAHSS), the 6MWD, the multidimensional scale of perceived social support (MSPSS), and the Cambridge pulmonary hypertension outcome review (CAMPHOR) to assess changes from baseline after six months and 12 months. The results of this study provide insights into the effects of web-based health care programs on patients with PH. The findings of this study are significant in terms of the improvement of quality support for patients with PH through the use of web-based health care programs in the future.

[/INST] Rational: The study titled "Effects of Long Term Ventilation Support on the Quality of Life of ALS Patients and their Families" aims to evaluate the quality of life of ALS patients who undergo long-term ventilator-assisted respiratory support, and to compare them to ALS patients who decline such support. The purpose of the study is to assess quality of life in patients with ALS using appropriate quality of life and symptom checklists. The study population is divided into two groups: those who accept long-term ventilation support, and those who decline. Two follow-up interviews are conducted at 3 and 15 months. The study includes several measures: quality of life, health-related quality of life, caregiver burden, and disease-specific quality of life of ALS patients who accept and decline long-term ventilator support.

[/INST] This study evaluates the impact of chronic/subacute subdural hematoma on neurological outcomes by monitoring spreading depolarization using ECoG monitoring. Patients with chronic or subacute subdural hematoma (cSDH) who undergo standard of care surgical evacuations will have transdural subdural ECoG monitoring electrode placed across the site of the subdural hematoma. Subjects will undergo follow-up testing. The incidence of neurologic deterioration within 5 days from surgical evacuation and 8-week mortality as well as 8-week functional outcomes (Extended Glasgow Outcome Scale, Montreal Cognitive Assessment, NIH toolbox, and PROMIS 29) are measured.

[/INST] MS patients who do not show any signs of recurrence following 2 years of treatment with Ocrelizumab are being offered a regimen of once a year (annual) or once every 6 months (biannual) Ocrelizumab infusions for a subsequent 2-year period. The study aims to assess the impact of these different dosing regimens to determine if the biannual regimen can provide comparable outcomes in terms of the absence of radiological disease activity to the annual regimen.

[/INST] The study aims to compare the impact on Quality of Recovery (QoR-15) of patients above 75 years undergoing surgery for colorectal cancer using the Combined Endoscopic Laparoscopic Surgery (CELS) method or conventional surgery.

[/INST] Nebulised 6% hypertonic saline was effective and safe in reducing respiratory infections. Patients with neuromuscular disorders had a lower number of antibiotic prescriptions and fewer hospitalizations. The study's secondary outcomes included lung function and quality of life, which showed positive effects from nebulized 6% hypertonic saline. Patients' adverse effects were comparable with placebo.

[/INST] The trial is a cross-sectional case-control study aimed at examining the prevalence of lifetime exposure to violence and the association with specific sexual behaviors. The study will involve 400 subjects, including individuals with high exposure to sexual violence, healthy controls, and individuals with paraphilic disorders, compulsive sexual behavior, and sleep disorders. Data will be collected through structured interviews, questionnaires, blood samples, and computerized testing.

[/INST] In this study from 2021, researchers conducted a single arm, non-randomized study. A total of 10 participants were recruited, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data was collected from all subjects. The primary outcome from this study was to characterize how the metabolic parameter kᵢₒ*V differs in tumor vs normal brain in patients with gliomas. Three sub-regions of the tumor core and periphery were assessed, as well as different normal appearing brain sub-regions. The secondary outcome was to compare how the aMRI metabolic parameter kᵢₒ*V changes with different disease types, stages, treatments, and in patients over time. In this study, investigators performed simultaneous PET scans to verify their results.

[/INST] Evaluating Strategies to Improve Guidelines Directed Medical Therapy, GREAT-HF Care is a planned cluster randomized trial to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions aiming to improve guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). The interventions include multifaceted clinical decision support (CDS), focused education, and referral to pharmacist co-management. Participants included eligible clinicians and patients with HFrEF. The main study outcomes were the proportion of eligible patients prescribed new GDMT classes at 30 days and proportions of additional SGLT2i or ARNI prescriptions within 30, 60, and 90 days. Key findings include increased rates of HFrEF medication prescribing in the multifaceted CDS group and pharmacist co-management group compared to the control group. Education-only interventions were less effective. The study highlights the importance of multifaceted interventions that include clinical decision support systems, education to healthcare providers, and community pharmacist co-management to improve guideline-directed medical therapy for heart failure.

[/INST] This is a randomized controlled trial that compares tamsulosin and ESWL combination therapy to ESWL-alone in patients with ureteral stones using a parallel assignment model. The patients are randomly assigned to receive ESWL-alone or ESWL and tamsulosin combination therapy. The trial includes participants between 18 and 70 years old with a single ureteral stone of 6-15 mm size.

[/INST] The purpose of the clinical trial titled Interventional Therapy of Tracheal Stenosis is to evaluate the technical and clinical success of various endoscopic and surgical interventions for treating tracheal stenosis that occur after percutaneous tracheostomy. The study will also measure the number of interventions needed and the time to decannulation. This is a multicenter trial that will involve 95 participants who are diagnosed with tracheal stenosis following percutaneous tracheostomy. All cases of tracheal stenosis above the tracheal cannula will be included. The primary completion date of the study is November 2023.

[/INST] The aim of this study is to evaluate the impact of sustained psychiatric intervention on viral exposure and psychiatric disorders in people who inject drugs (PWID) in Vietnam. The study will randomize two groups: a psychiatric intervention group and a control group of PWID diagnosed with a psychiatric disorder. The intervention group will receive a psychiatric consultation, medication, and continuous support from peer educators. The control group will receive harm reduction services and linkage to care for comorbidities, and the outcome will be compared to the intervention group. Viral exposure and psychiatric disorders such as depression, psychosis, and suicidal risk will be the primary and secondary outcomes of the study. The study will take place in Hai Phong, Vietnam, for one year.

[/INST] The primary purpose of this study is to compare the effectiveness of conventional endodontic therapy (ET) with a combination of PDT (photodynamic therapy) and ET, in the disinfection of root canals of individuals with apical lesion, using endoscopic instruments and the PAI index score to assess the lesion.

[/INST] The trial studied the effectiveness of psychoanalysis combined with psychopharmacotherapy of 1 patient with ASD. [/INST] The PIVCO (The Pulsed-field Ablation in Patients with Persistent Atrial Fibrillation) study is a prospective randomized clinical trial that compares the efficacy of a complex ablation strategy for the treatment of persistent atrial fibrillation to a less complex ablation strategy. The less complex strategy includes pulmonary vein isolation, while the more complex strategy adds ablations to isolate the posterior wall of the left atrium, mitral isthmus line, coronary sinus, and lines that target endocardial conduction on the right posterior septum, the roof, and the mitral isthmus. Patients will be followed up for one year, and outcomes such as recurrence of atrial fibrillation and quality of life will be measured. This study aims to determine a more standardized procedure representing optimal ablation strategy for patients suffering from paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.

[/INST] Head and neck (HN) cancers are the sixth most common cancer worldwide, and HPV infections of high oncogenic risk are strongly associated with HN cancers in developed countries . In the present study, a set of molecular characterization signatures to quantify HPV-positive and negative HN cancers is generated. Patients (n = 20) were diagnosed with oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma (OPSCC) or oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma (OCSCC). Tumor samples were analyzed via targeted capture next-generation sequencing (NGS). Somatic mutations were identified in a set of commonly mutated genes in HN cancer (n = 87 genes) and in hotspot regions of known driver genes (n = 48 genes). Furthermore, alterations in copy number variation (CNV) in cancer-driver genes were identified (n = 43), and gene fusion events across the coding genomic region were characterized (n = 51). The results show that HPV-negative HN cancer is associated with a higher somatic mutation burden, while HPV-positive HN cancer is associated with higher CNV and gene fusion rates.

[/INST] The study aims to evaluate the effects of prone position training on the incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications in colorectal surgery patients. The study has two groups: the experimental group (PPT group) who will receive prone position training, and the control group (C group) who will receive standard perioperative care without prone position training. The incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs) in patients will be analyzed and compared between the groups at 7 days after surgery. Other outcomes include arterial partial oxygen pressure (PaO2), arterial partial carbon dioxide pressure (PaCO2), arterial oxygen saturation (SpO2), oxygenation index, and extubation time. The study found that pulmonary complications after abdominal surgery have been reported between 9% and 40%. Decreased lung compression caused by the gravity of fluids, redistribution of fluids, reduction of transpulmonary pressure, compression and flattening of dependent pulmonary zones, changes in gravity-dependent ventilation, and decreased end-expiratory lung volume has been linked to the occurrence of pulmonary complications. In a literature review, the benefits associated with prone positioning are well known, including homogenisation of transpulmonary pressure, decreased lung compression, improved ventilation/perfusion ratio and, ventilation, and decreased P-SILI. The study found a significant reduction in pulmonary complications in the PPT group compared with the C group at 7 days. After surgery, arterial partial oxygen pressure (PaO2) remained stable and arterial partial carbon dioxide pressure (PaCO2) in the PPT group showed a significant decrease. Also, a lower oxygenation index (OI) was found in the C group but did not differ between the groups. However, arterial partial oxygen level with end-expiratory held breath (PEEP) titration was significantly lower in the C group. Overall, the results indicate that prone positioning training and the resulting reduction in pulmonary complications may improve pulmonary function during early recovery after colorectal cancer surgery.

The study also aims to gain an understanding of the treatment modalities employed and the organisation of geriatric rehabilitation. The study employs the methodological approach of observational cohort studies. The data collection process involves the collection of anonymised routinely available healthcare data. The duration of the study is estimated to be 2 to 3 years. A sample size of at least 52 patients per country will be required to achieve a power of 80% and a level of significance of 5% (two sided). The statistical analysis will involve the use of descriptive statistics, multilevel analyses, and paired sample t-tests. This study has the potential to contribute to the development of evidence-based recommendations to guide future clinical practice.

The summarized result of this clinical trial suggests that the use of enteral contrast in the non-operative management of ASBO in children did not have significant differences in clinical outcomes, including the rate of subsequent operations, length of hospital stay, or rate of adverse effects. Contrast-enhanced CT scans may help surgeons assess treatment efficacy and guide the decision to take patients to surgery, but the use of any oral contrast agent is likely to interfere with subsequent CT scans and may pose a potential risk of aspiration of contrast in young children or those with an increased risk of aspiration. Therefore, the study suggests that enteral contrast should only be used with patients who are candidates for surgery and have failed a conservative non-operative approach.

[/INST] This randomized controlled crossover study will evaluate the effect of immersive virtual reality (IVR) on the level of dyspnea in patients with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) receiving non-invasive ventilation (NIV) (El Escorial, 1994). The intervention is expected to alleviate the symptoms of dyspnea and anxiety in ALS patients. The study will use questionnaires and interviews to assess the efficacy of IVR in decreasing dyspnea in ALS patients. The questionnaires and interviews will be collected before and after the intervention. The efficacy of IVR will be measured using the Multidimensional Dyspnea Profile (MDP) questionnaire, which is a validated instrument for measuring dyspnea and its symptoms in lung disease patients. The study aims to determine whether the use of IVR could mitigate the symptoms of dyspnea in ALS patients. Previous studies have shown that IVR is effective in reducing pain and anxiety in patients with chronic diseases. This study proposes to replicate that experimental protocol on ALS patients. The results of the study could significantly impact the management of dyspnea in ALS patients and improve their quality of life. The findings of this study could also have implications for the management of dyspnea in other chronic diseases.

The secondary outcome measures include the rate of directed broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing (i.e., within 5 days after the antibiotic susceptibility testing), the rate of antibiotic de-escalation (modification of a broad-spectrum empirical antibiotic therapy to a targeted narrow-spectrum antibiotic therapy), and the rate of antibiotic prescription as a function of the number of selective antibiotic susceptibility tests received per practice, both as a continuous and ordinal variable.

[/INST] The title of the article is “Sodium Valproate Improves Clinical Outcomes in Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke: a Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial”. This study is a phase II, pilot, randomized, double-blind, non-placebo controlled, parallel-group trial to test whether sodium valproate could improve clinical outcomes in patients with acute ischemic stroke. Participants who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria are enrolled in the trial. They are randomized to receive one of the following treatments: low-dose sodium valproate group, high-dose sodium valproate group or placebo group for a period of 3 days after admission. During admission, the participants will be followed up at 28 days and 90 days. The main outcome of this study is the proportion of favorable outcomes (mRS score ≤ 2) at 90 days and mRS at 90 days and at 30 days. Other outcomes include mRS at 3 days and 7 days, infarct lesion volume, NIHSS at day 3, and day 7, and length of hospital stay.

[/INST] The study is a parallel non-randomized comparative effectiveness trial evaluating a virtual coach for preoperative weight loss in patients with obesity and ventral hernia. The participants will be allocated to one of two arms. The intervention arm will use the virtual coach, and the control arm will use the standard weight loss tools. The participants in the interventional arm will use the MyChart-enabled virtual coach (MyChart is an online connected health tool available through a hospital system) to manage their care and aid preoperative weight loss. The primary outcome is the average net weight change per group. Participants will be recruited for a 6-month study. At enrollment, demographics data will be collected. The outcome measures will be collected at baseline and 6-month visits. At 6 months, participants will answer questions about their satisfaction with the virtual coach on a 1-7 point Likert scale, and the results will be analyzed to compare satisfaction scores between the two arms. The results will help evaluate and determine the efficacy of the virtual coach as a weight loss tool.

[/INST] This clinical trial, named "Description of Septic Thrombophlebitis on Central Venous Catheter and Midline," is conducted at the Dermatology and Venereology Department of CHUA Hospital in Strasbourg, France. The aim of the study is to demonstrate whether Doppler ultrasound (US) can help in the clinical decision to remove or maintain a treatment of the infected peripheral venous catheter. The study was carried out on 17 patients who developed catheter-related sepsis and were hospitalised and transportable for Doppler ultrasound. The patients were identified based on the definition of catheter-related sepsis (ePOPI: positive blood cultures within 48 hours of a suspected catheter infection (or its removal) with one of the following criteria: differential time of positivity of central/peripheral blood cultures ≥ 2 hours; positive catheter culture ≥ 103 CFU/ml, with the same organism). All hospitalised, transportable, consenting, and affiliated to social security patients with a central venous catheter or midline who developed catheter-related sepsis were included in the study, while patients who declined consent, had a life expectancy of less than one month, had contraindications to anticoagulation, and were already under curative anticoagulant therapy were excluded from the study. The patients were randomly divided into two groups based on their venous Doppler ultrasounds and the presence (Group 1) or the absence (Group 2) of thrombosis. Their follow-up was conducted at day 8, 15, 30, 45, 60 and 90, with the primary outcome measure being the measurement of the duration of ultrasound signs of septic thrombophlebitis. The patients in the case group (Group 1) were shown to be more likely to not manifest ultrasound signs of sepsis. In light of these findings, the hospital decided to implement Doppler ultrasound for catheter-related sepsis patients as a standard of care.

[/INST] This clinical trial is a hospital-based cross sectional comparative study that will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Universitaire Valencia No. 1. The trial will enroll 60 patients with pterygium who will be followed for a period of up to three weeks after surgery. CD44, E-cadherin, and PCNA expressions in surgically excised pterygium tissue will be compared with tissue samples from a control group consisting of normal conjunctiva from 30 patients. Thin sections will be taken from paraffin-embedded tissue samples and tested using immunohistochemistry. CD44 (1:50 dilution), E-cadherin (1:200 dilution), and PCNA (1:100 dilution) will be stained. The results of the study show that these markers may be useful as prognostic indicators of recurrence of pterygium after surgical removal. The statistical validity of the study is based on the sample size provided, and statistical analyses using SPSS will be performed to determine the level of expression of the three markers. The limitations of the study include the lack of data on the risk factors for the development of pterygium and the short period of follow-up. The study is expected to provide useful information that can be used in the treatment of pterygium to determine the type of surgical intervention or the need for adjuvant therapy.

[/INST] TINO is a clinical trial that seeks to investigate the underlying mechanisms and consequences of age-associated loss of nasal T cells. The study will recruit 18-30-year-old young adults, 65+ healthy older adults, and 65+ frail older adults, and the participants will be asked to provide nose swabs and blood samples at baseline and every three months. Additionally, young adults who experience respiratory symptoms within three months will provide nose swabs and blood samples at months 1, 3, and 5 post-symptom onset. The study will involve measuring the frequency and phenotype of T cells, T-cell functionality, T-cell clone size, T-cell transcriptomic profiles, and nasal and peripheral immune cell stability. The study will also evaluate the potential association of nasal microbiota and respiratory tract microbiota with T-cells and other immune parameters. Another aspect of the study is to investigate the potential sex-specific differences in T-cell frequencies related to aging. Lastly, the study will explore the frequency of antigen-specific T cells in the nose and blood during viral infection.

[/INST] BRANT is a multicenter, randomized, controlled, open-label, parallel clinical trial that investigates the efficacy and safety of tirofiban in acute BAD-related stroke patients. [/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of telepharmacy for elderly patients with arterial hypertension. The primary goal is to characterize the clinical and sociodemographic features of patients, as well as compare acceptance and clinical significance of interventions in telepharmacy and in-person consultations. Secondary objectives are to determine the adherence of medication treatment using telepharmacy, satisfaction of patients, and difference in satisfaction between telepharmacy and in-person patients. Interventions are telepharmaceutical care and usual care, performed by a pharmacist from an information system of patient monitoring using teleconsultations via phone. Pharmacists were trained on pharmaceutical care protocols (intervention group) using the pharmaceutical information system. Each patient was assessed 3 times per month, and each session lasted 20-30 minutes. The control group received usual care, which involved face-to-face pharmacist education and counseling on medication management. Patients were aged 60 years or older and had arterial hypertension. Blood pressure readings were performed three times; the average of the last three values is compared between intervention and control groups. Adherence to treatment was measured using an adherence scale, and patient satisfaction was evaluated via a satisfaction scale and comparison between groups. Patient-level clinical significance of interventions was measured using the DOCUMENT. Patients are recruited for the study from hospitals in Valencia, Spain. The results indicated no significant difference in the rate of systolic/diastolic blood pressure target between the control and the teleconsultation groups. However, the teleconsultation group shows 94.4% adherence and satisfaction rates compared to 84.1% and 87.5% for the control group. The results also reveal higher patient satisfaction for the telepharmacist group compared to the in-person group.

It will evaluate the minimum diagnostics necessary for a venous ulcer and the cost-effectiveness of implementing this in both a primary or secondary care setting. In addition, it will establish a minimum data set to be collected for diagnostic and follow-up purposes, and identify the best diagnostic imaging techniques available for monitoring venous ulcers with the highest quality of evidence; however, there is no indication of how such evidence was obtained. The results are expected to improve the management of venous ulcers and assist in the establishment of standardized protocols. The target populations are primary care practitioners for the questionnaire-based study and vascular scientists for the consensus Delphi approach. The study design consists of online questionnaires. For the primary care practitioners, a single questionnaire is administered, while for vascular scientists, a series of Delphi questionnaires are proposed in the report. The Delphi consensus protocol is based on a three-stage Delphi questionnaire, each consisting of a two-week questionnaire. In summary, the study examines the diagnosis and management of venous ulcers in both primary and secondary health care and aims to establish a standardized protocol for monitoring venous ulcers based on the best available evidence.

[/INST] Background: Clinical deterioration occurs in approximately 5% of hospitalized adults. Delays in recognition of deterioration heighten the risk of adverse outcomes. Machine learning algorithms enhance clinical decision-making and can improve the quality of patient care. However, their impact on clinical outcomes depends not only on the sensitivity and specificity of the algorithm but also on how well the algorithm is integrated into provider workflows and facilitates timely and appropriate intervention. Preliminary Data: eCART has been built upon more than a decade of ongoing scientific research and chronicled in numerous peer-reviewed publications. eCART was developed at the University of Chicago by Drs. Dana Edelson and Matthew Churpek. The first version (eCARTv1) was derived and validated using linear logistic regression in a dataset of nearly 60,000 adult ward patients from a single medical center. That model had 16 variables in it and was subsequently validated in silent mode, demonstrating that eCART could alert clinicians more than 24 hours in advance of ICU transfer or cardiac arrest. eCARTv2, derived and validated in a dataset of nearly 270,000 patients from 5 hospitals, improved upon the earlier version by utilizing a cubic spline logistic regression model with 27 variables and demonstrated improved accuracy over the Modified Early Warning Score (MEWS), a commonly used score that can be hand- calculated by nurses at the bedside (AUC 0.77 vs. 0.70 for cardiac arrest, ICU transfer or death). In a multicenter clinical implementation study, eCARTv2 was associated with a 29% relative risk reduction for mortality. In further development of eCART, the University of Chicago research team demonstrated that upgrading from a cubic spline model to a machine learning model, such as a random forest or gradient boosted machine (GBM), could increase the AUC. In the most recent development - eCART v5 - the research team has advanced the analytic using a gradient boosted machine learning model trained on a multi-center dataset of more than 800,000 patient records. Now with 97 variables, this more sophisticated model increases the accuracy by which clinicians can predict clinical deterioration.

[/INST] The ASSET-PPD study examines the effectiveness of a 4-module support program aimed at training fathers on alleviating their partners’ perinatal depression. [/INST] This study is a phase IV randomized controlled trial that investigates the effectiveness and safety of busulfan-containing conditioning regimens for hematopoietic stem cell transplantation in severe aplastic anemia patients with HLA-matched sibling or unrelated donor. The study aims to compare the efficacy and safety of two conditioning regimens, one with flu, cyclophosphamide, and antithymocyte globulin (ATG) and one with cyclosporine A and mycophenolate mofetil (cy/my) for graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) prophylaxis in patients with severe aplastic anemia undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation with a HLA-matched sibling or unrelated donor. The two conditioning regimens differ based on the patients' risk for mixed chimerism. The primary objective is to investigate failure-free survival (FFS) in the two patient groups. FFS was defined as the time from transplantation to an event or death without relapse of the disease with a duration of at least one year post transplantation. Other outcomes include the patients' overall survival, event-free survival, and the incidence of grades II-IV and III-IV acute GvHD based on the Seattle criteria and chronic GvHD, using the criteria of the National Institutes of Health consensus project. The patients were followed for 180 days after transplantation. The results showed that the conditioning regimen including busulfan, fludarabine, and antithymocyte globulin (Bu/Flu/ATG) had no advantage over the Bu/cy/my regimen in terms of failure-free and overall survival. The authors concluded that both conditioning regimens could be used for hematopoietic stem cell transplantation in patients with severe aplastic anemia.

[/INST] The main objective of the clinical trial is to determine if prophylactic treatment with fitusiran (a drug developed by Spirox-Teva pharmaceuticals) is effective in preventing and treating severe hemophilia A cases. Hemophilia is a rare blood disorder that affects males by causing their blood to clot poorly. Fitusiran works by inhibiting the production of activated factor VIII (FVIII), which is needed for clot formation. By inhibiting FVIII, fitusiran prevents bleeding. Participants in the clinical trial will receive either fitusiran or emicizumab (another drug that is approved by the FDA for hemophilia A) as part of the prophylactic treatment. Previous studies have shown that emicizumab is effective in preventing bleeding in some severe hemophilia A cases. The goal of the clinical trial is to compare the effectiveness of fitusiran and emicizumab, by comparing the frequency of bleeding and other outcomes in participants receiving each drug. The specific eligibility criteria include being male younger than 65 years old, having severe hemophilia A, having inhibitors present, and having responded to emicizumab prophylaxis. The clinical trial will last for 12 months, and participants will be followed for 4 months after they stop receiving any form of study treatment. The results of the clinical trial are expected to show whether fitusiran is effective in preventing and treating severe hemophilia A cases.

[/INST] This clinical trial was a randomized, controlled study designed to compare the effectiveness of post facilitation stretch (PFS) with Maitland mobilization in improving pain and disability, and increasing ROM (flexion, extension, supination, and pronation) in patients with post-traumatic stiff elbow. The trial included 32 patients (30% male, average age of 21 years) who were randomly assigned to the intervention or control group. The intervention group received Maitland mobilization for 1 minute, three times per day, five days per week, for 4 weeks, while the control group received post facilitation stretch (6-10 seconds isometric contraction followed by 15 seconds of passive stretch) for the same duration. All patients received active and active-assisted exercises for the elbow, wrist, and forearm for 10 minutes, three times per day, five days per week, for 4 weeks. The primary outcomes were pain at rest and activity, elbow flexion and extension ROM, forearm supination and pronation ROM. The secondary outcome was elbow and forearm ROM (flexion and extension, supination and pronation). This trial was conducted in a single-center, outpatient setting, and the main analysis was performed on the intention-to-treat population. The trial had a relatively low risk of bias according to the Cochrane risk-of-bias tool. While Maitland mobilization and post facilitation stretch have shown comparable effectiveness in several trials, further research is needed on the efficacy and safety of these interventions in individuals with post-traumatic stiff elbow.

Participants are monitored with ECG, vital signs, and blood pressure, and will undergo an exercise test to measure their oxygen uptake and their peak exercise capacity (VO2peak). Following this testing, the participants will undergo different stages of lower body negative pressure (LBNP) to induce hypovolemia, with no intravenous volume expansion or with intravenous acetated Ringer′s solution given, while receiving cardiac output (CO) measurement. The experimental visits are followed by a recovery visit. All data will be analyzed using statistical methods, including pharmacokinetic modelling. The primary outcome is the half-life of change in cardiac stroke volume, and the secondary outcomes are intravascular volume and middle cerebral artery blood flow velocity. The clinical significance of this study is the ability to determine the volume expansion effect of Ringer′s acetate solution and its changes, and the hemodynamic effects on CO, stroke volume, and brain oxygenation.

[/INST] Small bowel obstructions (SBOs) occur when the flow of fluid and/or food through the small intestine is stopped or slowed. SBOs are common complications of abdominal surgery and can require a second operation to correct if they are adhesive. Treating aSBO may involve using a nasogastric tube (NGT) to decompress the bowel. This is a tube that is inserted into the patient’s throat, through their abdomen and into their stomach. The tube can help the bowel function by draining the abdomen of fluid and intestinal contents. The study aimed to evaluate the effects of using water-soluble contrast (WSC) with NGT insertions for aSBO treatment. The study will assess the quality of life after the different treatments through a survey questionnaire. By comparing different aSBO treatment methods and evaluating the effectiveness of water-soluble contrast with NGT insertion, the goal is to determine the best way to treat abdominal bloating and pain in SBO patients. The study will determine if water-soluble contrast is harmful or improves bowel function and quality of life for aSBO patients and help to decide if using water-soluble contrast will help to improve care for SBO patients.

There was a significant main effect of stabilization and stabilization related parameters on the shooting performance of the archery athletes. It was concluded that the stabilization of the body regions (cervical, thoracic, lumbosacral, and scapular regions) has a positive effect on the archery performance.

[/INST] Trotabresib, also known as CC-101, CC-90010, and 3-(3-((S)-2-Amino-1,4-dihydroxy-3-(((3S)-2-((S)-1H-tetrazol-5-yl)propyl)-5-oxopyrrolidin-3-yl)propoxy)-4ethyl)-5-oxopyrazolidin-2-yl)]-2,1,3-benzoxadiazole, is a small molecule inhibitor of DNA topoisomerase 1B (TOP1). TOP1 plays an essential role in separating and recombining duplex DNA during transcription, replication, recombination, and repair (27). TOP1-DNA covalent intermediates can lead to DNA damage and TOP1 inhibitors can stabilize this complex resulting in increased DNA damage, cell cycle arrest and cell apoptosis. TOP1B is expressed in different human organs and tumor cells. TOP1 is overexpressed in many tumor cell lines and also plays a crucial role in cancer development and progression. Therefore, TOP1 has been identified as an attractive drug target for cancer therapy.

[/INST] The trial entitled "Treating Binge Eating and Obesity Digitally in Black Women" aims to modify and adapt a validated program to be a culturally-relevant digital health tool for binge eating and weight management for Black women with obesity who binge eat. These aims will be achieved through conducting usability testing with a group of stakeholders to guide content and design refinements and refining the tool. The second aim is to examine feasibility and preliminary efficacy of the digital health appetite awareness + behavioral weight program in a randomized clinical trial in primary care. The study will measure the feasibility of the trial (recruitment, retention, and percentage of sessions attended), attendance, weight regain, and binge eating episodes. The trial is expected to create new strategies for Black women to address binge eating and related weight gain using digital health tools.

[/INST] The study, "The Effect of Beetroot Juice Supplementation Dose on Neuromuscular Performance During Resistance Exercise," investigates the effects of different doses of beetroot juice supplementation on neuromuscular performance during resistance exercise. The study uses a randomized crossover design to compare the impact of a high, moderate, low, and placebo dose of nitrate-rich beetroot juice shots on variables such as plasma nitrate, nitrite, peak, and average propulsion force, rate of power development, peak positive power, concentric mean power, jump height, take-off velocity, and flight time during a countermovement jump task. The participants complete a test at four separate visits with a washout period of one year between each visit. The results suggest that only the high and moderate doses of beetroot juice are effective in improving some performance parameters. The study highlights that it is not sufficient to achieve an ergogenic effect with a low dose of beetroot juice. Additionally, the study provides evidence that nitrate supplementation is not as effective for resistance exercise compared to endurance exercise. The study concludes that nitrate supplementation can enhance lower body explosive performance during resistance exercise in untrained individuals.

[/INST] The Effects of an Nutritional Intervention on PD-1 ICI in NSCLC is a randomized controlled parallel group study to investigate how daily nutritional intervention using specific nutrients during immunotherapy in oncology patients influences progression-free survival. The study protocol is a feasibility study in order to gain experience with the intervention in the clinic. Data collection and quality control will be evaluated as it is believed that patients are often not fully compliant with the study protocol.

[/INST] The abstract summarizes a clinical trial titled Effectiveness of a Proprioceptive Neuromuscular Facilitation for Ankle Dorsiflexion in Professional Table Tennis Players. The study is a randomized controlled trial with a crossover design. The study aims to compare the effects of Proprioceptive Neuromuscular Facilitation (PNF) to increase ankle dorsiflexion range and eccentric training combined with electrical stimulation. The intervention group received PNF and eccentric exercise with electrical stimulation (ES). The control group received eccentric training combined with ES. Both groups were tested before and after treatment, and after a follow-up period of one month. The PNF protocol consisted of proprioceptive stimuli of passive and active movements, and muscle strength tests to determine the success of the interventions. The eccentric exercises with electrical stimulation consisted of the combination of plantar flexion exercises, with the application of the ES, using specific amplitudes and intensities. The secondary objective of the study was to analyze the effect of interventions on the drop jump test, through ankle valgus. All subjects who meet the inclusion criteria, as well as those who meet the exclusion criteria, will be included in the study. The duration of the study was not provided. The study protocol was conducted according to the Declaration of Helsinki and was registered in ClinicalTrials.gov. The study population included healthy professionals and non-elite athletes without musculoskeletal or neurological conditions. The main outcome measures included dorsal range of motion ankles assessed by weight-bearing lunge test, ankle dorsiflexion range, and drop jump test with ankle valgus. The study results have not been published.

[/INST] Nutritional Counselling Promoting Adherence to the Mediterranean Diet as Adjuvant in the Treatment of Major Depressive Disorder: A Randomized Open Controlled Trial Study" is a study looking at the effectiveness of adding nutrition counseling to treatment for major depressive disorder. The study will test the hypothesis that an intervention promoting adherence to a Mediterranean diet can decrease symptoms of depression in patients with major depressive disorder who have elevated inflammation biomarkers, such as C-reactive protein (CRP) or interleukin 6 (IL-6). The study will compare the effectiveness of adding a nutrition counseling intervention to treatment for major depressive disorder to treatment for major depressive disorder alone in decreasing symptoms of depression. The primary outcome of the study is the decrease in symptoms of depression measured by the Beck Depression Inventory-II (BDI-II) scale at 12 weeks, six and 12 months after baseline. The study is designed as a randomized, open, multicenter parallel-group controlled trial with two arms (intervention and control group). Participants will be 18-70 years old, with a diagnosis of major depressive disorder, taking antidepressant medication, with elevated CRP, and having a score on the BDI-II scale of 14 or greater. The study plans to enroll 190 participants (95 per arm) from outpatient clinics. The study will consist of six nutrition consultations promoting the Mediterranean diet, additional to usual treatment for major depressive disorder, for the intervention group. The primary analysis will compare the difference in the decrease in symptoms of depression between the intervention and control groups using a mixed-effects regression model. The study has the potential to provide information about the effectiveness of adding a nutrition intervention to treatment for major depressive disorder in decreasing symptoms of depression and potentially improving outcomes in patients with major depressive disorder.

[/INST] This two-armed randomized controlled study examines the impact of a participatory approach to parenting education on parental mental health and observable parenting behaviors. The study examines the effects of a 4-week curriculum consisting of 8 curricula adapted for the local refugee community. The study enrolls participants residing in refugee shelters in Tijuana who are parents of school-age children. Participants will be randomized to an intervention arm or a wait-list control arm. Participants in the intervention arm will participate in the parenting curriculum twice a week for four weeks during month 3 of the study, while participants in the control arm will receive a handout about parenting techniques in Spanish during month 3. During months 4 and 5 of the study, participants in the control arm will receive the same parenting curriculum that the intervention arm receives. Prior information about parenting knowledge and behaviors will be collected, and this information will be collected again during months 4-5 of the study. For the duration of the study, researchers will conduct interviews on the effectiveness of the program and collect information from parents and caregivers. The study will implement 8 curriculums (1) GenerationPMTO, (2) Happy Parenting, (3) Family Group Meeting, (4) Family Strengthening Intervention for Refugees, (5) Strong African-American Families, (6) Creating Opportunities Through Mentoring Parental Involvement and Safe Spaces, (7) Family Focus, and (8) Healthy Families.
