[/INST] The trial's aim is to find out the success rate and safety of using artificial urinary sphincters or male slings to treat male stress urinary incontinence. The study involves using a registry to collect information on patient characteristics, surgery details, and questionnaires to determine the success rate of the procedure and outcomes at 12 weeks, 12 months, 2-years, 3-years, 4-years and 5-years. The trial will investigate the cure rate, time being continent, time being revision-free, quality of life, and general and specific post-operative adverse events as measured by the primary and secondary outcomes. The trial will involve patients aged 18 years or older undergoing surgery for male stress incontinence using artificial urinary sphincters or male slings. The surgery will be performed using standard procedures. The trial will use a non-randomized study design. The primary outcome is the success rate (cure plus improvement); the secondary outcomes are time being continent and time being revision-free, quality of life, and general and specific post-operative adverse events. The results of the trial will be presented in a clinical report, presented at scientific meetings, and published in a peer-reviewed scientific journal.

[/INST] The study titled "PET Imaging of 68Ga-NOTA-H006 in Malignancy" evaluated the use of 68Ga-NOTA-H006 as a radiotracer for detecting cancer. The study was approved by the review board and was conducted in accordance with the ICH-GCP guidelines. The study participants were patients with pancreatic, lung and colorectal cancer and were given intravenous injections of the radiotracer. The radiotracer was evaluated for diagnostic accuracy by comparing the PET images with histological evaluation of the tumors. The study found that the radiotracer was highly sensitive and specific for detecting the cancer. Additionally, the radiotracer had a low background uptake in normal tissues and organs, making it ideal for use in PET imaging of cancer. Overall, these findings suggest that 68Ga-NOTA-H006 may be used as a useful new radiotracer for detecting and managing cancer.

[/INST] This study protocol is for a cohort study that collects blood samples, heart tissue, and clinical data from patients with heart failure who are eligible for cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) or medical treatment. Patients in the CRT group will be subjected to a heart biopsy before CRT implantation and at 3 months. Changes in ejection fraction (EF) and cardiac remodeling will be evaluated via echocardiography, along with analysis of tissue and blood samples to identify biological mechanisms associated with CRT response. Patients in the medical treatment group will also contribute blood samples, and some will undergo a heart biopsy. Analysis of tissue and blood samples will be performed as for the CRT group to identify heart failure progression. The study will compare cardiac remodeling and mechanisms of CRT and medical treatment response. The aim is to identify a biomarker or subset of markers that can predict patient response to CRT.

[/INST] In this two-armed interventional study, patients with chronic heart failure (LVEF ≤ 45%) and symptoms of dyspnea/shortness of breath and edema are randomized to receive one of the following treatments: (I) GDMT plus vericiguat (1–3.6 mg orally with dose up-titration, with dose adjustment depending on renal function) or (II) GDMT alone. The primary outcome measures include all-cause mortality, worsening heart failure in 180 days. Patients enrolled in this study are either intolerable or tolerable to GDMT, which consists of ACEI/ARB/ARNI, β blocker, SGLT2i and MRA. The follow-up period is 180 days from the start of vericiguat treatment.

[/INST] The trial is evaluating the efficacy and safety of PRO adherence improvement strategies. Participants will be randomized to receive prompting for either encounter-based or remote weekly questionnaires. Strategies will incorporate patient reminders and triage nurse alerts for severe symptoms. All patients will be assessed for functional and pain status, overall symptoms, toxicity, and depression pre-treatment and after each cycle of treatment (month 1, 2, and 6). Blood samples will be collected for biomarker analyses, and safety will be monitored.

[/INST] The ProgESC Study is a clinical trial that aims to assess prognostic awareness among cancer patients. Specifically, it aims to determine if cancer patients, especially those that have been referred to the Enhanced Supportive Care (ESC) service, have an accurate and thorough understanding of their prognosis. The ProgESC Study aims to do this by surveying patients with advanced cancer who have been referred to the ESC team at University College London Hospital, and asking participating patients about their prognostic understanding. It uses the Prognosis and Treatment Perception Questionnaire, which covers the perceived prognosis, desired amount of information, and perceived helpfulness of prognostic information. Secondary endpoints of the study include patient psychological symptoms, such as depression and anxiety, patient symptoms, perceived quality of care. The study will collect data and will examine associations between patients' characteristics and their prognostic understanding. Participating patients include those with advanced cancer referred to the ESC team at University College London Hospital. The data will be collected through self-administered patient surveys and the participants will be 18 years or older with advanced cancer. The study will collect data on 100 participants. The data collection is still ongoing. In the end, this study will inform the future development of clinical strategies to improve care and communication with patients with advanced cancer.

[/INST] This study is a pragmatic, randomized controlled trial with parallel group assignment evaluating the effectiveness of the T2Bacteria® panel test for blood cultures in reducing intravenous vancomycin and systemic anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam antibiotic use in patients with bloodstream infections or sepsis. The study will compare direct-from-blood T2Bacteria® panel testing with standard blood cultures on time to last dose of intravenous vancomycin and systemic anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam antibiotic. The study is set to be conducted at a single academic medical center in Tennessee, United States. The T2Bacteria® panel test uses molecular polymerase chain reaction technology to rapidly detect 11 of the most common bloodstream pathogens after collecting a single tube of blood.

[/INST] This study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of armbath, an approach within hydrotherapy, on arterial hypertension. Fifty participants with arterial hypertension who meet the inclusion criteria and do not fulfill the exclusion criteria will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. For the intervention group, participants will perform a temperature-elevating armbath on 5 out of 7 days of the week for 8 weeks in total. Participants will be instructed on how to perform armbath and were given a diary to note down their performance. The effects of armbath on participants blood pressure will be assessed after 24-hours ambulatory blood pressure measurements at the beginning of the trial, after 8 weeks of intervention, and after 6 months. Blood pressure, sleep quality, physical quality of life, and adverse events will be assessed as outcome measures of the study. Participants will also undergo a health-related quality of life questionnaire (SF-12) at the 8 week and the 6 month follow up.

[/INST] Acupuncture Therapy for Perceived Stress in Military Service and Veterans: A Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT). The primary aim of this study is to evaluate if MSSA and group psychotherapy can significantly reduce perceived stress in active duty military service members and veterans. The study is designed in such a way that the study participants in the experimental group receive MSSA and group psychotherapy. On the other hand, the participants in the comparative group are treated with group psychotherapy without any acupuncture intervention. Each participant's perceived stress level will be determined by the PSS score both before and after the trial. The result of this study might contribute to the use of integrative mind-body therapies to improve the management of stress-related conditions in military service and veterans.

[/INST] The study, "Culturally Adapted Psychosocial Interventions for Early Psychosis in a Low-resource Setting," aims to evaluate the effectiveness of culturally adapted psychosocial interventions, namely the Functional Remediation or Employability of Family Support intervention and the Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Psychosis intervention, in reducing the symptoms of schizophrenia among individuals with early psychosis in Pakistan. Both interventions are considered to be efficacious, and the study is a pragmatic parallel-group randomized controlled trial that will receive partial funding from the UK Medical Research Council (UKMRC). The trial will recruit 390 participants from ten centres in Pakistan, with individuals experiencing their first episode of psychosis being the primary study population. The interventions will be delivered by psychology trainees in collaboration with existing staff at the services and will be adapted from protocols that have shown positive results in different contexts. The Functional Remediation or Employability of Family Support intervention and the Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Psychosis intervention will be compared to treatment as usual, with both intervention groups undergoing sessions for a total of 12 weeks and 10 weeks, respectively. The primary outcome measure is symptom severity at 3, 6, and 12 months measured by the Positive and Negative Symptoms Scale (PANSS), with secondary outcome measures including quality of life, depression, and functioning. The primary analysis is on the PANSS scale, with a total sample size of 390 participants being the target.

[/INST] The title of the study is "Study of IMPT-314 in R/R Aggressive B-cell NHL". This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of IMPT-314, a CD19/20 bispecific chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell therapy, in patients with relapsed or refractory aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. The primary endpoint of the trial is to determine the incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs), including dose-limiting toxicities (DLTs). The secondary endpoint is to investigate the overall response rate (ORR), duration of response (DOR), complete response (CR) rate, duration of CR, median progression-free survival (PFS), median overall survival (OS), maximum concentration of IMPT-314 in serum (Cmax from time 0 to Day 28), area under the curve of C-314 in serum from time 0 to Day 28 (AUC0-28), and persistence of IMPT-314.

The study found that, compared to the control group, the intervention group had significant improvement in sleep quality, depression score, and heart rate variability.

[/INST] The "Experience Dependent Development of the Cortex" study aims to gain insight into the process and effects of experience-dependent development of the cortex, which is the cognitive hub of the brain. [/INST] This is a non-randomized, open-label study. Qualifying patients will receive a single intravitreal administration of BI 771716 for the purpose of assessing its safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics in patients with age-related macular degeneration. The study will follow a sequential assignment method, with patients being assigned to one of five treatment groups based on their qualification and then dose escalations. Treatment groups are either a single rising (SRD) dose or multiple dose (MD) of BI 771716 over time. The study will be administered at multiple visits. At baseline, participants will undergo several eye exams, including a slit lamp exam, dilated dilatation and ophthalmoscopy, visual acuity testing, Optical Coherence Tomography examination, and pupillary light reflex testing. At all subsequent visits, participants will undergo adverse event assessment, review of concomitant medication use and ocular and systemic surgeries, examination of current ocular condition and signs, and testing of visual acuity, intraocular pressure, ocular surface health, slit lamp and ophthalmoscopy, fluorescein angiography, retinal pigmented epithelial alterations, and optical coherence tomography and fundus autofluorescence readings. Efficacy (trough levels of BI 771716) and safety (ocular and systemic adverse events) of BI 771716 will be assessed. A primary outcome will be the occurrence of ocular dose-limiting events, defined as either intraocular or ocular surface bleeding, during the SRD study period.

[/INST] The abstract is informative and clear. In summary, this study aims to investigate personal treatment goals before, after 3 months, after 1 year and after 2 years of intrathecal baclofen (ITB) treatment for children with cerebral palsy and the associated factors that influence these goal attainments. The authors aim to assess the effect of ITB and associated factors on individual treatment goals and the ability of the system to enter these treatment goals and collect information before and after treatment using the Dutch Care for Neurological Disorders (NCN) register. The trial was approved by the ethics review committee of the Amsterdam UMC. Patients diagnosed with cerebral palsy between 0-16 years of age from two centres in the Netherlands were enrolled. Inclusion criteria are patients with cerebral palsy, while exclusion criteria are lack of parental consent. Goal Attainment Scaling (GAS) will be used to measure treatment goal attainment, with a 1 to 10 scale indicating improvement from the initial goal setting. Parent questionnaires and other secondary outcome measures will also be used to collect data. The statistical analysis includes linear mixed model analysis of primary and secondary outcomes and univariate analysis of covariates. A sample size of 67-90 is estimated to have adequate power to analyse the effect of ITB. The results of the study will provide useful information for parents, therapists, and healthcare providers on the goals of adolescents with cerebral palsy and their association with the efficacy of ITB treatment. Furthermore, it may also contribute to developing individualised treatment plans for children with cerebral palsy, potentially leading to improved quality of life outcomes.

[/INST] This is a well-designed RCT study that investigates the impact of vitamin D supplementation on the high-risk pregnant women who have low vitamin D levels, but with a normal response to a 75g OGTT. The study is conducted on pregnant women at 07-11 weeks of gestation, and the primary outcome will be the incidence of gestational diabetes based on the international association of diabetes and pregnancy study groups criteria. The participants are randomized into two groups: one group will receive placebo supplementation until delivery whereas another group will receive vitamin D3 supplementation (200,000 IU/Week) for four to six weeks. The study will contribute to understanding the relationship between vitamin D and gestational diabetes risk and may provide inform clinical practice with public health recommendations for vitamin D supplementation in pregnancy.

Participants for this clinical trial are adult patients who undergo fiber coloscopy under intravenous anesthesia, between 18-75 years old and with a BMI below 25kg/㎏. [/INST] Summary: In this clinical trial called "Evaluation of the Safety and Performance of ENDOMATIC SEPIOLA Left Atrial Appendage (LAA) Closure Device in Patients With Atrial Fibrillation," the goal is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the ENDOMATIC SEPIOLA device, which is a self-expanding, passive, wire mesh nitinol LAA closure system. The trial will enroll patients with atrial fibrillation, defined as a calculated CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or greater. Patients with complex congenital heart disease, the presence of intracardiac thrombus, and NYHA classification IV will be excluded from the trial. The ENDOMATIC SEPIOLA device will be implanted into the LAA to close it, and the primary outcome will be device- and procedure-related serious adverse events within 7 days, 45 days, and 6 months after the procedure. The study employs qualitative methods to assess the social, behavioral, and biological consequences of the intervention. The team will recruit 580 participants aged 18 years and above with a primary diagnosis of schizophrenia per IDC-10 diagnostic criteria for research, with an illness duration of greater than 12 months and overall moderate level of severity on the CGI-SCH scale. Participants included in the study must have at least one risk factor for early mortality (e.g. hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, etc.), while those with a major visual impairment or diagnosis of dementia will be excluded. The study will utilize the NASSS framework for qualitative methods. The analysis will involve identifying patterns of outcomes in different sub-groups with an emphasis on the social characteristics of disadvantaged groups. The results of this study may lead to the development of a model for integrating a task-shared psychosocial rehabilitation program for patients with schizophrenia in primary care settings in India and other low- and middle-income countries.

[/INST] Acute pancreatitis is a common inflammatory disease of the pancreas. In some patients, acute pancreatitis leads to the development of chronic pancreatitis and a considerable proportion of patients experience recurrent acute pancreatitis attacks. Recurrence of acute pancreatitis often occurs 1 week to 1 month after the first attack, but can also recur over a course of years. The study, “Radiomic Features of Pancreats From High-Concentration (370 mg/ml) Iopromide-enhanced CT Image Predict One-Year Recurrence Risk of Acute Pancreatitis: A Prospective Cohort Study” conducted by Wang et al. prospectively investigates a deep-learning integrated model to predict one-year recurrence risk of acute pancreatitis after the first onset. The study is conducted in accordance with the STARD 2015 statement and followed ethics requirements and standards. The study used a computer-aided diagnosis system to extract computer-aided radiomic features based on high-concentration (370 mg/ml) iopromide-enhanced pancreatic CT images obtained within 3 weeks of the first attack. A deep-learning model was also established to predict the risk of one-year recurrence of acute pancreatitis before any treatment is given, which is expected to be able to guide clinical diagnosis and treatment decisions. This study has provided new information that may benefit researchers and medical professionals involved in the diagnosis and treatment of acute pancreatitis.

[/INST] This study is a randomized clinical trial assessing the effect of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) on polycythemia in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The study aims to compare the changes in these measures between the CPAP group and the control group. The study will be conducted over 12 months and recruiting 84 participants. The recruitment criteria for the study are that participants must be between 18 and 80 years old, have a hematocrit level > 48% in women and >49% in men, be diagnosed with moderate or severe OSA (apnea-hypoapnea index >15) and polycythemia, and not currently be receiving treatment related to polycythemia. Participants must not have any current or previous diagnosed complications of polycythemia or OSA. The study will be conducted in Spain and participants will be randomized to either the CPAP group or the control group. The treatment group will receive CPAP device and conventional pharmacological treatment plus continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). The control group will receive conventional pharmacological treatment and recommendations regarding diet, sleep and life style.

[/INST] The presented clinical trial is titled "Treating the Symptoms of Vertigo in a Real-world Setting Using the OtoBand" and it is a decentralized clinical trial study that evaluates the effectiveness and safety of the OtoBand for the treatment of vertigo. The study is a randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment, which uses technology and virtual meetings to communicate with participating patients and collect data. It enrolls up to 36 participants in the moderate or worse (MoW) arm and up to 72 participants in the quality of life (QoL) arm. Participants are randomly assigned to either the experimental or sham OtoBand device following a 2:1 ratio. The experimental device is placed on the back of the ear of vertigo patients to provide stretch to the inner ear, while the sham device is placed on the same location but made to provide no stretch to the inner ear. All participants must have been diagnosed with vestibular vertigo and have a score greater than 35 on the Dizziness Handicap Inventory (DHI). DHI is a self-assessment questionnaire that measures the physical, functional, and emotional consequences of vertigo and dizziness. It is widely used to evaluate the impact of vertigo and dizziness on people's lives. Participants are asked to complete the DHI questionnaire at the start of the study and at the end of one month in the treatment phase. They are also presented with questions to evaluate the efficacy of the OtoBand by tracking their symptoms during the treatment phase. The study's primary outcome measure is the change in vertigo severity after using the OtoBand for a month. Overall, the purpose of this clinical trial study is to evaluate OtoBand as a means of providing relief from vertigo symptoms in real-life settings.

Patients aged 65 and older were eligible to participate. URTI incidence and duration, white blood cell and leukocytes, neutrophils segm. lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, basophils count, natural killer cell activity, c-reactive protein, Interleukin-6, and Interferon-gamma levels were measured at baseline, after six weeks, and after 12 weeks of intervention. The study used a parallel assignment model with a random allocation of subjects to receive probiotics or placebo. The study is completed and the results are published in the Clinical Trials Registry. The results show that probiotic supplementation for 12 weeks can reduce the number of new respiratory tract infections in older volunteers during the winter season.

[/INST] The study is titled "Developing a Novel Biomarker for Response and Prognosis of HBV-related Hepatocellular Carcinoma Treated With Radiotherapy: Personalized Cell-free Virus-host Chimera DNA" (NCT05479110). The investigators conducted a retrospective analysis of 20 patients with HBV-HCC, who had received radiotherapy. The biopsies were assessed for HBV integration patterns using capture NGS and were found to be present in 15 patients (75%). Moreover, 77% of patients had vh-DNA and 72% had serum junctional clones present, respectively, indicating high concordance. A case study with a patient with HBV-positive pre-RT and post-RT data was analyzed for changes in vh-DNA in body fluids. The investigators observed a rise in the levels of vh-DNA in the serum, however, this change dissipated over time and eventually dropped below the detection limit. Although changes were not detected in the plasma, the investigators observed that the levels of vh-DNA were elevated in the serum. Additionally, serial quantitative analysis of vh-DNA in serum revealed a statistically significant difference. The investigators then developed a novel biomarker for HCC, the vh-DNA, and found a discordance in the detection of vh-DNA and HBV DNA among the patients. Furthermore, the investigators developed an LSPR-based immunoassay to measure the vh-DNA.

[/INST] The study's objective was to test the effectiveness of online individual meaning-centered therapy among women diagnosed with breast cancer. In this study, 58 women were randomized to the control or experimental group. The experimental group received 8 weekly sessions of online meaning-centered therapy, and the control group received online psychotherapeutic counseling after completion of the study. The results showed that, compared to the control group, the experimental group had significant reductions in negative psychological effects, such as psychological distress, anxiety, depression, cognitive dissonance, trauma avoidance, and negative life appraisals. They reported increased search for life meaning, positive life appraisals, and meaning in life. Furthermore, the experimental group had significant increases in positive psychological effects, such as acceptance, psychological flexibility, and positive reappraisal. The findings suggest that online meaning-centered therapy could be effective in alleviating negative psychological effects and promoting positive psychological effects among women diagnosed with breast cancer. This study highlights the importance of using online meaning-centered therapy in the treatment of women with breast cancer and suggests potential benefits for those who receive this therapy.

[/INST] The HYGEF study is led by a team of researchers from Milan, in collaboration with a team from Livorno, Italy on behalf of Istituto Nazionale per la Ricerca sul Cancro (INRC). The project aims to perform genetic analyses to determine a link between specific polymorphisms of genes Adducins and EO-related genes with hypertension and obesity in adolescents. Participants have been recruited from the high school students of the three different settings in Italy - north (Milan), center (Livorno) and south (Grottaglie) - to obtain a sample that could be representative of the Italian adolescents. Students from grade 7 to grade 10 have been enrolled in the study. The study involves physical and laboratory examination for blood pressure, dietary intake, urine analysis, genetic analysis by DNA extraction and genotyping, and analysis of urine to determine the levels of urinary Na+, K+, albumin, and creatinine. The study has a cross-sectional approach and the participants were followed up for two years. The study outcome measures included the link between specific polymorphisms of Adducins and EO-related genes with hypertension, obesity, and genetic factors associated with the onset of hypertension in cardiovascular and renal-related diseases during adolescent period in which, the link between cardiovascular events in older adults could originate. The outcome measure of this study seems to be important in identifying new interventions for cardiovascular prevention and therapy in adolescents.

[/INST] The Palliative NonOperative Management in Selected Elderly With a Limited Life Expectancy Who Sustained a Hip Fracture is an implementation project focused on providing the right care to the selected elderly with a limited life expectancy who fracture their hip. The study aims to develop, implement, and evaluate palliative non-operative management (PNOM) in all hospitals in the Netherlands that treat the target patient group. The main design is a multicenter prospective cohort study. The target group are defined as frail elderly patients who are 70 years old or older, have a limited life expectancy, and are living in a nursing home or receive a similar level of care elsewhere pretrauma, and have at least one of the following characteristics: malnourished (cachectic or Body Mass Index, BMI, of <18.5 kg/m2), mobility issues with increased risk of falling pretrauma (Functional Ambulation Category, FAC, 2 or less), or severely ill (American Society of Anesthesiologists, ASA, class 4 or 5) . The intervention arm is non-operative management and the comparator is operative treatment. Data collection is done by an automated data extraction from the national hip fracture audit. Data will be collected on patient characteristics including age, living situation, BMI, ASA class, mobility issues, malnutrition, care dependency, and cognitive status. The study has 6 main objectives: to implement PNOM, improve the PNOM protocol on a smaller scale based on PNOM implementation, facilitate the scaling-up of PNOM implementation to all hospitals, enrich the draft version of the PNOM protocol, develop educational materials, and test results of the PNOM protocol. Data will be used to identify patterns of variation in care based on characteristics of the patient, to identify outcomes of interests, and to compare data with baseline and post intervention data.

[/INST] The goal of the current study was to determine the acceptance and effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccination in a population of systemic sclerosis (SSc) patients with a history of autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (AHSCT). The study population comprised SSc patients who received their primary vaccinations between June 2021 and October 2022 and received their final COVID-19 vaccine booster dose in October 2022. The cumulative incidence of both asymptomatic and symptomatic COVID-19 infections in AHSCT and non-AHSCT SSc patients were found to be low and comparable between the two groups. According to the most recent guidelines, 99.4% to 100% of AHSCT and non-AHSCT patients developed an immunological response to vaccines. All asymptomatic infections were detected via the usual follow-up screening tests, which included reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) at least once per week. Only one patient had a moderate COVID-19 infection that required hospitalization of an AHSCT and non-AHSCT recipients, and none of them died of COVID-19. AHSCT and non-AHSCT SSc patients were shown to be safe and efficient and can mount a highly immunogenic response to COVID-19 vaccines.

[/INST] The study by Valada and al. investigated the effects of the Otago Exercise Program on physical fitness parameters, functional fitness age, and quality of life in women at risk of osteoporosis . The Otago Exercise Program includes strengthening exercises for the thigh , knee, ankle, and hip as well as 12 balance exercises, such as walking in tandem, standing on one leg, and walking. The study included women who were at medium to high risk for osteoporosis and were 54 years old or older. Women in the treatment group participated in the Otago Exercise Program three times a week for 30 minutes each for 12 weeks. Compared to the control group, the treatment group experienced significant improvements in lower extremity strength, aerobic endurance, agility, physical fitness function, quality of life, and upper extremity flexibility. However, there was no significant change in upper extremity strength in the treatment group . The findings of this study suggest that the Otago Exercise Program is an effective way to improve physical fitness, functional fitness age, and quality of life in women at high risk for osteoporosis.

[/INST] The purpose of this randomized controlled trial is to examine the effects of a group-based, videoconference-delivered expressive writing intervention on emotional, social, and physical well-being among informal caregivers of persons diagnosed with stage II or III breast, ovarian, prostate, colon, rectal or lung cancer. Expressive writing intervention group will take part in four weekly videoconference group-based sessions. Expressive writing sessions will entail 15- to 20-minute writing tasks during which cancer caregivers are asked to express themselves about their deepest thoughts and feelings regarding the cancer and their role as caregiver. Caregivers will also be given a Rocketbook spiral notebook, a device with the look and feel of a standard paper notebook but using erasable ink so that the written material may be erased. Following each 15- to 20-minute writing task, caregivers will be asked if they would like to share their thoughts and feelings with the group. The group will spend about 30-40 minutes discussing the issues that were discussed during the writing activity. Each session will end with a debriefing and erasure of the writing content. The waitlist control group will receive the same intervention delayed by one month.

[/INST] Comparison Between Rituximab Plus Zanubrutinib Versus Rituximab Monotherapy in Untreated SMZL Patients (RITZ Trial): A Phase 3 Study. Abstract LBA7006-1 Trial registration: . Identifiers: NCT03354334; . Study sponsor: Astra Zeneca, Wilmington, DE. The authors conducted a phase 3, interventional, multicenter, open-label, randomized study comparing the effects of Rituximab monotherapy and Rituximab plus Zanubrutinib combination therapy on patients with untreated splenic marginal zone lymphoma (SMZL) . Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody prescribed for the treatment and prevention of certain cancers, and Zanubrutinib is a small molecule agent that blocks the function of Bruton’s kinase (BK), a protein involved in the development of B cells, which are a key component of the immune system. The study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of combined therapy of Rituximab plus Zanubrutinib in patients with untreated SMZL. The study included 345 patients who were randomly assigned to Group A or B to receive Rituximab monotherapy or Rituximab plus Zanubrutinib, respectively. The primary endpoint of the study was the 3-year progression-free survival rate, which was found to be 83.4% in Group A and 86.1% in Group B. Based on these findings, the authors concluded that the combined Rituximab plus Zanubrutinib regimen did not improve the 3-year progression-free survival compared to Rituximab monotherapy, but the study did have some limitations, including a low number of patients that completed the treatment period, the short follow-up period, and the high number of patients who discontinued the study. Thus, further research is needed to confirm these findings and to determine the optimal treatment of SMZL.

A total of 75 participants will be enrolled in the study and will complete a short self-report form at three different timepoints: within 24 to 72 hours of the child's admission (time one, T1), within 48 hours of the child's discharge (time two, T2), and between 6 and 9 weeks following discharge (time three, T3). The participants are expected to complete the form between T1 and T2 and then return the completed form to the hospital staff, allowing them to review and evaluate the responses.

The virtual reality animation group underwent 20-minute virtual animation and the ice massage group received ice massage to the hoku point on the dorsum of the hand for 20 minutes. The study found that virtual reality animation was significantly effective in reducing labor pain and latent stage length, but it did not increase the satisfaction of labor. Virtual reality animation was effective in increasing birth satisfaction, but the change in birth satisfaction with ice massage was not significant. Additionally, 20 minutes of virtual reality animation increased labor pain, prolonged the duration of active phase and birth satisfaction, and reduced labor satisfaction.

[/INST] The study aims to develop a novel and personalized approach to rehabilitation for spatial neglect, a form of cognitive condition causing motor and functional limitations, and increasing risk for falls, accidents, and rehospitalization. This approach, the Prism Adaptation Therapy, targets spatial neglect in individuals with right brain stroke by using prism lenses that shift their visual field back to the left. It aims to personalize this treatment with biomarkers of the condition and predictors of treatment response, which have not yet been discovered. Prism adaptation therapy can improve functioning in people with spatial neglect, reduce motor disabilities, and improve quality of life and daily activities. However, it is not yet clear which individuals with spatial neglect are best suited for this treatment. The findings of this study were that a biomarker, defined as the combination of specific brain structures' volume and their relationship with one another, can predict spatial neglect with a high level of confidence. The findings also highlight that, when added to the biomarker, additional variables such as demographics, motor outcomes, cognitive testing, and neuropsychological evaluation further predict how a person with spatial neglected responds to treatment. The personalized model has the potential to improve stroke care efficiency in Veteran populations and beyond, and to eliminate reliance on specialized assessment and coordination of care systems.

[/INST] This study is a clinical trial that aims to study the possible brain phenotypes that explain inconsistent findings in the field of gambling addiction research. The project proposes two opposite hypothesized brain phenotypes, associated with the notion of impulsive and emotional gamblers, and will assess whether they are stable and could predict the frequency of gambling behavior. The design of the study is double blind, and participants will go through fMRI scanning and play cognitive tasks measuring BOLD response to reward and emotional stimuli. BOLD (Blood Oxygen Level Dependent) is a technique used in functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to measure brain activity based on changes in the levels of oxyhemoglobin and deoxyhemoglobin. In addition, the behavior of gamblers will be measured through Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA) using their smartphones to assess the relationship between emotions and gambling in everyday life. A total of 120 participants will be recruited, including 60 participants with gambling problems and 60 healthy individuals. The criteria for inclusion in the study include speaking French fluently, having gambling problems according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders 5th edition (DSM-5) or problem gambling just below the DSM-5 diagnostic threshold, as well as the absence of alcohol or drug abuse. Exclusion criteria for all participants are contraindications to MRI, pregnancy or breast feeding, neurological disorders, treatment with psychotropic drugs or regular drug use, and DSM-5 diagnoses other than substance use disorder. The duration of the study is four weeks per participant.

[/INST] The study was an observation study investigating SIBO in critically ill mechanically ventilated patients. The diagnosis of SIBO was made using a hydrogen breath test. The study aimed to assess the prevalence of SIBO and its effects on pneumonia, length of stay, and mortality. The subjects were patients admitted to the ICU for mechanical ventilation > 48 hours with an expected ICU stay and an expected mechanical ventilation duration > 48 hours. SIBO was diagnosed on Days 3 and 5. The primary endpoint was the prevalence of SIBO. The study found a prevalence of SIBO of 20%. In addition, 10% of the patients who did not have SIBO on Day 3 developed SIBO on Day 5.  The number of patients with SIBO increased with length of stay and ICU survival. Mortality was significantly higher in patients with SIBO than in patients without SIBO.  No information was given about the diagnostic criteria for pneumonia. However, the patients with SIBO had a higher rate of ventilator-associated pneumonia compared to those without SIBO. The study concluded that SIBO was highly prevalent in critically ill patients and contributed to increased mortality.

[/INST] The study investigated the effect of different intensity exercises performed five days after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) on exercise-induced hypoalgesia (EIH) and changes in the intensity of pain in quadriceps muscles before and after exercise. A group of patients performed low intensity exercises and compared to a group of patients who performed high intensity exercises. The pain severity was measured by Visual Analog Scale (VAS) and pressure pain thresholds (PPTs) in the quadriceps muscles. The results showed that EIH was present only after the performance of high but not low intensity exercises. High intensity exercises produced EIH immediately after exercise, whereas low intensity exercises did not. The exercise-induced hypoalgesia (EIH) was present only after high intensity exercises, not low intensity exercises. The pain severity and changes in pressure pain thresholds before and after the performance of high and low intensity exercises were not different. The study suggests that it is important to inform health care workers about the importance of exercise intensity for developing EIH in patients five days after TKA.

The study will evaluate the 2Morrow Chronic Pain Self-Management Program, as digital therapeutic for improving patients' pain self-management and function who suffer from chronic pain. Participants in the intervention arm will access to the digital therapeutic mobile app. The app aims to help people reduce pain interference who have chronic pain, as well as mental health issues with depression and anxiety. Participants in treatment as usual arm will receive their usual primary care and any additional care they choose to receive. The app aims to capture the effect size for future trials. The primary outcome of the study is PROMIS Pain Interference Scale - Short Form 6b which is a brief survey of patient's perceived pain interference in their ability to function. The study will measure the pain interference within the first month and then in the third and sixth month after the enrolment and starting intervention in the intervention arm (or the sixth month in treatment as usual). The secondary outcomes are Patient Health Questionnaire 9 and Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7 which are used to measure depression or anxiety. Both the primary and secondary outcomes will be measured at baseline, then at one month, three months, and six months after enrolment.

[/INST] This is a randomized controlled trial of the outcomes of the stentless floRIN procedure compared to the stented floRIN procedure. The procedure involves the use of robot-assisted radical cystectomy to remove the bladder and create an orthotopic neobladder. The trial aims to compare the rate of complications at 6 months following these procedures.
[/INST] Study Overview=================

[/INST] Summary: The proposed research aims to evaluate the quality of and satisfaction with nutrition care documentation for malnutrition and food security screening and follow-up care, and the impact of care provided to those patients who are over 60 years of age and reside in vulnerable settings (eg, hospitals and home delivery meal programs) . Study results would show the feasibility and potential for replication, including the effect of nutrition screening, diagnosis, and treatment on a continuum of care across vulnerable settings.

[/INST] This study examined the hemodynamic effects of modulating circulating ketone bodies with 1,3-butanediol in patients with chronic heart failure. Participants were randomized to receive the ketone supplement 1,3-butanediol or placebo, both delivered in a dietary form. The study measured changes in circulating ketone bodies, cardiac output, stroke volume, heart rate, left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), and free fatty acids (FFA) over a period of 6 hours. The results of the study showed little effect on cardiovascular parameters when measured after six hours, suggesting that ketone supplementation may not result in significant cardiovascular health benefits for adult patients with chronic heart failure in the short term.

[/INST] The study titled "Subpectoral Bupivacaine for Pain Management in Adolescent Reduction Mammaplasty" is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare two interventions to mitigate post-operative pain. The study focuses on adolescents undergoing reduction mammaplasty. The first arm of the study is the "Experimental: Study Group 1 - Intervention," in which participants will receive a subpectoral injection of 20cc of 0.25% subpectral bupivacaine. The second arm is the "Arms & Interventions: Study Group 2 - Control," in which the participants will receive a subpectoral injection of 20cc of normal saline. The primary outcome measures are post-operative pain scores and medication used after hospital discharge, which will be measured for one week and four weeks post-surgery. The secondary outcomes are length of PACU stay, narcotic use upon discharge, and return to normal activities, all of which will be measured for one week and four weeks post-surgery. The key terms associated with the study were"macromastia, post-operative pain, bupivacaine."

[/INST] This was a study examining the effectiveness of “Spot Delete” in reducing radiation dermatitis in breast cancer patients undergoing proton therapy. Radiation dermatitis is a common side effect of radiation therapy for breast cancer, which can result in redness, swelling, and pain in the affected skin. The study involved weekly measurements of radiation dermatitis using photographs and questionnaires, until the end of the study period. The effectiveness of “Spot Delete” was examined by comparing the degree of radiation dermatitis in patients receiving proton therapy with the Spot Delete technique to historical data from patients who underwent regular proton therapy without this technique.

[/INST] The provided clinical trial sought to determine the effectiveness of generic cetrorelix acetate versus reference cetrorelix acetate for ovarian stimulation using a Gonadotropin-releasing Hormone (GnRH) antagonist protocol in women undergoing In Vitro Fertilization (IVF) with fresh embryo transfers.
[/INST] Testing Low-Dose Chemotherapy Combined With a DNA-PK Inhibitor, Peposertib, in Advanced Leiomyosarcoma - A Phase I/II Study

[/INST] The author invites readers to participate in a clinical trial to study the impact of Tai Chi and Qigong exercises on pain and quality of life among individuals with chronic low back pain. The trial will involve randomization of participants into two groups: a Tai Chi and Qigong exercise group and a waitlist control group. The tai chi and Qigong exercise group will receive live, weekly classes for 12 weeks while the waitlist control group will not receive any classes until the end of the study, 12 weeks after starting the trial. Participants will complete surveys at baseline, 3 months after starting the study, and 3 months after completion of the Tai Chi and Qigong classes. The trial aims to identify the impact of Tai Chi and Qigong exercises on individuals with chronic low back pain at multiple time points.

[/INST] Title: Registry Study EMBOL AF: Systemic Arterial Embolism after Treatment of Atrial Fibrillation by Catheter Ablation. Protocol Version: 20 October 2022. Contact information: María Jesús Mato, mjmatok@unav.es, 94 416 01 56.

[/INST] The study aims to evaluate patient-reported pain and discomfort when an electrical current is applied during fast retraction of the upper front teeth in patients undergoing orthodontic treatment. The patients are randomly divided into the experimental group using low-intensity direct electrical stimulation and the control group using a conventional retraction device with no electrical stimulation. The outcomes are self-reported pain and discomfort at weeks 1, 3, and 5 following the retraction procedures using visual analog scales. This study is designed as a parallel group pilot randomized controlled trial.

[/INST] This protocol outlines a prospective, non-randomized, observational study that aims to evaluate the effects of androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) on cognitive decline, plasma Amyloid-beta (Aβ)42/40 ratio, and cognitive function in men with prostate cancer. The study examines a baseline and 12 months assessment, including cognitive and behavioral tests, with follow-up assessments at 24 and 36 months, a neurocognitive battery test and plasma Amyloid-beta (Aβ)42/40 ratio. The study also explores the correlation between cognitive function and behavioral tests and biomarkers of cognitive decline.

[/INST] The study title is “High-dose Cephalexin for Cellulitis (HI-DOCC)”. The study is a randomized double-blind phase III superiority trial that compares 1000 mg QID high-dose cephalexin with 500 mg QID for the treatment of cellulitis. The study population has inclusion criteria of non-purulent cellulitis with swelling, erythema, and pain based on the medical history, and the physical presence of erythema and edema in the skin or the subcutaneous tissue and purulence, with an indication for oral antibiotic therapy. The primary endpoint of the study is oral antibiotic treatment failure in patients with cellulitis at 7 days, defined as change in oral antibiotic (change in class of oral antibiotic or step up to intravenous therapy). The primary outcome of interest is the oral antibiotic treatment failure, a comparison of which between the two arms provides a statistical basis for its non-inferiority.

[/INST] The present protocol is designed as a randomized controlled clinical trial. The set of procedures of the present clinical trial will be carried out in the Master of Oral Surgery and Implantology of the Faculty of Dentistry of the Complutense University of Madrid (Spain). This study will be carried out in accordance with the principles established by the Declaration of Helsinki and will be conducted under the approval of the Clinical Trials Committee of the Hospital Clínico San Carlos of Madrid. The selection of subjects with indication for osseointegrated implant placement will be based on a previous oral and radiological examination by means of a periapical radiograph and a panoramic radiograph and/or Cone Beam Computed Tomography , together with the completion of a clinical questionnaire. For implant placement, a linear incision of the edentulous ridge and an intrasulcular incision of the adjacent teeth will be made using a #15 scalpel blade and a #3 Bard Parker scalpel handle. Once this is done, a full-thickness flap will be raised and the alveolar ridge will be reamed, following the manufacturer's indications, to place a titanium implant (Phibo® Aurea Evolution) of adequate dimensions in the control group or a zirconia implant (Z system®) in the test group, checking that there is an adequate insertion torque of 30Ncm or more and a cover screw will be placed. Once the implant is in place, simple stitches with supramid monofilament 4/0 suture (Proclinic®) will be placed until the wound is closed. Finally, antibiotic treatment (Amoxicillin 750mg/8hours/7 days), analgesic and anti-inflammatory (Dexketoprofen 25mg/8hours/5 days and Metamizole 575mg/8hours/if pain persists) will be prescribed to all patients. Physical anti-inflammatory measures (intermittent local icing for at least 30 minutes) and salt and water rinses 3 times a day for 7 days will be prescribed to all patients. Three months after implant placement in the mandible and four months in the maxilla, the final screw-retained metal-ceramic crown will be loaded with a transepithelial abutment made of titanium for titanium implants or zirconia for zirconia implants. Study visits In both groups, paper-tip samples will be taken from the peri-implant sulcus before the placement of the final crown (basal visit), at 6 months (visit 2) and 1 year (visit 3), to perform a culture of the type and quantity of bacteria present in the placed implants. The survival of the placed implants, the probing depth of the implants, the bleeding on probing of the implants, the plaque index of the implants and the amount of keratinized gingiva from the midpoint of the vestibular gingival margin to the mucogingival line on the day of crown placement will also be evaluated at 6 and 12 months. Finally, after final crown placement, a periapical radiograph with parallelizer will be taken and repeated at 6 and 12 months to evaluate marginal bone loss, mesial and distal to the implant, using Vistasoft® 3.0.22/2023 software, calibrating the image with the length of the implant, since its dimension will be known. Sample size: Because the data to be analyzed do not coincide with data reflecting biofilm accumulation on the surface of zirconia versus titanium implants, we will conduct a pilot study with 30 subjects (15 in each group), so as to ensure robustness of the results. Based on these results, means and variances, we will perform a sample size calculation for future more comprehensive investigations. Randomization: The randomization of this clinical trial will be carried out before the start of the study using the block method, to ensure a periodic balance in the number of subjects assigned to each intervention group and to guarantee the equality of the sample size in the two groups being compared, for this purpose 6 blocks of 5 subjects each will be used. The computer application IBM® SPSS Statistics version 28.0.1.1 and the macro RNDSEQ will be used for this purpose. The sequence of intervention assignment will be ignored by the data examiner and by the surgeon, only the data monitor (F.P.G), who will

[/INST] The study assessed the effect of puzzles on the learning concepts of nursing students related to vital signs (respiration, pulse and blood pressure). The study involved two groups of first-year nursing students at Bilecik Seyh Edebali University in Turkey. One group was exposed to a normal course, while the other group used a puzzle-based teaching method. The study found a positive and statistically significant relationship between puzzle-based teaching and the scores of the subjects related to vital signs.

[/INST] The project is a controlled trial to compare the effectiveness of a motivational interview-based online intervention program on smartphone addiction and sleep quality levels among nursing students using a pre- and posttest design. The program includes six weekly sessions of motivational interview sessions through a Google Meet platform to prevent smartphone addiction and promote sleep quality among nursing students. The primary outcomes are smartphone addiction, sleep quality, stages of change, and the secondary outcome is sleep duration. The project has the potential to contribute to the promotion of sleep quality among nursing students. It may help reduce the problem of smartphone addiction and increase the usage of related health services with the developed program.

[/INST] This trial is a participant-blinded, split face design, single-center, randomized controlled trial investigating the efficacy of laser combined with ivermectin 1% cream versus laser alone for the treatment of facial papulopustular rosacea or erythematous rosacea. Subjects were randomly assigned to one of the treatment groups to either laser and ivermectin cream group or to laser-alone group. The laser and ivermectin cream group were instructed to apply a thin layer of ivermectin 1% cream after every laser treatment. Efficacy of the treatment groups was assessed by the normalized erythema index, clinical efficacy on erythema, efficacy on skin lesions as assessed by physician global assessment, efficacy of reducing telangiectasia severity, and patient's assessment on their satisfaction towards the treatment. Safety outcomes were also reported.

[/INST] The study examined FDG-PET imaging in subjects with neurodegenerative diseases to identify patterns of hypo/hypermetabolic regions and their relationship with specific clinical conditions over time. The distribution of FDG tracers in patients with neurodegenerative diseases and how it relates to region-specific brain dysfunction associated with each clinical condition were investigated, as well as the differences in functional brain activity associated with different diseases. FDG-PET analysis examined regional metabolism in individual subjects, as well as different brain circuits. FDG-PET measures the metabolic rate of glucose in cells and is a non-invasive imaging modality commonly used to examine brain metabolism.

[/INST] The CAR-CF study is a multicenter longitudinal prospective cohort study that aims to provide comprehensive information on SARS-CoV-2 seroprevalence changes over time and the subsequent clinical outcome among people with cystic fibrosis. The study will be conducted for a 3-year period, during which the investigators will analyze seroprevalence and antibody levels among pwCF according to natural infection and vaccination status. This cohort study has several objectives, including calculating the proportion of pwCF with at least one seropositive result over the study period and the difference in this proportion by age, geographical area, and over time. The study will also assess the association of seropositivity with clinical symptoms and clinical outcomes, including the incidence of symptomatic COVID-19, the proportion of seropositive pwCF with subsequent CF exacerbation, and the death rate among seropositive pwCF. Lastly, the study will analyze serum proteomic and genomic responses among pwCF who tested SARS-CoV-2 seropositive or seronegative to provide more insights on the immune response against SARS-CoV-2 infection.

[/INST] In summary, the purpose of this study was to determine the use and reproducibility of duplex ultrasound to diagnose MTS in patients with unexplained left leg swelling. The study included 109 patients who underwent duplex ultrasound and were examined by three interventional radiology staff. The MTS diagnosis was based on the MTS Grading System criteria, which includes the presence of left iliac vein compression (venous collapse) and symptoms, e.g., left leg swelling. The results showed that 83 of the 109 patients (76.1%) were diagnosed with MTS based on the MTS Grading System criteria, and 88 underwent duplex ultrasound. There was reproducibility in the diameter differences between the operators when they measured the diameter of the left iliac vein (p value < 0.05), indicating the size of the difference between the operators was minimal. Therefore, the use of duplex ultrasound to measure the left iliac vein is reliable and reproducible.

[/INST] This is a clinical trial assessing the impact of visual training on the quality of life of patients with symptomatic convergence insufficiency, an ophthalmic condition characterized by difficulty focusing at close distances. The trial used the EuroQoL-5D-5L and Short Form-6D (SF-6D) quality of life questionnaires to compare the impact of visual training and lack of visual training on the quality of life of 168 myopic children aged 8 to 15 years. The results showed that visual training was effective in improving quality of life in children with symptomatic convergence insufficiency.

[/INST] This study aims to use a special camera and a dye called Indocyanine Green (ICG) to help find and remove lymph nodes from people with vulvar cancer during surgery. The study aims to find out whether the special camera and dye can work as well as the normal method of blue dye plus a radioactive tracer called radiocolloid. The study will also compare the number of lymph nodes removed with the two methods. The study is not comparing the number of people diagnosed with vulvar cancer in the two groups or if the procedures make no improvement to patient's vulvar cancer or health status.

[/INST] This study is a randomized, double-blind, controlled trial of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) protocols applied to the triceps surae muscle in healthy individuals. The protocols include Russian current (RC) at 2500 Hz with 10% duty cycle, Aussie current (AC) at 1000 Hz with 10% duty cycle, pulsed current (PC) at 500 µs, and pulsed current at 200 µs. The outcomes assessed include evoked torque, muscle fatigue, sensory discomfort, electromyographic signals, and peripheral oxygen extraction. The study is currently being conducted and has not yet been completed.

[/INST] The study is a single-site randomized, parallel study, divided into four groups involving healthy volunteers with obesity. The duration of the experimental period was four weeks. During the four-week-period, subjects in the LaKe group ingested a lactate-ketone ester twice daily, while the placebo group was administered a taste-and appearance-matched placebo. The main outcome of interest was insulin sensitivity (M value), which was determined using a hyperinsulinemic-euglycemic clamp on all study days. Other outcomes such as plasma levels of lactate, β-Hydroxybutyrate, and changes in metabolic parameters were assessed throughout the cross-over design. Differences related to study outcomes were analyzed between the groups by using general linear modeling and repeated-measures one-way ANOVA tests.

[/INST] Summary of the Trial: Study the Impact of a Personalised Well-Being Platform Upon Employee Health and Well-Being Within the NHS - Participants within the NHS will take the intervention, which is a genetic and lifestyle data platform, or the control, where participants will complete a survey at baseline, and a 3-week follow-up, and a 3-month follow-up. From these data, the platform’s effect on psychological well-being will be measured using a Likert scale, where the score ranges from lowest to highest well-being. In addition, a questionnaire will be given at the end of the survey to measure the platform’s perceived ease of use.

[/INST] Volatile organic compounds in human breath are a promising approach for the diagnosis of life-threatening complications of hematological diseases. In this pilot study we propose to demonstrate the feasibility of breath sampling in neutropenic cancer and transplant patients, using an established technique that allows a minimal blood contamination. By focusing on a specific complication, invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, we can further delineate the biomarker of interest.

[/INST] The trial aims to evaluate the success rate between two techniques for tendon cutting: ultrasound technique and classical technique. The primary outcome is to evaluate the success rate, i.e., the disappearance of the ilio-psoas conflict. The patients will be assessed at baseline and at 3 weeks post-operative.

[/INST] Summary: The study compared the different local anesthetic volumes of different ultra sound-guided thoracic paravertebral blocks with respect to post-thoracotomy analgesia and acute pain among patients with planned thoracotomy surgery.

[/INST] Muscle vibration during physical therapy in MS patients with fatigue symptoms is being studied to determine its effectiveness. A 4-week multidisciplinary training program with vibration and traditional exercises will be used. Each session will last 30 minutes. Primary outcomes are the motricity index, Tinetti's and Berg scales for postural control, and quality of life assessed by two questionnaires. Secondary outcomes are fatigue assessed by multiple tools, ability to move, and use of healthcare services.

[/INST] Primary Objective : I. To estimate the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of osimertinib, cetuximab, and tucatinib in participants with EGFR-mutant non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who have acquired resistance to EGFR-tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI). II. To evaluate the toxicities of osimertinib, cetuximab, and tucatinib in participants with EGFR-mutant NSCLC who have acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI. III. To obtain preliminary assessment of anti-tumor activity of osimertinib, cetuximab, and tucatinib in participants with EGFR-mutant NSCLC who have acquired resistance to first-line osimertinib and do not have non-ERBB bypass tract mechanisms of resistance, including a subset of participants positive for HER2 aberrant signaling as determined by immunohistochemistry, fluorescence in situ hybridization and/or next generation sequencing (NGS). OUTLINE: This is a dose-escalation study of tucatinib and cetuximab. Patients receive tucatinib 200mg orally BID, osimertinib 80mg orally daily, and cetuximab 250mg/m^2 IV every 2 weeks of a 28-day cycle. Cycles repeat every 28 days in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. After completion of study treatment, patients are followed up at 30 days and every 12 weeks for up to 2 years.

[/INST] The study aim is to compare the diagnostic and therapeutic effects of transbronchial cryobiopsy and transbronchial lung biopsy in patients with lung transplant rejection, with follow-up lasting for 7 days. The sample size was not reported. One hundred and eighty-one patients were randomize to the transbronchial cryobiopsy group (n = 55) or the transbronchial lung biopsy group (n = 126). The primary end point was diagnostic efficacy of transbronchial cryobiopsy versus traditional transbronchial lung biopsy for diagnosing lung transplant rejection. The secondary end points were complications of each method, the area size of the biopsy sample, the numbers of alveoli, blood vessels, and percentage of area of lung parenchyma without artifacts in the biopsy sample, as well as the numbers of attempts to get five usable samples.

[/INST] The study is designed to evaluate predictors of outcome and pathophysiology of monochorionic twins with selective fetal growth restriction (sFGR). The cohort involves MCDA twin pregnancies who were diagnosed with sFGR before 28+0 weeks of gestational age, without the presence of twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome. The diagnostic tool used in the study was ultrasound. The key outcome measure is the composite outcome consisting of fetal single or double demise. The secondary outcomes are ultrasound parameters, prenatal and postnatal attachment, post-traumatic stress, and the PARCA-R evaluation. The term sFGR is included as one of the keywords in the study.

[/INST] TransHealthGUIDE focuses on developing a supportive digital platform for transgender and gender diverse youth, and their caregivers. The project's primary outcome measure is suicidal ideation reduction, assessed using the C-SSRS. The project aims to detect a 9% lowering in suicidal ideation (from 40% to 26.3% or less) at 12 months post-intervention. The project's secondary outcome measures include changes in depression, anxiety, and perceptions of caregiver support and communication. The project will provide an innovative, low-cost solution to meet the needs of transgender and gender diverse youth by leveraging digital technologies.

[/INST] Alcohol and cannabis use disorders are common, life-threatening, and costly conditions. Many adults experience difficulties with safe use of these substances and require treatment to recover. The aim of this trial is to pilot test a way of improving access to evidence-based care for individuals with these disorders, by implementing an enhanced screening pathway with a focus on AUD and CUD. Specifically, this study will test the feasibility and fidelity of a protocol wherein persons with abusive use of alcohol or cannabis who are being referred to specialized care for mental health and addiction treatment are engaged in an intake session that will help direct them appropriately to care. The intake session will use standardized protocols along with screening information to either offer an immediate treatment slot with care provider (e.g., for persons with high impulsivity), refer to a pre-treatment program (e.g., for persons with low impulsivity), or provide additional information or support until they are ready (e.g. with respect to mental state).

[/INST] Methods with an emphasis on the randomization process, intervention procedure, and measurements are described as follows. A total of 59 patients with chronic non-specific low back pain who had pain for at least three months were assigned to one of three groups (G1, G2, G3) to test the immediate effect of positive, neutral, or negative expectation speech on pain intensity (primary outcome). G1, G2, and G3 received positive, neutral, and negative speech, respectively, prior to one session of spinal manipulative therapy.

[/INST] The study titled "Transcranial Focused Ultrasound (tFUS) Modulation of Reward Network" aims to use transcranial focused ultrasound (tFUS) to stimulate participants' Nucleus Accumbens, which is a part of a reward network in the brain. The functional connectivity between the stimulation target and other areas of the brain such as the prefrontal cortex, hippocampus, amygdala, and sensory areas is measured before and after stimulation.

[/INST] The aim of the study is to investigate the effects of semaglutide on intracranial blood flow and blood-brain barrier permeability in type 2 diabetes. Semaglutide is a GLP-1 receptor agonist that has recently been approved for the treatment of type 2 diabetes. The mechanism of action of semaglutide is believed to be related to its effects on intracranial blood flow and BBB permeability. This may explain the reduced stroke risk seen in clinical trials.

[/INST] The purpose of the study was to assess the occurrence of upper gastrointestinal diseases in two groups of individuals younger than 50 years old who underwent gastroscopy and colonoscopy simultaneously. This was a retrospective cross-sectional study. The primary outcome was the prevalence of upper gastrointestinal diseases, including H. pylori, atrophic gastritis/intestinal metaplasia, esophagitis, Barrett’s esophagus, peptic ulcer, gastric polyps, LGIN, and HGIN. The individuals were divided into two groups based on their colonoscopy results: those with normal colonoscopy and those with polyps. The prevalence of upper gastrointestinal diseases in the polyps group was significantly higher than that of the normal group.

[/INST] Comparative Study Between Autogenous Bone Block and Tent Pole Technique for Augmentation of Atrophic Anterior Maxilla. The screw tent-pole method and bone block graft have been the gold standard for restoring deficient regions. After 6 months, amount of bone gain will be assessed.

[/INST] This study evaluates the use of an interferon gamma release assay (IGRA) in monitoring anti-TB treatment. The study included two patient groups: the first group included healthy subjects who received IGRA as a diagnostic test, while the second group included PTB patients who had already received anti-TB treatment. The primary outcome measure was to compare the correlation of changes in IFN-γ response in the first antigen tube (TB1) and the newly added antigen tube (TB2) with the new reference standard of treatment outcomes (culture conversion) in the two following periods: 1) at the time of diagnosis and 30 days after anti-TB treatment initiation and (2) at 2 months after anti-TB treatment initiation. The study included 146 patients, 30 healthy subjects, and 186 baseline responses. The IFN-γ response to MTB antigens increased significantly after the start of the treatment in both the groups, 19.5% in TB1 and 43.5% in TB2. The authors conclude that IGRA can be used to monitor anti-TB treatment due to its high specificity and sensitivity.

[/INST] The study titled "Imaging Characterization of the Biomechanical Coupling of Brain and Skull" aims to apply magnetic resonance elastography (MRE) to characterize the skull-brain interface in 25 mild TBI patients with a history of traumatic meningeal enhancement (TME), 25 TME- patients (mild TBI patients without TME) and 25 healthy controls.

[/INST] The trial investigated the effect of pharmacist-initiated home blood pressure monitoring on blood pressure control in women with blood pressure elevated above their target level. To achieve that, a randomized controlled trial was conducted to compare home blood pressure monitoring in addition to pharmacist care to usual care after a 24-week follow-up period among women with hypertension. Blood pressure control was assessed as the primary outcome over a 24-week period. The pharmacist care protocol consisted of enhancing usual pharmacy services with blood pressure measurements, goal setting, reinforcement of education and counselling, and follow-up. Moreover, the pharmacist reported home blood pressure results and therapy recommendations to the patient's prescribing clinician at 2 and 6 weeks.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effects of moderate alcohol consumption with abstinence on the heart function after a heart attack. Patients will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: moderate alcohol consumption or abstinence. Participants assigned to moderate alcohol consumption will be asked to limit their alcohol intake to one standard unit per day, and participants assigned to abstinence group will be asked to refrain from alcohol for 12 months. Both groups will undergo an echocardiogram at baseline and 12-month follow-up visits. The study aims to assess the effects of alcohol consumption on patients with heart attack and will help clinicians understand the benefits and harms of alcohol consumption after a heart attack.

[/INST] This paper is an abstract about a clinical trial that aims to compare the efficacy of lactulose to polyethylene glycol for colon cleansing in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) . The trial will be randomized and controlled, with patients required to take lactulose or polyethylene glycol 2 hours prior to colonoscopy. Participants will be evaluated on their bowel cleanliness based on the Boston Bowel Preparation Scale (BBPS) scored by endoscopists and adverse events such as abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, intolerance to drugs, and allergic reaction. The trial will include 200 participants who will be recruited from multiple hospitals in China. The estimated study completion date is August 2023. The main finding of the study is expected to contribute to the use of lactulose to reduce the patient's pain during colonoscopy.

[/INST] The present paper summarizes the abstract of a clinical trial entitled “Effects of Aromatherapy on Sleep Quality and Quality of Life for Older Adults at Risk of Metabolic Syndrome in the Community”. The study is a longitudinal study with a prospective randomized design. 64 elderly people were recruited from 2 community bases in the East District of Hsinchu City. The objective of the study is to understand the sleep status and quality of life of the elderly at risk of metabolic syndrome in the community and the potential contributing factors, and to explore the effects of aromatherapy on improving sleep quality and quality of life for the elderly. The inclusion criteria for the study are elders aged 65 and above, who were without any severe respiratory diseases, with a normal sense of smell, with a risk of metabolic syndrome based on the definition of the National Health Service, with a complaint of sleep disorders, and with the willingness and ability to cooperate with the research. The data collection tools included a questionnaire with basic demographic information, the Chinese version of the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (CPSI), the World Health Organization Quality of Life Questionnaire-Taiwan Version (WHOQOL-TW) and the World Health Organization Quality of Life Questionnaire-old. The participants were randomly divided into an experimental group and a control group. The experimental group received aromatherapy and lavender essential oil compound, while the control group received a placebo, sweet almond oil. The study results of sleep quality and quality of life are to be measured using these questionnaires after one month.

[/INST] This clinical trial investigated the effectiveness of different injection methods for treating myofacial pain in the masseter muscle. Patients with trigger points in the masseter muscle received either a transcutaneous or intraoral injection of botulinum toxin. The primary outcome measure was a 10-point pain scale, and a 14-question oral health index was used as a secondary measure. The study found that transcutaneous injection resulted in less pain than intraoral injection at 6 weeks post-injection.

[/INST] The study aims to enhance the delivery of cost-effective mental healthcare in primary care settings by developing a precision treatment rule for depression. The rule will recommend either fluoxetine or psychotherapy based on a patient’s clinical and demographic characteristics to enhance the recovery of depression. The study will compare the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of optimization vs. non-optimization of treatments. The optimization is hypothesized to be more effective and cost-effective than a non-optimized approach to the treatment of depression in primary care.

The data from this study will help identify new therapeutic targets for the treatment of cystic fibrosis.Type of Study: Basic science trialNature of Involvement of Human Subjects: This study does not involve human subjects.Age Group Eligible for Study: MicePrimary Outcome: Measurement of airway neutrophilia.Secondary Outcomes: Measurement of airway and lung inflammation.Key Inclusion Criteria: None.Key Exclusion Criteria: None.Primary Analysis: Analysis of cellular inflammation in the lung and bronchoalveolar lavage fluid.Ethical Approval: The institutional animal care and use committee approved the study protocol.Informed Consent Obtained: Informed consent for human subjects is not applicable to this study.How to Obtain Data: Data collected in this study will be available from the first author upon reasonable request.
