[/INST] This is a single-center cross-sectional study conducted in a medical institution that aimed to compare the pulmonary ventilation function between patients with primary and recurrent abdominal incisional hernia. The main steps of the study were: patients search, information review, data record, data verification, statistical analysis and study report. The inclusion criteria were patients screened with abdominal incisional hernia. The exclusion criteria were abdominal external hernias, such as parastomal hernias and umbilical hernias, patients with abdominal incisional hernias diagnosed less than one year before the study, and incomplete data.

[/INST] This study is conducted in patients presenting with symptoms of suspicious coronary disease but with a negative diagnosis of coronary ischemia. They fall into two categories: patients with a normal coronary artery (Group III) and those with moderate stenosis but without plaque involvement (Group IV). The latter will have repeat scans at 6 to 18 months to assess the evolution of their coronary plaques. Patients with a significant change in their coronary calcifications or with plaque growth will be assigned to the study arm. The study arm will have three repeat scans at 6, 12, and 24 months to assess the evolution of the plaque through non-invasive imagery. The non-invasive imagery will be performed using 18F-Na PET scans. The primary aim is to describe the evolution of coronary plaque in symptomatic patients with moderately stenosed coronaries. The secondary aim is to assess the impact of treatment of hypertension, diabetes, and lipids on the evolution of these plaques. The study will also assess the incidence of MACEs in the moderate stenosis group compared to the normal stenosis group and the rate of death in the moderate stenosis group compared to that in the population of the same age and cardiovascular risk profile. The study will contribute to our understanding of the natural progression of coronary plaques and the use of non-invasive imaging modalities in this population.

[/INST] The study is a cross-sectional study that aims to study the association between white matter hyperintensities (WMH) shape and other markers of cerebrovascular disease, cognition and glymphatic disruption in patients under 65 years old with memory or vascular brain abnormalities from the memory clinic (or geriatric clinic). The study will include 50 patients and will use 3T and 7T Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scans to assess the shape of white matter hyperintensities as well as other markers of cerebrovascular disease and glymphatic disruption. Associations between WMH shape and other markers of cerebrovascular disease and cognition will be investigated by logistic regression (adjusted for age and sex) and brain clearance, volume of perivascular spaces, presence of WMH and dementia score will be investigated also by logistic regression (adjusted for age and sex). The WMH shape will be assessed by convexity, solidity, concavity index, and fractal dimension of periventricular/confluent WMHs. The study will assess WMH shape by using an in-house developed analysis pipeline. The study will be conducted at the Leiden University Medical Center and Alrijne Hospital Leiden. The study will start on 2021-01-01 and will end on 2024-12-31. The main study parameter/endpoint is to study the association of a more complex WMH shape with structural and functional markers of cerebral SVD and cognitive scores (mini-mental state exam, clinical dementia rating and cognitive domain scores). The study will benefit the field of neurocognitive disorders by adding knowledge about the relationships between WMH shape and other markers of cerebrovascular disease, cognition and glymphatic disruption in patients with vascular brain abnormalities. There are no significant ethical issues concerning the study. The results of the study may not provide a substantial benefit to the participants, but they may further our knowledge about dementia and cerebrovascular disease. The study will be conducted in compliance with good clinical practice and Dutch law.

[/INST] The summary of the clinical trial "The Role of Artificial Intelligence in Endoscopic Diagnosis of Esophagogastric Junctional Adenocarcinoma：A Single Center, Case-control, Diagnostic Study" was generated. The trial focused on stomach neoplasms as the condition, and the intervention was to explore the role of artificial intelligence in the endoscopic diagnosis of esophagogastric junctional adenocarcinoma. The trial used a case-control, diagnostic design and established an intelligent endoscopic diagnosis system based on deep learning. The primary outcomes consisted of four sub-measures: sensitivity, specificity, negative predictive value, positive predictive value, and accuracy. Lastly, endoscopists of different levels were compared with the established intelligent endoscopic diagnosis system.

[/INST] The FRSW107 study evaluates the efficacy and safety of recombinant human coagulation factor VIIa-Fc fusion protein (FRSW107) in pediatric patients. The intervention group received FRSW107 at 25 IU/kg, administered three times per day, with the option to adjust the dose to 65 IU/kg if considered clinically relevant. The evaluation of the clinical outcome of bleeding and its clinical manifestations will be assessed throughout the study using methods such as blood analysis. Outcomes include annualized bleeding rate (ABR) and annual joint bleeding rate (AJBR) for all bleeds. The study plans to complete data collection for enrolled patients by December 2028.

[/INST] Introduction: The use of music has been shown to have therapeutic benefits in many different clinical populations. There is already emerging evidence in support of the use of music therapy in palliative care. Studies seem to suggest that music therapy may alleviate physical pain as well as psychological, social, and emotional suffering, and may also lead to spiritual benefits. However, there is a lack of information regarding what forms and techniques of music therapy are most beneficial, as the approaches vary widely between studies. Researchers conducted a crossover study of 20 participants receiving two types of music therapy sessions (live and recording). Participants completed a series of surveys pre- and post-music therapy sessions and autonomic recordings were taken during the sessions.

[/INST] The summary of this trial aims to reduce waste and healthcare costs related to cataract surgery by examining the impact of recycling surgical supplies on postoperative endophthalmitis. The study will compare rates of postoperative endophthalmitis in patients undergoing cataract surgery in two intervention groups, using disposable items versus sterilizing reusable items.

[/INST] This study aimed to investigate the efficacy of dTMS, which is a magnetic stimulation technology, as a new therapeutic tool in the treatment of anorexia nervosa (AN). Current evidence on dTMS for the treatment of AN is limited, and there is a need for more research to understand the efficacy and safety of dTMS in AN.

[/INST] The SeDeN-p3 study is a mixed observational study of knowledge, expectations, acceptability, and parental representations regarding expanded newborn screening using genetic. The study will be conducted in France among parents or co-parents whose newborn child was recently born, as well as parents or co-parents whose youngest biological child is aged 1 week to 3 years old. Other study groups will include parents or co-parents whose child had a suspicious newborn screening result that was confirmed at the diagnosis phase, as well as parents or co-parents whose child was diagnosed later based on clinical signs for diseases not included in the list of diseases screened in the French national newborn screening policy. Researchers will use questionnaires and interviews to collect data. The main outcome is a mixed matrix of multiple dimensions of parental acceptability of expanded newborn screening. The study aims to assess parental knowledge and expectations regarding expanded newborn screening using genetic. It also aims to explore the parental acceptability of expanded newborn screening using genetic, as well as explore parental opinions on the use of genetic testing for the diseases not included in the list of diseases to be screened or in the list of diseases to be confirmed in the French national newborn screening policy using current methods.

[/INST] This study includes participants aged 18 years and older with low back pain (LBP) for the last six weeks or longer and who understand written and spoken English. The proposed study will assess the effects of Tai chi, a safe form of exercise for people of all ages and physical abilities on pain levels, quality of life, and sleep symptoms of patients with LBP.

[/INST] This observational study is being conducted to study the toxicities and efficacy of CAR T-cell therapy in PLWH with B cell malignancies. [/INST] PEAR-MET is a study evaluating the utility of computer vision and bioinformatics in personalized medicine. The study aims to evaluate the functionality of therapies and biomarkers through imaging-based biomarker development for patients diagnosed with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). The researchers will create a system capable of handling and processing images for data input, then design algorithms and software to process the images. In doing so, they hope to better understand and characterize treatment responses. The system will then be used to measure specific biomarkers, which will correlate with the response of each patient to therapy. Finally, the study will evaluate the response of patients who receive immunotherapy or targeted therapy.

[/INST] The main task performed by the research paper entitled "Delayed Surgery in Inflammatory Bowel Disease" is to conduct a health economic analysis involving evaluations of quality of life factors and other relevant aspects. This analysis involves a comparison between an arm where participants are waiting for surgery, and an arm where participants are currently undergoing surgery. The data for this analysis was acquired from patients suffering from "Inflammatory Bowel Disease” (IBD) from the time period of 2017-2021, and they included those who are both waiting for and undergoing elective surgery. The primary objective of this study is to determine the effects of surgery delays on health economics, including quality of life. The secondary objective is to analyze the effects of surgery delays on socioeconomic parameters and the rate of postoperative complications.

[/INST] The objective of this trial is to assess the role of myeloid-derived suppressive cells (MDSCs) in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients. To answer their question, the researchers propose to take a sample of the tumor at the time of surgery and put it in culture for subsequent analysis in vitro.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that explores the effects of reducing added sugars on sweetness perception in adolescents. The trial will compare the effects of replacing sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) with plain sparkling water on taste perception and consumption of SSBs and unsweetened sparkling water. A mobile app will be used to record food intake, and participants will undergo oral glucose tolerance testing to monitor changes in glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity. Other outcomes include measures of glycemic variability and waist circumference. Changes in sweetness perception and taste preference will be investigated using sensory testing. Participants will use the TADA app to track food and beverage intake. Other methods used to monitor adherence to the intervention will include a glucose monitoring system and surveys. The proposed study seeks to determine whether reducing added sugars in the diet can improve sweetness perception and decrease SSB intake in adolescents.

[/INST] This is a randomized clinical trial to evaluate the early wound healing score (EHS) as the primary objective of the study. Primary outcomes are early wound healing score (EHS) with a summation of clinical signs of re-epithelization (CSR), clinical signs of haemostasis (CSH) and clinical signs of inflammation (CSI). A total score of zero points is assigned in the presence of suppuration, while the worst possible score is 0 point. Dentinal sensitivity and other complications such as swelling, post-operative infection, pain and patient satisfaction will also be measured.

[/INST] The trial is a single center, randomized, controlled, observational clinical study. The study recruited 60 patients (18 years old or older) who suddenly lost hearing within 72 hours. Primary outcome measures consisted of changes in pure-tone averages and speech recognition scores from baseline to 3 months after starting treatment. Secondary outcome measures consisted of changes in THI scores and visual analogue scales of tinnitus from baseline to 3 months after starting treatment. Information on these variables was collected at baseline and after 3, 7, 14, 30, and 90 days of treatment. The findings of the study have not yet been reported.

[/INST] This text outlines a project to screen for Cystinosis and primary hyperoxaluria in newborns. The project is a result of a pilot study conducted in 2018/19 to establish a molecular screening for cystinosis. Cystinosis screening will be performed using a quadruplex PCR and next-generation sequencing, while primary hyperoxaluria screening will be done using droplet digital PCR. The outcomes of the project are the confirmation of diagnosis of cystinosis and primary hyperoxaluria with follow-up and clarification by centers specialized in the care of the diseases.

[/INST] The summary of the trial document is as follows:This study is a randomized controlled trial that investigates the effect of the negative-pressure drain on surgical site infection in surgical wounds of abdominal surgery. The trial does not conceal information about surgical technique and drain placement methods, but the investigators control various surgical procedures to reduce inequality in evaluation and bias. Negative pressure drainage is a drainage catheter that is placed in the subcutaneous wound of an intra-abdominal surgery wound for draining fluid such as hematoma, seroma, and pus. In this study, the drain placement is done after completion of surgery and before skin closure, and the subcutaneous wound of the intra-abdominal surgery site is used. The negative-pressure drain is set to -75 mmHg, and the pressure is released within 4 hours after the drain is placed. The drainage catheter is changed when the amount of drainage fluid is 20 ml per day or more. The drain is removed and the drainage catheter is left in place when the drainage volume per day is less than 20 ml. The drain is applied for 5 days after the placement of the drain and is removed if the drainage amount is less than 20 ml per 24 hours. The drain remains during all study days. The primary outcome is the change in the rate of surgical site infection of the abdominal surgery site at post-operative day 3, day 5, and day 7 and before discharge. The secondary outcome is the change in the length of the hospital stay and the scores in the quality of life (36-Item Short Form Survey Instrument [SF-36]) from before discharge until 14 days, and after 14 days of discharge and until 1-year follow-up for the primary outcome.

[/INST] The study is a clinical trial aimed at comparing the immune modulation effects of palbociclib, ribociclib, and abemaciclib with letrozole in estrogen-receptor positive and/or progesterone receptor positive breast cancer. The study will collect tumor, blood, and stool samples prospectively before treatment, at 2 weeks after treatment, and after 12 weeks of treatment at the time of surgery. Immune modulation effects will be compared between three treatment groups across breast tumor RNAseq analysis. The study involves a parallel assignment of patients to three experimental groups with two months of treatment duration each and a primary outcome measure of the expression of immune-related signature change after different CDK4/6 inhibitor treatments by RNAseq. The study is designed to characterize the RNAseq from serial tumor biopsy samples through the completion of the study with an average of 3 years.

[/INST] Dementia Care Quality at Home Project aims to develop, implement, and evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of HBPC Dementia Care Quality at Home intervention in two HBPC practices. [/INST] The study is a two-arm, randomized controlled trial comparing the effect of Resistance Training and Flexibility Training on PPD. A total of 36 females aged 20-40 years with postpartum depression will be recruited. Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale, Exercise Self-Efficacy Scale, and Maternal Postpartum Quality of Life Questionnaire will be used as subjective measurements for depression, exercise self-efficacy, and quality of life, respectively. Spss Statistics version 25.0 will be used for statistical analysis.

[/INST] The study is to compare the surface hardness and wear resistance of two sets of artificial teeth, prefabricated and milled by computer-aided design (CAD)/computer-aided manufacturing (CAM), after three and six months of use. The study is a crossover study, with the participants being randomly assigned to two treatment groups. Participants who were at least 55 and no more than 65 years old, completely edentulous, and those with angle class I maxillomandibular relation were eligible for the study. To compare wear resistance, the surface hardness of the two types of artificial teeth will be compared. To compare surface wear, vertical and volumetric changes in dentures due to wear of artificial teeth will be measured using a 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional measuring system. The study will measure the wear resistance of two types of artificial teeth (prefabricated and machined teeth) after three and six months of wearing by assessing the surface hardness and measuring the horizontal and volumetric changes due to vertical wear.

[/INST] This clinical study is a part of the ARIADA Phase II Program. This program uses two biomarker-based, neoadjuvant studies of patients with HER2-enriched (HER2+) and Luminal and HER2-negative (HER2−) breast cancer.

[/INST] This is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) titled, “The Effects of Using Different Anesthetics on the Prognosis of Primary Tumors and Its Mechanism of Action”. This study aims to compare the effect of intraoperative use of intravenous anesthetics and inhalation anesthetics on the prognosis of patients with brain, lung, liver, and ovarian cancer tumors. The study will also examine the mechanism of action of each type of anesthetic. The participants will be ASA class I-III patients above the age of 18 who are getting elective surgery for brain, liver, lung, or ovarian cancer. Both the experimental and control groups will receive one of the following types of anesthesia: sevoflurane or propofol. The intervention received by the experimental group and control group was not specified. The primary outcome is OS from the date of surgery until the date of the first documented progression or death from any cause. The secondary outcomes include the presence of disease progression(the period from the day of surgery to the date of first documented progression), Clavien-Dindo classification, Karnofsky performance score, blood loss intraoperatively, duration of surgery, number of transfusions, duration of anesthesia, total opioid use, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and number of days of ICU stay.

[/INST] The study "Dissemination Programme of Physical Activity-Related Health Competence in Nursing Education" aims to develop and implement a health promotion programme based on the curriculum contents of physical activity-related health competence and subsequently disseminate it to other institutions. The study is a cluster-randomised controlled trial with four study arms, where schools act as the unit of allocation. The intervention's primary short-term outcomes are students' physical activity-related and psychological health competence, quality of physical activity, and movement quality. The long-term effects are the same outcomes assessed six months after the end of the programme. In addition, the primary outcome measures for the students is a relational composite outcome index based on leisure-time physical activity and occupational physical activity. The long-term outcomes also include general health status, work ability, and musculoskeletal complaints. The study's secondary outcomes include physical job stress in nursing, which will be assessed both in the short and long term. Participants are undergraduate nursing students, and they are randomly assigned into study groups by school clusters. The control group receives no specific intervention, while the other three groups receive the developed programme via different intervention models.

[/INST] The study is titled "Effect of Diosmin/Hesperidin Combination on the Clinical Outcomes in Patients With Polycystic Ovary Syndrome". The study is a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effects of diosmin/hesperidin combined with a metformin-containing treatment or diosmin/hesperidin alone on the clinical outcomes in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). The primary objectives of the study are to evaluate the effects of diosmin/hesperidin combined with a metformin-containing treatment or diosmin/hesperidin alone on the inflammation and glucose metabolism in patients with PCOS. The secondary objectives are to evaluate the effects of diosmin/hesperidin combined with a metformin-containing treatment or diosmin/hesperidin alone on the other clinical outcomes, including PCOS signs and symptoms, hormone levels, quality of life, and safety parameters. The patients will be randomized to one of the three treatment groups (diosmin/hesperidin and a metformin-containing treatment; diosmin/hesperidin alone; or placebo) and will be followed for 4 months. The study will be conducted in Korea and will enroll a total of 100 participants.

[/INST] In this research, the authors investigated a novel tracker to guide the resection of early-stage lung cancer and to assist with lymph node dissection during minimally invasive surgery. They developed a fluorescently labelled antibody against the HER-1 receptor and injected it into patients with lung cancer within 5 days before the surgery. On the day of the surgery, they used an NIR camera to observe the location of the cancer cells and metastatic lymph nodes. In vitro and in vivo studies demonstrated that this method could accurately localize and guide the resection of tumours. The use of an NIR camera during lung cancer surgery showed promising results, particularly for detecting small nodules and lymph node metastases. Thus, the authors concluded that Cetuximab could be a potential tracker for fluorescent-guided lung cancer resection. The study provides insights into the potential of using this NIR camera system for lung cancer surgery and highlights the importance of fluorescence-guided techniques in precision medicine.
[/INST] Standard Versus Prolonged Antibiotic Prophylaxis After Pancreatoduodenectomy (SPARROW): a Multicenter, Randomized Controlled Trial

[/INST] The study is a phase 2 basket trial that will evaluate the combination of sotorasib and panitumumab in participants with advanced solid tumors harboring the KRAS G12C mutation. Participants must have confirmed KRAS G12C mutations detected by next-generation sequencing analysis. The primary outcome measure is an objective response rate based on RECIST v1.1, assessed after cycle 1 day 1 (each cycle is 14 days). Eligible participants must be ≥19 years old. Participants with active brain metastasis or leptomeningeal metastasis are excluded. The study will evaluate up to 84 participants.

[/INST] The study was titled "Use of a Novel Volume-stable Collagen Matrix (VCMX) in the Treatment of Single Gingival Recession Associated With Non-carious Cervical Lesion Partially Restored" and was a parallel randomized controlled trial with a masked design. Participants in the study consisted of adults at least 20 years old and were either nonsmokers or light smokers. They had no systemic disease, no signs of periodontal disease, and had an acceptable oral hygiene. In order to participate in the study, participants were required to have a gingival recession between 1 and 2 mm that had been partially restored with healthy tooth structures, and an adjacent tooth without a cervical lesion or cervical abrasion. The experimental group was treated with a combination method that included partial restorations, coronally advanced flap (CAF), and VCMX. The control group was treated with partial restorations and CAF. The duration of the study was 180 days, during which the patients were examined and analyzed at multiple follow-up points to assess the efficacy of the treatments. A gingival recession-reduction parameter was used to determine the success or failure of the treatment. The results indicate that the experimental group with VCMX had a significantly lower rate of gingival recession compared to the control group. The study suggests that VCMX is an effective treatment option for single gingival recession associated with non-carious cervical lesion partially restored. It is a minimally invasive and patient-friendly approach that may become a viable treatment option for managing single gingival recessions with a cervical lesion.

[/INST] Methods: Participants were patients with gastrointestinal tumors who were admitted to the First Hospital of Shanxi Medical University in China from July 2021 to June 2023. Patients were stratified based on three variables: nutrition risk screening score NRS2002 ≥ 3 and PG-SGA ≥ 4, low BMI at admission, and age ≥ 70 years at the beginning of the study. They were assigned to either an intervention group or a control group based on these variables. The intervention group received 5 steps of malnutrition treatment based on the NRS2002 score, an individualized dietary plan, and physical activity. The results of the NRS2002 screening and the PG-SGA scale were analyzed between the two groups. The results of a stratified analysis were also analyzed for each variable.

[/INST] The study examined the effect of a connection between dental implants and abutments on marginal bone loss and gingival seal. The study included two groups of partially edentulous mandible patients with Kennedy class I or II (unilateral or bilateral free end) or III (posterior intermediate edentulous section) mandibular requiring two implants to restore at least two molars, two molars and one premolar, or two premolars and one molar. The height of the transgingival abutment was at least 2 mm. The two interventions involved restoring multiple implants with a conventional multi-unit abutment between the implant and the prosthesis or a Connect® abutment between the implant and the prosthesis. The primary outcomes were the difference in peri-implant marginal bone level measured by standardized periapical radiography at 1 year. The secondary outcomes included peri-implant microbiome and peri-implant inflammation measured by next-generation sequencing methods and multiplex techniques methods at 1 year.

[/INST] In the context of sports, the word “setter” refers to a position player who is responsible for receiving a volleyball and setting the ball to the middle hitter for an attack on the opposite team. [/INST] The trial study aimed to investigate whether HFR (hematodiafiltration with endogenous reinfusion) can effectively reduce the clearance rate of uremic toxins compared to conventional HD. The study included patients who were 18 to 75 years old, were stable with MHD, and had arteriovenous fistula or an artificial blood vessel for vascular access with a blood flow between 200mL and 2000mL per minute. Patients were required to sign an informed consent form to participate for three years. The study aimed to evaluate the clearance rate of uremic toxin by HFR and the concentrations of β2-microglobulin, indoxyl sulfate, and λ-free light chain before and after HFR. The study also measured spKt/V and urea reduction ratio, as well as the concentration of other middle molecules and macromolecular uremic toxins, serum albumin, branched chain amino acids, vitamins A, C, E, dialysis comfort score, and biochemical and hematological indicators, before and after HFR.

[/INST] This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of multimodel therapy combining Bortezomib, Sorafenib, and Bevacizumab for primary liver cancer (hepatocellular carcinoma, HCC), which have high recurrence rates after liver transplantation. The primary endpoints are the 1-year recurrence rate-free survival rate (1-year RFS rate). The study period is from when the patient is randomized to the time of disease recurrence or any cause-induced mortality. The eligible participants are patients with HCC who underwent liver transplantation in other hospitals. Sorafenib, Bortezomib, or Bevacizumab will be administered in the treatment group.

[/INST] This paper outlines the protocol for a pragmatic trial that investigates the impact of a supportive-expressive group therapy intervention (SEGT) on mental health outcomes for adults with limb loss who are inpatients. SEGT is being compared to treatment as usual (TAU), where participants in TAU may receive treatment via social work, psychiatry, physiatry, and occupational therapy. The primary outcomes of the study are depression severity (measured by the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9)) and anxiety severity (measured by the Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7 (GAD-7)). The study will recruit adults (18 years of age) who have lost a limb in any location and at any time. Participants who are acutely distressed at the time of recruitment will be excluded, as they will need immediate care that will be prioritized over participation in the study. All other consenting participants will be randomized to either the SEGT intervention or TAU, with those who are randomized to SEGT receiving support from interprofessional team lead by a psychiatrist. Participant surveys will be conducted at the start of the study, immediately after the intervention, and 3 months later at follow-up.

Albumin ≤ 2.5 g/dl upon presentation. The study design is parallel assignment with non-masking. The albumin levels will be maintained above 3.0 g/dl in the studied group. ROTEM, INR, APTT, endothelial function, inflammatory markers, pulmonary function test, albuminome, mortality at 28 days will be analyzed. This study will run for a maximum of one year.

For enrollment of participants, the study included patients over 18 years of age, were in need of hypotension to maintain a stable blood pressure of more than or equal to 65 mmHg; and requiring sedative medications due to discomfort, safety reasons, and to facilitate life support measures, after obtaining the consent of the patient or the patient's family members.

[/INST] The trial is a phase II trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the short-term evolution of infants with ulcerative-necrotizing enterocolitis who are undergoing intraperitoneal CO2 insufflation. The trial involves a total of 40 infants aged between 28 weeks to 37 weeks gestation. The infants will be randomly assigned to the intervention group (laparoscopy with intraperitoneal CO2 insufflation) or the control group (laparoscopy without intraperitoneal CO2 insufflation).

[/INST] The given clinical trial document is for comparison of hair removal using intense pulsed light and diode laser in female patients with axillary hair. The study is randomized controlled trial of intense pulsed light and diode laser to the axilla of female patients. The procedure sessions are once a month and the follow-up will be carried out 30 days and 6 months after the end of the treatment. The patients will be instructed not to perform any trichotomy procedures in the region during the trial period. The treatment technique is punctual where the applicator will be kept in full contact with the skin, at 90° and moved to the next point after deposition of energy over the entire treatment area, until the defined energy will be delivered. The patient will be assessed on hair count, Global Aesthetic Improvement Scale (GAIS), pain score (visual analogue scale), quality of life (WHOQOL-bref), patient's satisfaction level, Self-esteem scale, and terms related to study. Diode laser and intense pulsed light are effective methods of hair removal that can achieve long-term results, with excellent patient feedback.

[/INST] Objective of this study is to assess the evolution of plasma brain-derived tau (BD-tau) levels in patients with large- or medium-vessel occlusion stroke within 9 hours of symptom onset. The aim is to characterize BD-tau levels in relation to timepoints after onset (every hour from 0 to 48h), and investigate if there is a correlation between BD-tau levels, radiological infarct evolution, and functional outcome. 100 patients will be enrolled from a specialized stroke service and blood samples will be collected along with routine blood draws. Patients will be assessed for standard clinical variables and undergo neuroimaging at admission, at 24h and at 48h if possible, or at discharge. Infarct core volume, regional cerebral collateral blood flow, and final infarct volume will be assessed using radiological procedures. Functional outcome at 90 days (mRS) and 7 days (mRS or CRS-R) will be used as standard measures of outcome. Secondary outcomes will include early recurrent ischemic stroke and secondary intracerebral hemorrhage. A Bayesian mixed effects model with Markov chain Monte Carlo methods will be used for statistical analysis.

[/INST] Artificial Intelligent Accelerates the Learning Curve for Mastering Contrast-enhanced Ultrasound of Thyroid Nodules is a clinical trial that aims to train radiologists in using artificial intelligence (AI) to improve their ability to assess thyroid nodules using contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) by providing training datasets. The training datasets consisted of the features of thyroid nodules extracted using AI by assisting radiologists. Intervention was provided to two groups of trainees who had not received any CEUS training before. Both groups had access to the AI-extracted features of thyroid nodules on the training CEUS videos and also had 3-monthly performance assessments and feedback. The faculty could review the trainees’ progress and provide one-to-one training. The primary outcome was the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (ROC). The secondary outcome was the performance assessment at the end of the 3-month intervals. The trial showed that the performance of the trained group improved significantly better than the control group and reached the level of expert radiologists by the sixth month after the training. This clinical trial showed that the use of AI-extracted features from CEUS videos could significantly accelerate the learning curves for residents.

[/INST] The investigators will program the Artificial Variance (AV) platform to generate a simulated video of a person walking through the lab and navigating toward different objects and tasks. This will be presented to the participants on a screen as though they were seeing it in their prosthetic vision. The participants will then be asked to perform different tasks depending on the specific type of experiment: perceptual judgment tasks (e.g., detecting a stimulus) or behavioral tasks (e.g., reporting size by drawing on a touchscreen). The amount of reaction time and participant response will be recorded. Furthermore, the AV platform will be programmed to track the participant’s eye movement in order to record what they are looking at. They will not have access to the code and only get the output. For the device users: A) The participant will be sitting 1.5 meters away from the screen, and will be asked to pay a lot of attention to what they will see on the screen (i.e. an artificial video of the virtual environment). B) The prosthetic stimulus will be presented to the subject and the subject will be instructed to view it and pay attention to it. C) The subject will be asked to rate the visibility of the stimulus according to standard rating scales (e.g., a 10- or 13-point rating scale). For the control subjects (with no visual prostheses): A) The control subject will be sitting 1.5 meters away from the same screen and will be shown an artificial video of the lab empty besides the subject, simulating an environment without a prosthetic implant. B) The subject will be asked to imagine that they are wearing their prosthetic visual implant and can see the stimuli from the lab while being in this environment. The researcher will have control over the frame of the video (changing to a different frame on the video or “zooming" in on an object on the screen). C) The subject will be asked to rate the visibility of the stimulus according to standard rating scales (e.g., a 10- or 13-point rating scale).

[/INST] This study evaluates the effectiveness of ultrasound examinations in monitoring lymph node basin recurrence of high-risk cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck (cSCCHN) over two years. Participants are separated into three groups based on their TNM (tumor size, nodal metastases, and metastases to other organs) stage 2 or 3 cSCCHN diagnosis received. After diagnosis, one group of individuals undergoes immediate sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) only, while the other two groups receive SLNB. Those in these latter groups then undergo ultrasound surveillance, with participants in one group having ultrasounds every 6 months for 2 years. The primary outcome is the number of participants who develop nodal metastasis over two years with those in the ultrasound group compared to historical controls. The number of participants who experience local recurrence of the disease, disease-specific mortality, or overall mortality over two years is also compared between study groups and controls.

[/INST] Gastroesophageal Reflux in Infants is an observational study designed to examine saliva biomarkers of gastroesophageal reflux in infants undergoing 24-hour esophageal MII-pH. Infants aged 1–12 months with symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux are eligible for the study. The diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux in infants will rely on 24-hour esophageal MII-pH. Saliva samples will be collected at multiple time points during the MII-pH and after the test. The sample size for this study is unclear. No follow-up will be conducted after the analysis of the study results. The primary outcome of the study is gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) symptoms; the secondary outcome is the biochemical profile of salivary markers of gastroesophageal reflux in infants. The pH and impedance signals detected by MII-pH are considered the gold standard for diagnosis and quantification of gastroesophageal reflux. However, MII-pH cannot be used in the long term as it is invasive and uncomfortable for patients. The biochemical profile of salivary markers of gastroesophageal reflux can potentially be a non-invasive, low-cost, and reproducible diagnostic tool for infants with persistent symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux after MII-pH monitoring or negative MII-pH.

The results show that the average length of hospital stay is 18.62 days, and the mortality rate is 24%. They also found that 42% of the total deaths occurred in the trauma unit in the first 24 hours. They conclude that it is necessary to improve prevention policies through injury registries that describe the general characteristics of the injured population in the emergencies and the injuries sustained, as well as the complications and outcomes that occur in the short, medium, and long term.

In addition, four of the participants will be video-taped at multiple timepoints to track their postures, and they will be asked to wear an accelerometer and pedometer 25% time of the day for a week at the beginning of the trial. Questionnaire and mobility assessments will be performed before and after the six-week period to measure mobility, pain, and other parameters related to the study. The study's primary outcome will be the change in participants' mobility, as determined by the difference in mobility between visit two and visit one. The results will help confirm the feasibility of the program, guide implementation decisions, and provide the necessary information for developing a larger, long-term study.

[/INST] In general, this study describes the protocol for evaluating the effectiveness of a web-based adherence intervention in patients with metastatic breast cancer (MBC). The study has two major goals, firstly, the development of a prediction model of non-adherence which has been developed in the R1595/21-IEO 1704 retrospective study, and secondly, developing a framework that integrates risk predictive models alongside educational and training tools that could be incorporated into a DSS named TREAT (Treatmet Adherence SupporT). The TREAT system is a web-based DSS that contains four sections: 'Metastatic Breast Cancer', 'Adherence to Cancer Therapies', 'Promoting Adherence', and 'My Adherence Diary'. The system is targeted at MBC patients to identify clinical factors (comorbidities, pain presence, tumor type, treatment type), psychological parameters (personality traits, anxiety, depression, self-efficacy for coping with cancer and sense of coherence), and QoL variables that serve as predictors for patients' adherence to OATs. This study is a randomized controlled study that involves 100 metastatic breast cancer patients who are admitted to the Division of Medical Senology. The patients are randomized into two arms, i.e., control arm and intervention arm. The intervention arm receives the TREAT system, and the control arm receives a standard medical advice. The subjects are asked to use the TREAT system ad libitum for 3 months. To be eligible for the study, the patient must be over 18 years old, have a metastatic breast cancer diagnosis, be taking oral treatment intervention for metastatic breast cancer, have internet access and their own smartphone or tablet, and have read and signed the informed consent. The control arm patients will not be provided with access to the TREAT system. The two arms of the study will be followed for 3 months. The primary outcome measure of the study is the evaluation of the effectiveness of the TREAT system in fostering adherence to oral anticancer treatments. The subjects will be assessed for this purpose after 3 months. The study will also evaluate the clinical, psychological, and quality of life parameters that predict adherence, the risk perception that predicts adherence, and the psychological predictors of adherence. The study will last for 3 months, and the study subjects will be assessed three times. The first assessment will be at the beginning of the study, and the second and third assessments will be after 1 month and 3 months, respectively. The outcome measures of the study will be assessed using various questionnaires, including the Breast Cancer Management Inventory Quality of Life (BCMI QoL). The questionnaires will be administered to the study subjects during their visits to the Division of Medical Senology. The data from the four assessments will be combined, and the results will be analyzed by means of statistics. This study aims to develop and assess the effectiveness of the TREAT system in increasing the adherence of patients with metastatic breast cancer by leveraging the predictions from the TREAT system.

[/INST] Melatonin, as a potentially potent antioxidant and anti-inflammatory agent, has been investigated for its effects on cardiovascular and bone metabolism in patients with peritoneal dialysis. The aim of this study is to determine the effects of melatonin supplementation on glycemic parameters, cardiovascular diseases risk factors, bone metabolism markers and quality of life in peritoneal dialysis patients. The null hypothesis is that melatonin administration and placebo consumption are not significantly associated with changes in the mentioned markers. The study is a single-blind, randomized controlled trial. Recruited peritoneal dialysis patients who meet the inclusion criteria will be randomly assigned to receive either intervention (melatonin) or comparison (placebo) supplementation containing melatonin or starch, respectively. The supplements will be consumed orally according to the intervention protocol for a period of 10 weeks. Serum biochemical parameters for glycemic profiles and cardiovascular disease risk factors, as well as bone metabolism markers, will be measured at baseline and after the 10-week intervention period by a biochemistry unit based on standard laboratory procedures. Additionally, questionnaires will be administered to assess quality of life, sleep quality and depression among the participants. Statistical analysis of the data generated from laboratory examinations and questionnaires will be used to test the null hypothesis, and the findings may provide evidence to support the use of melatonin supplementation for patients with peritoneal dialysis.

The study found that the skin surface temperatures of the lumbar regions decreased significantly after AA compared to those before AA. The study concluded that acupuncture treatment at bilateral Kidney point on the ears can induce changes in the temperature of other parts of the body, which may affect the functioning of internal viscera . Children with a history of seizures or other neurological illnesses, or any psychiatric illness will be excluded. Both ASD children who are receiving treatment or are not receiving any treatment will be included in the study. A stool sample will be collected from each participant and analyzed to identify changes in the gut microbiome and metabolome, with a focus on the relationship between those changes and risk factors related to autism. The main focus of this study is to analyze the relationship between gut microbiome changes and autism risk factors in children, as well as the contribution of those changes to the diagnosis and prognosis of autism in children. Additionally, the study aims to identify gut microbiome or metabolome changes that can be targeted for diagnosis or treatment of ASD.

[/INST] The study "Effectiveness of Internet-based Self-help Money Management Program Among Adult With Severe Mental Illness" is a randomized controlled trial that aims to develop and assess the effectiveness of a self-help money management program delivered through the internet. The study will evaluate the efficacy of a self-help course consisting of four modules that cover topics related to money management skills and financial well-being, utilizing a Model of Human Occupation (MOHO) approach. The program will be compared to a control group using waitlist intervention to assess the positive outcomes of the self-management money management program on financial self-efficacy, financial behaviour, financial attitude, financial well-being, and psychological and physical wellbeing, including anxiety and depression. The study will also assess the participants’ perceptions regarding the internet as a delivery mechanism for self-management programs. All the data will be analysed in an intention-to-treat basis, using linear mixed effects and multiple t-tests. The results suggest that self-help money management programs can have a positive impact on financial self-efficacy, which in turn can lead to better financial health, and consequently, financial and psychological stability. The study is novel as there are limited money management education programs available for people with severe mental illnesses. Additionally, this is the first study that will evaluate the efficacy of self-help money management programs delivered through the internet for severe mental illnesses. Overall, the study aims to develop and evaluate a self-help money management program that can potentially increase financial literacy and stability among people with severe mental illnesses.

This study proposes to use the SF-12 to evaluate the quality of life (QOL) of the recruited patients. The recruited subjects’ QOL will be measured two times. The first measurement will take place when they are initially recruited for the research, and the second will take place up to 24 weeks later. Participants will also be assessed for depression and anxiety using two different scales, the Depression Anxiety Stress Scale 21, and the Coping with Stress Scale. Furthermore, the researchers will use the Self-Efficacy Scale and the Cardiac Self-Efficacy Scale to evaluate the patients’ belief in themselves and their ability to confront AF symptoms or the worsening of their symptoms. The data collected in this study will help researchers identify those who are more susceptible to the negative influence of illness perceptions, coping strategies, self-efficacy, and anxiety and depression on their quality of life and, consequently, develop interventions that can help them mitigate the negative impact of those factors.

[/INST] Our systematic review compared the effectiveness of white noise versus multisensorial stimulation during retinopathy examination, a common practice in the neonatology context to assess the risk of retinopathy in blindness among preterm infants. Overall, our review suggests that multisensorial stimulation offers similar examination completion rates and better physiological indicators (HR and BP) compared to the white noise group. However, our review showed no significant differences between multisensorial stimulation and white noise in examination success rate. More studies are needed to evaluate the effectiveness of multisensorial stimulation during ROP screenings and its impact on examination completion rates and success rates. Future research should also consider the multisensory nature of retinopathy screening and explore novel ROP screening methods such as the Synchronous Multi-Sensory Analgesia and Sedation (SUMMIT) method. Our study provides valuable insights into potential ROP screening strategies and highlights the importance of multisensory stimulation during ROP screening. Further research in the field of ROP screening is needed to create effective and well tolerated ROP examination protocol for premature infants.

The HCW group only rinses their mouth for about 30 seconds, 30 minutes before each meal. In both groups, nutrition support supplements are used to help patients maintain their nutrition. According to previous similar studies, the incidence of mucositis-related side effects is reduced by 30%. Moreover, the treatment is well tolerated and does not result in any additional side effects.

[/INST] This clinical trial study investigated the effect of music, white noise, and heart sound on newborn pain. The study, designed to minimize newborn pain during blood sampling, enrolled 84 preterm or full-term newborns with a gestational age of 28-42 weeks who were eligible to participate in the study. Infants were randomly assigned to three groups: white noise, mother’s preferred music, or a heartbeat soundtrack. The control group received no music therapy. The effect of these sounds used during the procedure and for 20 minutes afterward on pain severity was measured using the Neonatal Infant Acute Pain Assessment Scale (NIAPAS). The results of the study could not support the effect of music, white noise, or heart sounds on reducing pain in newborns during a heel lance. However, these results should be considered with caution as there is a high risk of bias and low certainty of evidence. It will need to be replicated by a sufficiently large RCT that is at low risk of bias to provide a reliable conclusion about the effect of the intervention under investigation to inform future clinical practice. It is hoped that the authors will consider the points we have raised and revise their manuscript based on the suggestions given, with the goal of publishing this work in Clinical Trials.

First, it will compare the two training and supervision models of 15 hours of remote training, followed by 12 weeks of remote supervision (1 hour per week), versus face-to-face training of 15 hours, followed by 12 weeks of face-to-face supervision (1 hour per week). Second, it will compare the effectiveness of the two training models in determining the progress of parents with regard to parenting stress and children's developmental outcomes. Parents of a child with a developmental disability and/or autism who speak and/or understand English will be included. The study is scheduled for two years, from 2022 to 2024, with study participants recruited during the summer of that year. The study will be conducted in the city of Pittsburgh and surrounding areas. The study will use a non-randomized design with two active groups. Both groups will be trained in caregiver skills training. Participation in the caregiver skills training will continue for 12 weeks, with sessions lasting 6 to 90 minutes. The outcomes being observed are parent skills and knowledge, parenting stress, child development, and caregiver adherence to the training program. The primary outcome will be based on a caregiver skills survey, and other measures will be used to assess parenting stress, child adaptive behavior, and social communication skills.

[/INST] Transcranial Electrical Stimulation in Subacromial Pain Syndrome is a study being conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of transcranial electrical stimulation (TES) in the functional recovery of individuals with Subacromial Pain Syndrome (SPS). The study will involve participants aged 18-65 years who have experienced neck pain that includes redness, itching, burning, drowsiness, headache, and tingling sensations following shoulder exercises. All participants in the study will undergo standard upper limb exercises, along with TES or placebo TES stimulation. The primary outcome measures of the study include pain and disability index, Western Ontario Rotator Cuff (WORC) index, Visual Analogic Scale (VAS) for pain intensity, and shoulder muscle strength. The secondary outcome measures include range of movement, active range of movement, joint position sense, subacromial space width, scapular rhythm, scapular muscle activation, and cortical activity. The study will be conducted over 36 weeks, with a 3-week follow-up period. It will be of interest to identify whether TES is effective in reducing pain and functional impairment in individuals with SPS. The findings of this study can improve our understanding of the effectiveness of TES in individuals with SPS.

[/INST] Children between ages 2 and 17 diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder by a qualified health professional who already receive applied behavioral analysis treatment from Oxford Recovery Centre in Utah, United States were included. Subjects with prior history of seizures or genetic or mitochondrial diagnoses were excluded. The study was conducted in a retrospective study design, where children with autism received oral and written information about the treatment. Children, who agreed to participate, and have signed informed consent were divided into two groups. The first group received the treatment with hyperbaric oxygen in addition to existing ABA treatment (HBO group) and the second group received ABA treatment only (control group). The HBO group completed a minimum of 40 sessions of a hyperbaric oxygen at 2.0 ATA, and up to 60 minutes at 100% medical grade oxygen in a hard-sided monoplace hyperbaric chamber, and completed ABA treatments, while the control group received ABA treatment only. The primary outcome of the study was the age-appropriate level of verbal testing. For measuring the level of verbal test, the two age-appropriate measurements were used: the VBMAPP and the ABLLS, which is collected by trained teachers. A 6-month follow-up assessment using the VBMAPP or ABLLS was chosen to assess the long-term impact of treatment. The number of participants, who experienced side effects related to treatment with hyperbaric oxygen therapy was assessed.

[/INST] The objective of the study is to compare the analgesic efficacy of an ultrasound-guided 4-in-1 block and an ultrasound-guided adductor canal block in patients undergoing knee surgeries. The study is a comparative randomized double-blind trial in which 50 patients will be enrolled undergoing a knee surgery to receive either 4-in-1 luminal and an ultrasound-guided adductor canal block. The analgesic efficacy will be measured in terms of postoperative pain scores at 6, 12, 18, and 24 hours. The postoperative opioid requirements will also be measured in terms of first time for opioid rescue and total opioid in the first 24 hours.

[/INST] The study examined whether Immediate Lymphatic Reconstruction (ILR) could reduce the risk of lymphedema in patients with breast cancer. Patients who received axillary lymph node dissection were either divided into a group that underwent immediate lymphatic reconstruction or a group that did not. The incidence of arm lymphedema was then compared between the two groups. Drainage volume, seroma or lymphocele development, patient reported outcome measures (PROM) using the LYMPH-Q Upper Extremity Module, and subclinical lymphedema were also assessed. The study design was a prospective randomized controlled trial with an intervention of ILR or non-ILR and a primary outcome measure of the occurrence of arm lymphedema over two years. Secondary outcome measures were PROM, drainage volume, seroma or lymphocele development, and subclinical lymphedema.

[/INST] The study evaluated the hand rehabilitation outcomes of patients with hand burns who received releasing incisions. Participants were adults hospitalized with hand burns who received releasing incisions and skin grafting. The primary outcome measures were functional scores, scar quality, and healing status, which were assessed at various time points after the burn. The secondary outcome measures were the VAS pain score, QuickDASH score, and need for surgical revisions. The study found that the releasing incision technique improved functional outcomes, including return to activities and pain, and had a higher scar quality rating in post-operative assessments at 6 months post-burn.
[/INST] Study Title: The Stanford Plant-based Educational Study: Providers Learning About Nutrition Together (PLANT)

[/INST] The study aims to validate a questionnaire that assesses survivors' needs in early breast cancer patients. The questionnaire consists of 17 items and addresses breast cancer survivorship concerns. [/INST] The present study is a prospective clinical study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness and acceptability of the Connecting and Reflecting Experience (CARE) program on postpartum depression, postpartum anxiety, parenting stress, and infant temperament. The treatment group will receive 90-minute sessions weekly for 12 weeks, and each session will consist of up to seven parents. Participants will be assessed at the beginning of the treatment, at post-treatment (the eighth session), and at one-month follow-up. The study measures will include the Beck Anxiety Inventory, the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale, the Parenting Stress Index, a brief self-reported treatment satisfaction survey, and the revised Therapeutic Factors Inventory. The study aims to examine whether the CARE group, which focuses on parental reflective functioning, improves maternal internalizing (postpartum depression and anxiety symptoms) and externalizing problems (parenting stress and infant temperament). The study is still actively recruiting and has recruited 35 participants.

[/INST] Effects of the EEG-NFB on Cognitive Function study,  examines the effects of 3 weeks of neurofeedback training on cognitive function in 25 men aged 20 to 25 using the Trail-Making Test (TMT) and the Stroop Test (ST). [/INST] The clinical trial aims to compare the favorable neurological outcomes at 90 days post-operation between radial access and femoral access in patients with acute basilar artery occlusion undergoing endovascular recanalization.

[/INST] A mixed methods study aims to understand Black and African American community perspectives on integrating prenatal care with community doulas and test a randomized controlled trial to compare doulas to standard prenatal care. By involving community members in study design and examining their perspectives, researchers hope to build trust and understanding between medical institutions and marginalized communities. The study further addresses issues of distrust in healthcare and lack of doulas in underserved areas through a novel integration of community doulas with existing prenatal care. The study design, community engagement through focus groups, and intervention provide a valuable approach that can be adapted in other healthcare and community settings to promote the involvement of community members in health research and improve healthcare delivery.

[/INST] This study is a phase 1 trial of IBRX-042 which is a therapeutic vaccine expressing HPV E6 and E7 proteins of HPV to treat patients. The primary objective of the study is to determine the maximum tolerated dose of IBRX-042. The secondary objective of the trial is to determine the safety profile of IBRX-042, including the incidence of adverse events and clinically significant changes in safety laboratory tests, vital signs, and physical examination findings. Another secondary objective is to determine the dose response and immunogenicity of the vaccine.

[/INST] Detailed Summary:This is a randomized, controlled clinical study evaluating the effectiveness of glaucoma treatment with OMNI Canaloplasty versus OMNI Canaloplasty and Hydrus Stent implantation over one year. The study includes 80 participants aged 18 years and older with mild to moderate glaucoma and open-angle disease. The study involves a 50/50 chance of receiving either OMNI Canaloplasty alone or OMNI Canaloplasty with Hydrus Stent implantation. Both procedures involve cataract surgery, where the eye is randomized to one of two treatments without blinding.

[/INST] This is a randomized, double-blind, two-arm, parallel-group comparative trial conducted in 12 eye clinics or hospitals in Russia. The study population comprised patients with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) who received fixed combination of dorzolamide/ timolol eye drops 20 mg /5 mg or 0.5 ml (Dorzolamide/timolol) or fixed combination of dorzolamide/timolol eye drops 20 mg/5 mg or 0.5 ml (Cosopt) two times a day for 12 weeks. The primary efficacy endpoint was the comparison of mean IOP between the treatment and control groups at the last visit. The sample size was calculated based on the previous clinical trial to detect non-inferiority of the test product against the reference product at a one-sided significance level of less than 0.025. The analysis followed the intent-to-treat principle. The study protocol was registered with the Russian Ministry of Health in March 2017 and approved by the ethics committee of the Academic Medical Center Hospital of the Medical University of Lomonosov Moscow State University of Medicine and Dentistry in August 2017. Written informed consent was obtained from all participants before enrollment. The trial was registered in ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT04358745). The last patient visit was completed on June 30, 2018, and the trial was terminated in June 2019.

[/INST] Text Messaging to Improve Adherence to Repeat Colonoscopy via the VA: A Pilot Study is the official title of the study. The study duration is up to 21 days from the day of the participant's enrollment, with follow-up data collected up to 7 days post-procedure. The intervention arm of the study will receive motivational and instructional text messages. The primary outcome is participant satisfaction with the text-messaging intervention, measured by the National Colon Cancer Preparedness Survey (NCCPS) score. The percentage of participants who attend the scheduled colonoscopy appointment, have adequate bowel preparation during the colonoscopy appointment, and follow-up data are the secondary outcomes. The study also includes terms related to colorectal cancer for screening and surveillance colonoscopy.

The secondary outcomes will be rates of complications during surgery or up to six weeks after surgery, time to conception up to two years after surgery and fertility rate two years after surgery.

[/INST] This is a study entitled “On-line Crowdsourcing of Multi-Timescale Inference Strategies”. It is a basic science study that focuses on inferential behavior, specifically, how people think about the immediate past to make predictions about events in the future. The study uses a single arm design where Experimental: Environmental Feature Experiment is the intervention. The subjects are asked to make short-term and long-term predictions using a task where the current state is known and a task where the current state is unknown. The subjects’ choices on the task trials will be assessed, and these choices will be used to evaluate the overall study outcome.

[/INST] Sinomenine is a compound extracted from Chinese medicinal herbs. This study was a multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial of early-stage knee osteoarthritis. The main outcome of the study was the change in the total score of WOMAC from baseline. The tibial cartilage volume and walking time were the main secondary outcomes. [/INST] In the United Kingdom, the number of cardiac surgeries has steadily increased over the past decade, with more than 100,000 procedures anticipated to be performed annually by 2030 [1, 2]. The demand for cardiac surgeries has risen due to an ageing population with an increased life expectancy, which has led to an increase in the prevalence of conditions requiring cardiac surgery. In addition, advances in perioperative care and cardiothoracic surgery have led to lower risks and a higher success rate for these surgeries, which has further contributed to a rise in demand for cardiac surgeries. As a result, the United Kingdom has been projected to require approximately 20 additional specialist cardiac surgeons per year to fulfil this considerable demand .

[/INST] Summary of the article: The study compares the effectiveness of "Dumpling suture method for Ileostomy" and "Traditional suture method for Ileostomy." The suture placement methods are related to stoma complications. The study followed the standard protocols, was randomized and double-blinded, and conducted on 110 patients. The primary outcome of the study was the complication rate of stoma within 30 days after surgery. It included discoloration, erosion, and wound overgrowth. The secondary outcomes were Stoma DET score, Stoma Pain Score, and Quality of life scale score for patients with stoma. The results suggested that the suture technique in the Dumpling suture group (Dumpling group) had a lower incidence of stoma complications. The Stoma DET scores (p = 0.035) and stoma pain scores for 1 week after surgery (p = 0.035) in the Dumpling group were also significantly lower than those in the Traditional group (Traditional group). Although the number of patients in the two groups was still limited, the results needed further studies to prove. Due to the advantages of the "Dumpling suture method for Ileostomy" and the advantages of minimizing stoma complications, surgeons should apply it reasonably.

[/INST] This trial assesses progression in functional performance and daily living activities in older adults with Parkinson's disease. At the first visit, participants must have received a Parkinson's disease diagnosis according to the United Kingdom Brain Bank criteria. In addition, they must have a clinical dementia rating (CDR) score of 1 or less during the first visit. The study aims to define a cognitive phenotype of early to moderate disease progression, characterized by progressive cognitive decline and instrumental activities of daily living dysfunction without dementia. This study will also focus on defining clinical variables (e.g., age at disease onset, age at enrolment, and motor impairment) that are useful for predicting cognitive prognosis.

[/INST] The purpose of the clinical trial study is to identify the optimal effective dose of rocuronium to prevent myofibrillation after the injection of succinylcholine. The study will enroll 132 eligible participants with an age range of 18 to 80 years into three groups based on their age. Each study group will be assigned to different dosages of rocuronium. The study will use the binary response model, followed by the Down-and-Out design. The sample size in each study group will be 21, 21, and 21 for Ages 18-44 group, Ages 45-59 group, and Ages 60-80 group. The primary outcome for response is "Yes" or "No" which means the occurrence of myofibrillation within an average 45 seconds. Each participant will receive a single dose of rocuronium one minute before the injection with succinylcholine. Myofibrillations will be recorded, and data analysis will be conducted after dosing and post-dosing after 45 seconds. The study investigators will assess the safety of trial medication in all the involved patients at the end of the procedure.

[/INST] Participant recruitment and eligibility screening will involve health screening, demographic information, and the Caffeine Consumption Questionnaire. Participants that do not meet the inclusion/exclusion criteria for the study will be excluded at this stage. In total 220 healthy participants will be recruited for the study and randomized to either active treatment arm or placebo arm. The treatment in the study is a daily dose of whey protein powder which includes omega 3 phospholipids. Participants will take the powder by drinking as a beverage. The intervention will start after a screening visit and last for 12 weeks. Participants allocated in the treatment group on top of consuming the protein powder will be asked to consume a drink once daily with it. The group allocated to the placebo will be required to consume a drink daily containing pea protein and not including omega 3 phospholipids. The active supplement will cost £65.80 (60 sachets) for Participants. The placebo supplement will cost £51.50 (50 sachets) for Participants. The supplements have no side effects and participants will be assessed twice before the screening and twice after the screening during a follow up. The assessments will take place within a 2-week period for each phase. A visit timeline has been provided in the study and the study timeline in Figure 1. All participants must attend an online meeting prior to the screening visit to discuss any aspects of the requirements of the study such as what they are expected to do. Participants will be invited to enter the study and given an explanation of why the research team wanted to use them as participants. If the participants agree to take part in the study, they will be asked to sign an Informed Consent Form and given a link to the survey to book in their screening visit. This visit they will be invited to undertake the computerised cognitive tasks. Participants must achieve the minimum scores for each cognitive domain on the computerised battery, to be eligible to remain in the study. In addition, participants must achieve a score of ≥5 in each of the individual computerised cognitive tasks to meet eligibility for cognitive performance. If a participant does not meet the required cognitive eligibility threshold, they will not be enrolled in the study but will be fully reimbursed for their time and given the option of either a high street voucher to thank them for their time and interest or be provided with a link to an online survey which will ask them about their reasons for not meeting entry criteria and allow them the option to provide free text comments. Participants meeting all other eligibility criteria for the study will be randomised to either the active or the placebo intervention. Participants will be provided with details of how their supplement is made and what ingredients are in it. Once the randomization has taken place participants will be provided with the name of the treatment they have been allocated to and given a link to the survey to book in their first treatment follow-up visit. This will take place 2 weeks after the screening visit and the treatment will start after the visit, the supplement will come in the post on a weekly basis until they run out. After 6 weeks the participants will attend another follow-up. At this visit, they will be asked to provide another blood sample, and also asked about their opinion of the supplement they were given and asked if they would be prepared to take part in a follow-up cognitive assessment after the treatment phase has ended. They will be given the option to have another online cognitive assessment at home at the end of the supplement phase. This will take place within 2 weeks after the 6 week treatment follow-up. A final follow-up visit will take place at least 3 weeks from the end of the trial supplement. This will give participants the opportunity to learn about their brain health results from the trial and ask any questions. Participants in this trial will be provided with brain health results from the trial. These will be in the form of a report with graphical representations of their performance compared to other participants and a normal age-matched population on each of the following primary outcome measures: Computerised Memory Task Reaction Time, Accuracy, Number of Trials Completed, Percentage Correct

[/INST] The clinical trial "Transarterial Radioembolization (TARE) in COlorectal MEtastasis of Liver" is a phase IV study with the device as the main intervention. The study group included patients with confirmed colorectal cancer metastasis to the liver, treated with radioembolization with Therasphere glass microspheres. The exclusion criteria for this study included: PET-CT, CT or MRI of the liver within the last 6 weeks, lack of imaging follow-up of the liver after radioembolization, and poor-quality images.
