[/INST] The Liver Care Trial is a randomized controlled trial designed to study the impact of liver screening on alcohol use disorder patients. The study allocates participants to either an intervention group, where they are offered liver screening, or a control group, where the screening is avoided. The trial aims to determine the effectiveness of liver screening in reducing alcohol consumption, as well as the uptake of the screening opportunity. The study's primary outcome measure is alcohol abstinence or light consumption (≤ 10 units per week) after six months. The Liver Care Trial is among the first that aims to understand the potential impact of offering liver screening to patients with alcohol use disorder, and therefore is likely to generate important information that will guide the future development of screening programmes. The study also assesses the feasibility of running a liver disease screening programme, including the acceptability and uptake of the offer of screening. The trial is a part of the European ALFA project and is a collaboration between researchers from Germany and Denmark.

[/INST] The study is entitled "Study of the Value of Trio Exome Sequencing in the Etiological Assessment of Specific Non-syndromic Language and Learning Disorders." It is a clinical trial which will include 100 participants with non-syndromic specific language and learning disorders (SLLD). The participants will be required to meet specific inclusion and exclusion criteria to be eligible for participation in the study. The participants will undergo trio exome sequencing to examine their genetic background. Blood samples will be taken as biological material. The participants will also receive a consultation for results delivery and study material on Humanities and Social Sciences. The primary outcome measure will be the identification of a genetic cause defined by the presence of at least one ACMG class 4 or 5 variant. The time frame for this outcome is approximately 4 months through study completion.

[/INST] The Five Days for Health (FDH) is a weight loss program that uses a multidisciplinary team approach to promote lifestyle modifications that lead to weight loss. Participants are encouraged to develop a healthier diet, increase physical activity, receive psychological support, and are educated on various aspects of weight management. The study includes assessments of weight loss, body composition, and metabolic parameters at baseline and during the course of the program. The study has inclusion criteria such as age, BMI, and medical conditions and exclusion criteria such as current enrolment in another weight loss program, regular intake of medications that affect appetite, history of gastric bypass or other weight loss procedures, and pregnancy or plans to become pregnant. The intervention involves a structured five-day lifestyle modification program led by endocrinologists-diabetologists together with a nutritionist, psychologist, and kinesiologist. Evaluation includes an assessment of weight, body composition, and metabolic parameters. The study has limitations in sample size and limited diversity. Overall, this study provides valuable information about the effectiveness of multidisciplinary team-based weight management programs in achieving and maintaining weight loss in individuals with obesity.

[/INST] The article summarizes the clinical trial of Bio-008 in the treatment of patients with advanced or metastatic solid tumors. Bio-008 is a fusion protein consisting of three parts: anti-CLDN18.2 scFv, IL-2, and Fc domain. It was developed to target CLDN18.2 positive tumor cells, bind, and internalize the anti-CLDN18.2 scFv, kill tumor cells, and activate T cells. The clinical trial is a phase I, single-center, open-label study. It tests the safety, pharmacokinetics, and anti-tumor response of seven dose groups of Bio-008 in 91 patients. The results show that the dose, pharmacological characteristics, and anti-tumor response of Bio-008 have good dose-response relationships, and Bio-008 has a potential antitumor effect in various tumors. However, the results also show that the safety of some dose groups also shows a dose-response relationship, so there is a narrow margin of safely used doses and a potential risk of adverse events during treatment. Nevertheless, the results indicate that Bio-008 is safe and has a potential anti-tumor effect, and suggest the potential importance of Bio-008 in anti-tumor treatment. ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT03739704.

[/INST] The aim of the study was to investigate whether music affects premature baby's pain, comfort, oxygen saturation and heart rate. Therefore; pain, comfort, oxygen saturation and heart rate were examined using music methods, the rainstick and the Happiest Baby® music, and audiotape. The study used randomized-controlled trial design and infants with ROP examination were enrolled. The intervention was music, which is classified into four groups; (1) music therapy method (the rainstick), (2) music therapy method (The Happiest Baby® music audiotape), (3) music with the audiotape and (4) no music audiotape during retinopathy examination, and there was no music before or after. The outcomes are premature infants' pain (using PIPP), comfort and crying (using PBIC), and oxygen saturation and heart rate with the pulse oximeter at the baseline and 3 and 120 minutes after. It was observed that intervention music significantly decreased pain scores compared to the control music-free group (P < 0.001). The method was also found to significantly increase comfort scores in the intervention group. Music during retinopathy significantly increased oxygen saturation in premature infants (P < 0.001). Music decreased maximum heart rate and increased minimum heart rate (P < 0.001).

It will be conducted in multiple countries. This study will help address and fill the unmet needs in the treatment of ischemic stroke by investigating a new agent that promotes neuroprotection and vessel repair. This study will also investigate the tolerability and safety of the drug in patients with cerebral ischemic stroke.

The researchers will use structured interviews and self-reported questionnaires for assessments. A Cox Proportional Hazard Model will be used to analyze the influencing factors of remission of borderline personality disorder, and a Generalized Estimating Equation Model will be used to analyze the influencing factors of the patients' social function and quality of life.

[/INST] This trial aims to compare two different mental health interventions, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) versus mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT), to improve patient-centered mental health outcomes, quality of life, well-being, and functional impairment among autistic adults with co-occurring anxiety and/or depressive disorders. These outcomes will be measured at baseline, post-treatment (18 weeks), and at 3, 6, and 12-month follow-up periods. Other outcomes of interest include participant satisfaction with the treatment, their satisfaction with the therapy provider, satisfaction with the intervention, and negative effects of the intervention.

[/INST] Methotrexate for Immune Related Arthritis or Arthralgias is a clinical trial that examines the efficacy and safety of using methotrexate for treating inflammatory arthritis or arthralgias in patients with cancer who have received immunotherapy. The study includes a total of four eligibility criteria. The first two criteria are related to the type of inflammatory arthritis patients must have experienced, such as grade ≥ 2 irAA or arthralgia, which is thought to be related to immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy. The third eligibility criterion includes the demographics of the participant, who must be 18 years of age or older. The fourth eligibility criterion is the clinical factors of the participant, which states that those with any condition that would hamper compliance with the study protocol and follow-up schedule are ineligible for the trial. Patients can be enrolled if they have developed arthralgia with the history of inflammatory arthritis, they are older than 18 years, or they do not have any conditions that would hamper compliance with the trial. The study arm of the trial involves patients receiving prednisone with methotrexate for 12 weeks. The primary endpoints and secondary endpoints of the trial include the proportion of patients who could discontinue prednisone by 12 weeks without experiencing recurrence grade 2 or higher irAA, cumulative dose of prednisone utilized, development of irAEs not present at baseline, adverse effects of irAEs, re-treatment with cancer immunotherapy, and progression-free survival.

[/INST] In this study, we evaluated the difference in sleep quality in elderly patients who underwent total hip arthroplasty surgery under general or regional anesthesia. Sleep quality was evaluated using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) questionnaire. 20 patients were randomized to a general anesthesia group and 20 to a regional anesthesia group. All patients were monitored preoperatively, intraoperatively, and postoperatively in terms of potential complications. Sleep quality was evaluated on the night before surgery, one day after, and one week after surgery. Patients who underwent surgery under regional anesthesia had better sleep quality than patients who underwent surgery under general anesthesia regardless of when the sleep quality was evaluated.

Participants will receive atogepant once daily for 24 weeks, and the primary outcome measure is the change in mean monthly migraine days from baseline to the end of the study. The study is expected to be completed by July 2024.

Each patient rated their pain on a scale of 0 to 10. 0 means “no pain” and 10 means “worst possible pain”. HA35 injections have the potential to treat painful conditions at multiple sites, including back pain. They are also effective in treating herpes zoster pain. Overall, 35kDa Hyaluronan fragment HA35 injection is a potential treatment option for patients with complex pain conditions, such as back and herpes zoster.

[/INST] The study is titled "The Effect of Bicarbonate Profiling in Dialysis Fluid on Phosphate Removal During Hemodialysis and Blood pH" and is considered a non-randomized controlled trial. Hemodialysis patients were randomized into four groups: Group 1 received Dbic at 35 mmol/L during hemodialysis for four weeks, and then a four-week washout period. After another four-week treatment, it received constant Dbic at 30 mmol/L. Group 2 received Dbic at 35 mmol/L for four weeks, then four weeks with Dbic at 30 mmol/L, and then a four-week washout period. After that, it received Dbic at 35 mmol/L for four weeks. The aim of the study is to evaluate the efficacy of different bicarbonate concentrations in dialysate on phosphate clearance, blood pH, and concentration of bicarbonate in blood and dialysate during dialysis. The results show that there was no difference between the groups in terms of removing ions such as phosphate and calcium, and the effect of treatment did not change with the change in Dbic. There were also no differences between groups in terms of sodium removal or acid-base balance. The data suggests that there are no significant differences in the efficacy of removing ions or acid-base balance based on the concentration of bicarbonate used in the dialysate. More studies would need to be conducted to confirm the results.

However, the exact details of the outcome measures have yet to be established. [/INST] In this prospective, randomized controlled trial, 2 methods of capitate and radial shortening for the treatment of Avascular Necrosis of the lunate were compared. Capitate shortening was done in the supine position with a dorsal mid-lateral approach and using Herpert screws for compression. Radial shortening was done with Henry approach and a small DCP or small T plate for fixation. Both approaches resulted in improved (Modified) Mayo wrist scores and better range of motion, with radial shortening being associated with less wrist pain and better hand grip strength. Capitate shortening may thus be a better option than radial shortening in treating stage II and stage III lunate avascular nerosis.

[/INST] A clinical trial proposed by Vie et al.  in the context of prosthesis dysfunctions will study a cohort of patients (50 knees, hips, and shoulders) with knee, hip, or shoulder joint prosthetic infections after at least one-month symptoms. These patients will undergo joint aspiration, during which blood will be drawn and biomarker levels measured (mainly CRP levels). The fluid collected during joint aspiration will also be analyzed through different methods to determine bacteriological samples and leukocyte counts. The analysis of these three methods (clinical diagnosis, blood biomarker analysis, and joint aspiration) will allow researchers to assess their respective concordances and study the diagnostic accuracy of these methods. Based on the results of joint aspiration, patients in this study will have two different classifications: a primary classification into groups of “suspected infection,” “doubtful infection,” and “uninfected” and a secondary classification into groups of “infected,” “doubtful infection,” and “uninfected.”

[/INST] The aim of the study is to assess the airway dysfunction in cystic fibrosis patients using 19F MRI. The study utilizes a combination of dynamic 19F MRI and dynamic D2O MRI to evaluate the airways of cystic fibrosis patients and assess changes over a 14-day period. [/INST] The study is titled "A Bioequivalence Trial of Fasting Single Oral STI-1558 Capsule in Healthy Chinese Subjects". The study involves a randomized, open-label, two-sequence, single-dose, double-blind, two-period crossover design. The primary objective of the study is to determine the relative oral bioavailability of a drug called STI-1558. The study involves 32 eligible healthy Chinese subjects who were divided into two groups. One group received STI-1558 and the other group received the reference preparation. All subjects were randomly assigned to the intervention group in a 1:1 ratio. The study consisted of a screening period, a single-dose period and a follow-up period. The primary outcome measures were the maximum observed concentration (Cmax), area under the curve from 0 to last time point (AUC0-t), and area under the curve from time 0 to infinity (AUC0-inf). The secondary outcome measures were the time to reach the maximum plasma concentration (Tmax), half-life (t1/2), absolute bioavailability (%F), pre-systemic metabolism (%ex), mean residence time (MRT), clearance (CL/F), and the volume of distribution (V⁢z/F). Subjects who completed the study were discharged on day 10 and followed up or visited on day 14 of the study. No abnormalities were reported, and no adverse events occurred during the study period. The study was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the International Conference Harmonization Guidelines for Good Clinical Practice. The manuscript has the following limitations: a) it is not clear whether the statistical significance of the clinical trial data; b) whether the study was sufficiently randomized and adequately blinded; c) whether the statistical methods used in the study were adequate; d) whether all important data are reported in the manuscript; e) the risk of bias associated with the study, including allocation concealment, blinding, and attrition bias. The randomization and blinding of the study were based on a random number generated using a computer system, and therefore minimized the risk of selection and detection bias. In addition, the authors of the manuscript did not indicate any dropout or missing data during the course of the study. It is therefore unknown whether there was any reporting bias in the study.

[/INST] The abstract of this study discussed the effectiveness of detachment of the breathing circuit on the rate of DLT (double-lumen endotracheal tube) malposition after a change of position in patients undergoing thoracic surgery. The study was designed as a prospective, double-blind, randomized controlled study with two arms. The primary outcome was DLT malposition, which was defined as at least 5 mm away from the optimal endobronchial tube position. The secondary outcomes included the effects of lung collapse, oxygen saturation, and length of stay in the PACU. Participants were patients undergoing elective thoracic surgery requiring a left-sided DLT under general anesthesia who provided informed consent and complied with the inclusion/exclusion criteria. The study found that detaching the breathing circuit at the point of change of position in patients undergoing thoracoscopic surgery had a lower rate of DLT malposition.

[/INST] The aim of the study is to investigate the efficacy of the Diabetes Support Group intervention for families of children with recently diagnosed type 1 diabetes. The Diabetes Support Group is a 6-month intervention to improve family-reported outcomes such as diabetes-related distress. The study includes a six-month active intervention and a two-year follow-up phase after the end of the intervention period. The study design is a two-group randomized controlled trial (RCT) with a waitlist control group. The study will start in 2016 and will be completed at the end of 2019, including data analysis and follow-up phase. The study population will comprise families of children with type 1 diabetes, who have been diagnosed within one year prior to enrollment. Participants will be required to have a medical diagnosis of diabetes, and to have a stable living arrangement. The study will evaluate the efficacy of the intervention in terms of perceived health status, medical decision-making, and satisfaction with medical care. The study will also evaluate the efficacy of the intervention in terms of quality of life and diabetes-related distress. The study will assess the relationship between quality of life and medical care satisfaction with perceived health status over time. The study will also examine factors that influence perceived health status at baseline, and test the intervention’s effects on diabetes-specific distress over time.

[/INST] The CRATOS trial is a single-group study aimed at evaluating the clinical and safety outcomes of the Cratos stent graft used for descending aorta pathologies, including aortic dissection, intramural hematoma, or penetrating aortic ulcer. The inclusion criteria for the trial involve patients between the ages of 18 and 85, with an aortic dissection from the ascending aorta to the descending aorta, and a length of at least 2 cm without aortic dissections. Additionally, patients must be legally authorized to provide informed consent for participation in the trial. The exclusion criteria include patients with an aortic dissection, aneurysm, or aortic malformation involving either the abdominal aorta or the aortic arch requiring graft replacement, and patients with prior aortic surgery within 30 days prior to enrollment. Patients must not have a coexisting aortic aneurysm that would require concomitant replacement and the ascending aorta cannot be replaced simultaneously. Patients with a life expectancy of less than one year, a history of a degenerative connective tissue disease, or significant tortuosity or stenosis in the iliac or femoral arteries that would prevent introducer sheath placement and subsequent vascular access with a conduit are also not eligible for the trial.

[/INST] The study aims to compare two techniques for ultrasound-guided lumbar plexus block, the Trident technique and the Shamrock technique. For the Shamrock technique, the projection of C line (line obtained by the probe placed on the iliac crest) was noted with invisible ink pen. Then the probe was oriented cephalically (for line greater than C) and caudally (line less than C) on the costiform processes. For each lines, the quality of image, the depth of lumbar plexus and the presence of vessels were also noted [Image 1, Image 2]. The projection of C, >C, <C on the costiform processes were noted [Image 1, Image 2].

[/INST] OPTI - DOSE is a pilot clinical trial testing if lower starting dose of orally administered anticancer drugs is a safe option in elderly patients. The participants will be started on the highest safe dose of monotherapy with pazopanib, olaparib, lenvatinib, sunitinib, or palbociclib, and it will be lowered for up to 4 weeks, if necessary, until reaching the lowest possible safe starting dose. Dose-reduction schedule is inversely fixed to every two weeks (every four weeks for palbociclib). Every two weeks (every four weeks for palbociclib), efficacy, safety, pharmacokinetics, and patients’ reported outcomes will be assessed. The pilot clinical trial will last 48 weeks.

[/INST] The study in question is a pragmatic randomized controlled trial aimed at investigating the effects of the facility- and community-based models of depression treatment. Both models use a psychological treatment of high intensity with evidence-based therapy delivered by trained mental health workers and community members. They are then compared to an effective low-intensity treatment (active comparator), and the effects of these interventions are assessed through reduction in depression severity and improvement in symptoms. Contact coverage, effect coverage, and sustainability are also evaluated, and the results of the study may lead to improved access to depression care in rural and remote communities. There is a study from India conducted in 2018 which studied the cost-effectiveness and impact of community-based models of depression treatment and found high costs associated with the community-based treatment compared to the mental health worker-based treatment, but increased reach and reduction to population disability . The cost-effectiveness of community-based intervention is an important area to study further, and this study may shed light on the feasibility of using community volunteers and their impact on the outcome of the treatment.

[/INST] The study is a phase II multicenter study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of mosunetuzumab in treating follicular lymphoma that has relapsed or progressed during or within two years after receiving first-line treatment. The primary objective of the study is to compare the progression-free survival (PFS) among patients who receive mosunetuzumab therapy, to those who received rituximab and bendamustine or rituximab alone in their first line treatment, within 24 months of starting first line treatment. PFS is defined as the time from the beginning of the study treatment to the first documented disease progression or death of any cause, whichever occurred first. Rituximab and bendamustine or rituximab alone are considered the standard first-line treatments for follicular lymphoma. Mosunetuzumab is a novel bispecific T-cell engaging antibody that binds to CD20 on lymphoma cells and CD3 on T-cells, thereby activating cytotoxic T lymphocytes to kill CD20 positive lymphoma cells. The secondary objectives of the study include assessing the overall response rate (ORR), complete response rate (CRR), duration of response (DOR), time to new lymphoma treatment (TTNT), overall survival (OS), and safety and tolerability of mosunetuzumab in patients with POD24. The study also focuses on identifying prognostic indicators of efficacy, such as 18F-FDG-PET-CT response, to determine whether transformation to high-grade lymphoma will occur in patients with a POD24 event and mosunetuzumab treatment. Additionally, the study seeks to identify prognostic indicators of response to identify patients at higher risk for progressive disease and provide the rationale for combination therapies with novel targeted agents, immunotherapy, and/or cellular therapy. The target population of the study is adult patients with a current POD24 event due to follicular lymphoma. A sample size of 60 patients will be recruited and followed-up for at least 2 to a minimum of 5 years. The study design includes a follow-up period of 2.5-5 years depending on when the last participant's minimum follow-up ends. The study will not involve any new participants after patient recruitment is completed.

[/INST] This study is a phase I/II trial of two drugs, PLX2853 and trametinib, in the treatment of advanced uveal melanoma. The drug PLX2853 is a selective inhibitor of the BET protein family, which regulates genes involved in the regulation of cell growth, development, and differentiation. Trametinib is a small molecule inhibitor of MEK that is involved in the MAPK pathway, which regulates multiple cellular processes including cell growth, proliferation, differentiation, and survival. The primary objective is to determine the recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of the drugs to evaluate efficacy and safety. The trial will be conducted in two phases: a phase I dose escalation and a phase II expansion cohort. In both phases, the participants will be given PLX2853 and trametinib as combined therapy. The dose escalation of the study will involve a dose escalation design with the aim of determining the RP2D. The primary endpoint of the study is to determine the MTDs of the study drugs as a combination therapy. Other secondary objectives include the assessment of the safety and tolerability of the study drugs, response rate (RR), progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), efficacy, pharmacokinetics of the study drugs, evaluation of the biomarkers and pathologic responses to the study, and adverse events.

[/INST] This is a clinical trial investigating the effectiveness of a new model of care implementation strategy compared to usual care in patients who have not reached their LDL-target. The study will compare a new model of care implementation strategy with usual care in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) or ASCVD-risk equivalent for lipid management. Participants will be randomized to either a Usual Care Arm or a Model of Care Arm. The Model of Care Arm will encompass the following components: 1) education on ESC guidelines and Guideline Directed Management therapy (GDMT); 2) monthly short message service (SMS) based on LDL-C goals, and a reminder text message regarding their appointment; 3) telephone-based support calls from a study nurse trained in motivational interviewing, which will cover diet, exercise, medication, and where necessary smoking cessation. A summary of any recommendations will be sent to the primary care physician via email or letter. Both groups will have access to inclusionisiran at the treating physician's discretion. The overall study duration will be 365 days and data will be collected at baseline, 180 days, and 365 days. The primary outcome will be the LDL-C concentration at 180 days between the two arms. Secondary outcomes will be the LDL-C concentration at 365 days, and other measures related to LDL-C management such as medication adherence, self-efficacy, health-related quality of life, knowledge, and health service utilization (both for lipid-related and for non-lipid-related issues).

It should include the main objective, the type of clinical trial, the study population (the number of patients and their baseline characteristics), the intervention, the primary outcomes and their measures, key secondary outcomes, the main study design features (number of treatment arms, sample size, data collection schedule and data collection methods), key inclusion and exclusion criteria, participant timeline, key outcome measures, key study design issues and ethical concerns, main statistical methods of data analysis. [/INST] The study's title is "ACT for Healthy Living: a Brief Acceptance and Commitment Therapy Intervention for Women With Obesity." It is a randomized controlled trial designed to evaluate a brief intervention called "ACT Workshop." The ACT workshop is a behavioral intervention that teaches acceptance and commitment therapy skills to approach healthy living. The study will enroll 70 women with obesity and examine the changes in psychological flexibility, valued living, stress tolerance, and weight self-stigma seven days and one month after the ACT workshop. The primary outcome measures are the Acceptance and Action Questionnaire for Weight-Related Difficulties, Distress Tolerance Scale, and Valued Living Questionnaire. The secondary outcome measures are the Weight Self-Stigma Questionnaire, Emotional Eating Scale, Body Shape Questionnaire, International Physical Activity Questionnaire-Short Form, Rapid Eating Assessment for Participants-Shortened Version, and participant weight. This study aims to evaluate the effect of the ACT workshop as a weight management program and as a weight self-stigma reduction program. The results will provide evidence for the efficacy of the program and guide its future implementation.

Inclusion criteria involved patients ages 3-18 who met diagnostic criteria for HSP and involved the gastrointestinal tract with abdominal colic and/or gasto-intestinal bleeding, refractory gastrointestinal HSP defined as patients who were treated with high-dose IV corticosteroid 2mg/kg/day for 3days without efficacy or had relapses during the attenuation of IV corticosteroid treatment. The outcome measures included count of red blood cells in stool. The trial was designed as single-arm clinical trial and used open label. The treatment arm was MMF given 15mg/kg/day two times per day with a 4-week maintenance treatment for patients who responded to the induction treatment. Based on previous studies, this study was done to assess the efficacy and safety of MMF as a steroid sparing agent in refractory gastrointestinal HSP. Based on this retrospective study, MMF can be used to treat refractory gastrointestinal HSP and no serious adverse events have been reported in this study. This study provides information on the efficacy and safety of MMF in refractory HSP.

[/INST] The study is titled "Electroencephalogram (EEG) Enhanced Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (eTMS) for Chronic Trauma and Stressor-Related Disorders (TSRD) (ETMS for Stress)" and aims to assess the safety, feasibility, and preliminary efficacy of adjunctive eTMS treatment for chronic TSRD in a proof-of-concept clinical trial. The study proposes to test a non-invasive device that simultaneously measures EEG activity and delivers focused magnetic pulses (Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation; TMS). The device provides customized TMS parameters based on real-time EEG analysis. The study's primary objective is to enroll 30 patients to assess the safety and feasibility of eTMS as an adjunctive treatment for patients with chronic TSRD, and an interim analysis will be performed after data collection at 6 weeks. If safety benchmarks are reached, the study will recruit an additional 270 participants for an 18-month clinical trial to assess the feasibility, efficacy, and safety of eTMS treatment for chronic TSRD. The study's primary outcome is the rate of device-related serious adverse events (SAE's) and total number of participants with eTMS-related SAE's or unexpected device-related SAE's during treatment. The study also proposes to measure the rate of participants who complete 80% of eTMS visits and the mean change in the mental component summary scores on the Veterans RAND 36-item Health Survey Mental Component Scores (MCS). The study's secondary outcome is to assess the feasibility and efficacy of 6 weeks of eTMS treatment for chronic TSRD.

[/INST] A retrospective study of radiotherapy combined with EGFR-TKI for stage III EGFR mutant lung cancer patients. Patients included must have been diagnosed with lung cancer by pathology, have an EGFR mutation type confirmed by genetic testing, and be in accordance with the international eighth edition of TNM stage stage IIIA-IIIC. Patients with combined surgery or chemotherapy were excluded. The test group received radiotherapy + EGFR-TKI combined therapy. Radiotherapy includes 3DCRT or IMRT, using 54-66 Gy/27-33 f as the prescribed dose, plus EGFR-TKI therapy, and different EGFR-TKI drugs were: gefitinib 250 mg orally once daily, erlotinib 125 mg orally three times a day, erlotinib 150 mg orally once daily, oseltinib 80 mg orally once daily, and ametinib 110 mg orally once daily. EGFR-TKI + RT therapy was taken until disease progression or intolerability. The primary endpoint of the study was progression-free survival, which is measured from the time of treatment to the first instance of documented progressive disease or death. The study is retrospective in nature and the quality of evidence is low.

[/INST] The research “Identifying the Microorganisms Responsible for Acute Head and Neck Infections” is a study designed to determine the specific microorganisms that are associated with acute head and neck infections. The data collected include the identification of streptococci species using DNA analysis of ribosomal ribonucleic acid (rRNA) genes and biochemical testing, patient demographic information (age, sex, and infection site), and clinical outcomes (length of hospital stay, antibiotic treatment, and diabetic diagnosis). This study aims to evaluate the microorganisms associated with acute head and neck infections and determine the common traits of patients with a specific infection. The results of the study may improve the diagnosis and treatment of head and neck infections. The study has the potential to provide a better understanding of head and neck infections and contribute to the advancement of medical knowledge.

[/INST] This study evaluated the use of artificial tears to prevent the post-radiotherapy nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO). [/INST] The ACHIEVE Initiative is a project aimed at improving maternal health outcomes in pregnant people in North Carolina. The initiative consists of three multi-component implementation strategies: training, coaching, and facilitation, that aim to support the implementation of an outpatient hypertension bundle in 20 rural clinics. The study will use a pre-post intervention design and measure the impact of the intervention on care through the Normalized Percentage, which will be determined by the number of times the desired action is taken, divided by the total possible number of times the desired action could feasibly be taken (n/N) multiplied by 100. Normalized Percentage scores are then translated into a normalized percentage (0-100) for ease of interpretation. Specific outcome measures include blood pressure measurement technique, patient education on hypertension, recognition and response to simulated episodes of severe hypertension, and recognition and response to actual episodes of severe hypertension. The target population consists of patients with severe hypertension, so data will be collected from 20 clinics which have 50 or more pregnancies per year and are primarily serving uninsured or NC Medicaid populations and patients of Black/African American or rural descent. Patient education on hypertension will be based on a standardized patient education handout and delivered by the patient care team to pregnant women with hypertension during at least 2 prenatal care visits or within a few days of hospital admission, whichever occurs first. The handout will either be delivered 1-on-1 by the provider, to a group of patients together, online or by phone. There will be a focus on assessing the impact of the intervention on recognition and response to simulated episodes of severe hypertension by the care team, to ensure that staff feel comfortable handling blood pressure changes when they occur, which in turn will facilitate the improvement of the recognition of severe hypertension in pregnant people. The intervention will be implemented over a 12-month period (September 2021 to August 2022). All data will be measured before and after the intervention, with measurements taken continuously over 48 months. The primary outcome measure for this study is the Normalized percentage of achieving the highest possible score for blood pressure measurement technique, which is derived from an observation checklist with a maximum score of 11. The patient population is described as the pregnant population of North Carolina, with a focus on people with severe hypertension. The ACHIEVE Initiative is a promising intervention that targets outpatient care, which is an important area for improvement as most pregnant people receive the majority of their healthcare in outpatient settings. It is essential to improve the care received by pregnant people in these settings to reduce the incidence of severe outcomes. The study has a clear and measurable objective and data will be collected using multiple methods and measures. The study focuses on the delivery of patient education, and it is encouraging to see this aspect of care being examined. Overall, the study design is well executed and has the potential to make an impact.

[/INST] The trial aimed to test the effectiveness of message loss or gain, or the loss and gain of alcohol use, on reducing weekly alcohol consumption in older adults over a period of 8 weeks. Participants were randomly assigned to three groups, including control or placebo in parallel. Weekly alcohol intake was measured with a web-based drinking diary, which was conducted 8 times in total (baseline, week 10, week 20, and week 28). In addition, text messages were sent eight times a week, and participants were asked to respond to those messages. The researchers also collected other data such as age, sex, marital status, education level, and medical history of the participants at baseline.

[/INST] This study is evaluating the safety of a radioligand, 18F-Fluselenamyl, in eight to ten participants. Healthy participants and participants with mild cognitive impairment of Alzheimer's dementia will be injected with a single intravenous bolus injection of 10 mCi ± 20% of the investigational radiotracer 18F-Fluselenamyl. PET/CT images (skull vertex to proximal thighs) will be obtained immediately following intravenous (IV) injection. The primary objective is to evaluate the biodistribution, kinetics and calculate human dosimetry of this radioligand. PET imaging will also be conducted to assess the sensitivity of [18F]-Fluselenamyl to image amyloid beta in participants with mild cognitive impairment of Alzheimer's dementia and conduct comparative analysis of PET imaging data using [11C]-PIB imaging in the same participants.

[/INST] Long-term Effect of TMS in Primary Progressive Aphasia is the title of an upcoming clinical trial. This is a comparison of a randomized trial. This trial will compare two interventions, namely, "TMS" and "behavioral therapy." Aphasia is the most common speech and language disorder and is a prominent symptom of both frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and Alzheimer's disease (AD), the two most prevalent types of primary dementia. PPA is a clinical disorder that develops gradually, causing language difficulties. The purpose of the research is to examine whether the primary target of TMS over the prefrontal cortex will result in language enhancement over time. The primary outcome employed in measuring brain metabolism. Language assessment, daily-living activities, and neuropsychiatric symptoms are secondary outcomes.

[/INST] A randomized, placebo-controlled trial was conducted to investigate the efficacy of immunosuppression therapy in patients with post-COVID-19 syndrome and cognitive deficits. The study aimed to assess the improvement in memory satisfaction as measured by the Multifactorial Memory Questionnaire (MMQ) and neurocognitive function as measured by the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA). Additionally, measures of self-perception of the memory were assessed by the “memory ability” and “memory strategy” subscales of the MMQ were used to assess memory ability and memory strategy, respectively. Changes in memory from baseline to weeks 8, 20, and 52 between the Methylprednisolone and the placebo groups (primary endpoint). Changes in the MMQ and all secondary outcomes in the Methylprednisolone and placebo groups were analyzed. The study concluded that patients with post-COVID-19 syndrome and cognitive deficits treated by oral Methylprednisolone showed significant improvement in memory satisfaction and mood from baseline to weeks 8, 20, and 52, compared to the placebo group, indicating the efficacy of Methylprednisolone as a therapeutic option for post-COVID-19 syndrome. Participants in the study were middle-aged, so the efficacy of Methylprednisolone as a therapeutic option for post-COVID-19 syndrome for older age groups remain unclear, suggesting the need for further research.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial to investigate the aetiological factors of malnutrition. The study is using a total of 62 patients who meet the inclusion criteria for malnutrition. Three of the arms of this study are intervention: two involving administration of olive oil polyphenol supplements, which is expected to reduce inflammation, and one involving administration of omega-3 fatty acid supplements, which is expected to improve protein synthesis. The study will collect clinical data (including anthropometry, body composition, blood biochemistry, bioimpedance, functional status, oral intake, and oral health) at baseline, 1 month, and 3 months. The primary outcome measures include albumin, prealbumin, c-reactive protein, and nutritional status. The secondary outcome measures include measures of appetite, nutritional intake, blood biochemistry, biomass, functional analysis, and inflammatory markers.

[/INST] The KP ENRICH study is a randomized controlled trial to examine the effects of financial incentives for buying healthy food on glycemic control in food-insecure adults with diabetes. Participants are at-risk adult patients with type 2 diabetes and food insecurity who are assigned to one of two groups: the control group or the intervention group. The control group receives monthly financial incentives worth $25, which they can apply to buy any food from Instacart, a grocery delivery service. The intervention group receives monthly financial incentives worth $55, which they can only apply to buy healthy food (fruits, vegetables, and nuts) from Instacart. They also receive free home grocery delivery for up to 4 months in addition to the financial incentives. The study will assess the effect of the intervention on glycemic control, food security, nutrition security, dietary habits, diabetes-related quality of life, and readiness to change dietary habits.

[/INST] The Esbjerg Cohort is a cross-sectional study that aims to investigate how ergonomic exposure in relation to physical capacity has an effect on work ability and musculoskeletal pain in 55-70 year old workers. [/INST] We conducted a small-scale pilot study, which was based on noninterventional study data regarding patients with advanced breast cancer. The study involved patients with breast cancer who were between 18 and 75 years old. The study was conducted in France. The primary objective was to analyze the number of patients with PIK3CA mutations and to describe each patient's path from diagnosis to treatment. The secondary objectives were to characterize patients with PIK3CA mutations based on mutation type and source of testing, treatment sequence, and the effect of prior treatment on overall survival. The study concluded that 23% of the patients' tumors had at least one potentially actionable mutation, and 8% had a PIK3CA mutation. In another study, the PIK3CA mutation rate of advanced breast cancer was 13%. This study confirms previous studies regarding PIK3CA mutation type, and it further supports the use of PIK3CA mutation-targeted treatment. In addition, it emphasizes the importance of PIK3CA mutation testing in patients who are HER2-negative with metastatic breast cancer. The study provided valuable information about the different treatment sequence options, including the treatment sequence of patients with PIK3CA mutations. However, due to the limited size and the non-interventional nature of the study, the generalizability of the findings may be limited. Future research is required to validate these findings and to understand the best treatment sequences for patients with PIK3CA mutations.

[/INST] The study "Examining the Effects of Melatonin on Sleep Spindles in Children with Autism" by L. Liu and J Zhang from China, was performed to study the effect of melatonin on sleep spindles in children with and without autism spectrum disorder. The study was carried out as a pilot study and included five participants (three male and two female) aged 12-18 years old, including three children with ASD (two male and one female) and two typically developing children (one female). Each participant underwent a baseline night of sleep, and then melatonin was administered 30 minutes before bedtime for two consecutive nights. The study found that children with ASD had lower sleep spindle densities compared to those in the control group, though these results were not statistically significant. The researchers conclude that melatonin has the potential to improve sleep spindles in children with ASD, but further studies are required to confirm these findings.

[/INST] The DETERMiN8 umbrella trial is an important multicenter, open-label, single-arm, phase IB/IIA trial that will provide a clearer understanding of the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab and pertuzumab in molecularly defined paediatric and young adult cancer patients with solid tumours, or haematological malignancies, that harbor HER2 alterations, irrespective of the tumour cell line of origin. The trial's design, interventions, comparisons, and outcome measures make it unique and suitable for assessing the efficacy, safety, and other outcomes related to trastuzumab and pertuzumab in rare oncology cancers that have limited clinical data. By evaluating paediatric, young adult, and adult patients with HER2-positive cancer, the DETERMiN8 trial will provide information on treatment efficacy in terms of objective response rates, progression-free survival, overall survival, and disease control rates. The trial will also address safety outcomes related to hematological, gastrointestinal, and other side effects related to trastuzumab and pertuzumab. Moreover, the trial will generate real-world evidence that can aid in the development of cost-effective treatment regimens for HER2-positive patients. The DETERMiN8 trial will also generate a repository of samples suitable for pharmacogenetic analysis, molecular diagnostics refinement, and development of response evaluation criteria.

[/INST] A 6-month observational study to determine the microbiome signature associated with asthma severity and treatment response. Participants will be divided into two groups: a naïve asthma group (not on biologics) and a biologics group (on biologics). The two groups will undergo a comprehensive health assessment and collection of background patient data prior to the 6-month monitoring period where asthma severity and treatment response will be assessed. Sampling of biofluids and biomaterials from the respiratory tract of participants will also be done, providing insights into the respiratory microbiome. A detailed analysis of these samples will be performed using multiple-omics technology and an integrative approach.

[/INST] The study protocol titled "Comparing Split-Body and Full-Body Resistance Training in Amateur Cricket Players" is a randomized controlled trial that investigates the effects of split and full-body resistance training on strength and functional performance in amateur cricket players. The study encompasses a sample size of 30 individuals who are male cricket players, between 20 and 30 years of age, with no significant health issues and no history of strength training. The intervention period is six weeks, and the exercise program consists of three non-consecutive days of training each week. The study primary outcome measures are the one-repetition-maximum (1-RM) bench press test and leg press test. The study's results may help athletes, coaches, and fitness professionals in choosing effective resistance training programs for physical performance in amateur cricket players.

[/INST] This clinical trial evaluates the effect of giving breastfeeding education to fathers on parent-baby bonding, breastfeeding self-efficacy, and breastfeeding initiation. The results show that the intervention group with both parents was effective in parent-infant bonding and breastfeeding self-efficacy, but not effective in breastfeeding initiation. However, the effects of breastfeeding education on parent-infant bonding and breastfeeding self-efficacy were maintained.

[/INST] This protocol addresses the urgent need to reduce risky alcohol and drug use and sexual risk behaviors among young women in the southern U.S. The population will consist of young women presenting for care in reproductive health clinics across a large network of health centers in the South. The project incorporates implementation science methods to create and test new strategies for integrating alcohol and substance use, sexual risk reduction, and violence screening and intervention into the clinical environment of women's health. The study builds on several lines of research including the extant literature on best practices in patient-centered alcohol use intervention, current approaches to implementation of alcohol screening and interventions in various clinical settings, and the growing body of research examining strategies for integrating evidence-based practices into various primary care and clinical settings. The study addresses a gap related to implementing screening and effective brief interventions in primary care and women's health settings.

[/INST] The most informative summary of this clinical trial is as follows: 44 participants with overweight and normal weight were randomized in a parallel four-armed study to drink three cups (200 ml/cup) daily of tea bags, containing two different herbal blends (rhubarb root and senna, green tea and senna, green tea, and rhubarb root,) vs. placebo tea (with chamomile and mint). Participants were in the age range of 50 and 70 years and the trial lasted 21 days. The primary outcome of the study was LDL-C, HDL-C, triglycerides, LDL-C: HDL-C, LDL-C: TC, Non-HDL-C, TC: HDL-C, triglyceride TC: HDL-C, glucose as blood markers of metabolic health. The secondary outcome was dietary score for diet quality. The authors conducted repeated-measurements analyses for blood markers and linear mixed models for diet quality scores to test their hypotheses (H0: there is no change in diet or blood markers associated with metabolic health because of the tea intervention; H1: there is change in diet or blood markers associated with metabolic health because of the tea intervention). For diet quality scores, they found no effect of the tea in the three intervention groups vs. placebo (p = 0.062, p = 0.057, p = 0.089). Regarding blood markers, the authors found no effect of the tea in rhubarb root vs. placebo (TC: HDL-C: p = 0.600, TC: HDL-C: p = 0.779, TC: HDL-C: p = 0.600, Non-HDL/HDL p value = 0.054, LDL/HDL p value = 0.023; LDL/C p = 0.850). However, the three-week tea interventions were enough to cause the senna tea group to have significantly lower LDL-C: HDL-C (p = 0.007), LDL-C: TC p = 0.013, and TC: HDL-C (p = 0.030) and higher LDL/C ratio vs. placebo (p = 0.004, p = 0.003, p = 0.047). Regarding the green tea interventions, these were able to cause an increase in TG p = 0.024 and TC: HDL-C (p = 0.026) vs. placebo and also to lower the triglyceride levels vs senna tea (p = 0.009). On the other hand, rhubarb-root interventions caused a significantly higher glucose level vs. placebo (p = 0.048). Therefore, in a nutshell, senna tea and green tea were beneficial for lipid markers linked to metabolic health while rhubarb root and green tea reduced glucose levels compared to placebo.

[/INST] Effect of strengthening activities for external rotators of hip and ankle muscles for knee osteoarthritis will be studied. 180 patients will be divided into two groups: control and experimental, and each group will be 90. In the control group, only quadriceps strengthening and strengthening of hamstring and calf muscles will be done. In the experimental group, quadriceps strengthening, strengthening of hamstring and calf muscles, strengthening of external rotators of hip and ankle muscles will be performed. [/INST] The provided trial report describes a clinical trial named “A Clinical Study to Evaluate the Safety and Effectiveness of Novabel Bioabsorbable Steroid-releasing Stent for the Chronic Sinusitis”. Participants in this randomized double blind study were recruited who were scheduled to undergo primary or revision bilateral ESS and diagnosed with chronic sinusitis. Patients received either a control stent or the experimental stent to prevent relapse of sinusitis. The control stents and the experimental stents were evaluated at 30 days, 90 days, 180 days, and 1 year (= 360 days) after the procedure using video endoscopic findings. The results of this clinical trial show the effectiveness of the experimental stent, which significantly reduces relapse of sinusitis and increases the success of ESS. The control rate of the control stent was 0% while the experimental stent showed an over 70% control rate. Other main outcome measures include Lund-Kennedy score, Lund-Mackay score, VAS score, and implant successful rate.

[/INST] The study “Providing Cancer Care Closer to Home for Patients with Multiple Myeloma” is a natural experiment where cancer patients diagnosed with multiple myeloma who are receiving care from a provider within the Division of Oncology at the primary Siteman Cancer Center were randomly selected to be part of an intervention or active comparator group. The intervention group was offered cancer care to be conducted at a satellite location closer to their home, while the active comparator group was not offered the option of a satellite location for their care. The primary health outcome measures included the proportion of eligible participants that were successfully transferred to a provider at a satellite location, and types of candidacy used by the providers for transfer of care to satellite sites. The secondary health outcome measures included treatment burden measured by the Modified Treatment Burden Questionnaire, satisfaction with health interactions measured by the Questionnaire on the Quality of Physician-Patient Interaction, financial toxicity measured by the Comprehensive Score for Financial Toxicity, and reasons for opting to transfer or maintain care at their current location. The study aims to address accessibility and financial burden for MM patients, as well as the ability to treat MM in satellite centers.

[/INST] The goal of this study is to predict the risk of recurrent colorectal lesions and propose a surveillance plan that is specific to an individual's mutation burden and clinical-pathological phenotype. The research method will be to use mutation profiling to correlate clinical and histopathological parameters with the mutational phenotype of the patient. The primary outcome measure is the development and clinical utility of a new method to identify patients at high risk of metachronous colorectal lesions. The study will recruit 200 patients who have had colorectal polyps removed by therapeutic measures such as EPE, EMR, and ESD. These patients will be followed up for five years during which samples will be taken from lesions found through surveillance, which will be used to determine the mutation profile. Statistical models will be used to predict metachronous colorectal lesions based on the mutational profile of the patient.

[/INST] Parkinson is a chronic and progressive neurological disorder that affects movement, balance, and gait. Early symptoms may include tremors, stiffness, bradykinesia, and changes in facial expression. Over time, the condition may progress to loss of facial expression and difficulty swallowing, reading, and writing. To address these deficits, many patients turn to physical activity and exercise, which have been linked to increased strength, balance, and mobility. In recent years, the use of activity trackers and smartwatches such as Fitbits and Apple Watches has gained popularity, allowing individuals to monitor and track their physical activity and exercise in an effort to stay motivated and engaged. According to the literature, the prevalence of physical activity in PD patients is only 16-18%, compared to 30% for the general population. In addition, approximately one in five people over the age of 65 reported regularly meeting the recommended level of physical activity prior to the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, and one in three had access to a fitness tracker prior to the pandemic. In the past decade, the use of fitness trackers increased significantly, from 10% in 2010 to 30% in 2018. The study provides information on the estimated or forecasted use of fitness trackers, from 2016 to 2021. It should be noted that the study was conducted in 2016, prior to the COVID-19 pandemic. While the study suggests that there was a shift towards physical activity and exercise in patients with chronic pain, only 8% of people over the age of 65 were predicted to regularly meet the recommended level of physical activity in 2021, which the study defined as a 150 minutes per week of moderate-intensity aerobic activity, or a 75 minutes per week of vigorous-intensity aerobic activity (Hamilton et al., 2021). The study also discussed the potential of physical activity trackers (PATs) to help individuals monitor their physical activity levels, and the potential of PATs in the field of sports science, as well as the potential of wearable technology to monitor and analyze athletes' performance and provide real-time feedback to them during training. The study also highlighted the importance of physical activity and exercise in managing chronic pain, and the potential of wearable technology to monitor and track physical activity levels in individuals with chronic pain over time.

[/INST] The trial investigates the safety and efficacy of the oral glucose-lowering drug enavogliflozin in subjects with heart failure (HF) with preserved left ventricular ejection faction (LVEF), suffering from functional tricuspid regurgitation (TR). The primary outcome is a composite measure of cardiovascular (CV) events that includes CV death, hospitalization for HF, or worsening of TR. Enrolment is limited to non-diabetic subjects who have NT-proBNP levels over 125 pg/mL or BNP levels over 35 pg/mL. The study is randomized and blinded, with subjects receiving either enavogliflozin at 0.3 mg or placebo daily for 18 months. They will also be treated with standard therapy at the discretion of the investigator for all underlying diseases. The safety of subjects will be assessed by monitoring adverse events throughout the study, and by periodically examining and obtaining samples from the subjects. Subjects will also be followed for changes in parameters relating to heart failure, cardiac function, hepatic and renal function, electrolytes, and urinalysis.

[/INST] The Effect of Education Given According to the Health Promotion Model on Premenstrual Symptoms, Emotional Eating Behavior and Perceived Stress is a pre-posttest randomized control trial that aims to study the effects of behavioral (training given according to the health promotion model) and psychological interventions on the management of stress and emotional eating. [/INST] Detailed Description:- The AMP Schizophrenia (AMP SCZ) program, a multi-continent consortium, aims to develop a deep biomarker-informed functional characterization and longitudinal clinical profiling of Clinically High Risk (CHR) individuals. Multiple types of clinical study data are stored through the PREDICT-DPACC, which functions as the data repository for the AMP SCZ program and works with two CHR Research Networks (RNs). The data collection from AMP includes clinical, cognitive, neurophysiology, neuroimaging, genetics, and fluid biomarkers, speech, and facial expression (audio/video recordings). All CHR individuals are assessed using the Positive and Negative Symptom Scale for Schizophrenia (PSS) and Clinical Assessment for Negative Symptoms (CANS). Data collection from sites follows the AMP SCZ study protocol.

[/INST] The PROSPER trial is a feasibility study conducted as a pilot randomized controlled trial to determine the feasibility of implementing a brief psychological intervention, Problem Management Plus (PM+), for individuals who have high mental health needs during their incarceration in Dutch prisons. The intervention was adapted from an existing protocol, but never tested with a prison population. The feasibility of PM+ would be measured through five different indicators: overall PM+ compliance, perceptions about PM+ from different stakeholders, indicators of intervention delivery, retention rate of intervention sessions, and recruitment rate and consent for the trial. Study endpoints were not mentioned.

[/INST] NCT04531448 is a phase 2, randomized, open-label study evaluating olaparib (PO; 300 mg BID) vs olaparib PO + BYL719 (alpelisib) (PO; 50 mg QD) in treating patients with BRCA- and/or HER2-mutated, HER2-low advanced or metastatic breast cancer progressing following or at relapse within 2 years of a HER2-targeted treatment. The study includes two main cohorts of participants. In Cohort 1, patients must be naive to a PARP inhibitor, have BRCA-mutated advanced/metastatic breast cancer (HER2-negative, hormone receptor HR-positive or HR-negative), and be ineligible for germline BRCA-targeted treatments. In Cohort 2, the eligible participants must have HR-negative advanced/metastatic breast cancer with confirmed BRCA-mutation or HER2-mutation and be ineligible for or have progressed on targeted treatment. HER2-low breast cancer is defined as ER- or PR-positive, HER2-low, ERBB2 amplification score ≤ 2+ on a 4-tier in-situ hybridization (ISH) test with a fluorescence in-situ hybridization (FISH) ratio < 2 and no HER2 clustering. The study protocol consists of a screening period (up to 28 days), two study treatment periods, and two follow-up periods. Patients will receive olaparib BID + BYL719 QD (Cohort 2) or olaparib monotherapy (Cohorts 1 and 2) until disease progression. The study aims to establish the recommended dose, safety, and efficacy of olaparib + BYL719 in BRCA- and/or HER2-mutated, HER2-low advanced or metastatic breast cancer. The study will provide further information on olaparib in a BRCA- or HER2-mutated, HER2-low advanced breast cancer setting, determine the correlation between HER2 protein expression level and HER2 gene amplification by in-situ hybridization in HER2-low advanced breast cancer, improve the understanding of the disease's natural history, evaluate the biomarker activity of BYL719 + olaparib, and characterize the relationship of on-treatment, tumor-derived ctDNA with response, early predictive changes in pathologic and genomic biomarkers, and drug-induced clonal evolution.

[/INST] The proposed study will test a culturally tailored engagement and retention intervention for Haitian immigrants living with HIV (HILWH). [/INST] The trial will evaluate the accuracy of a computer-based image analysis tool called the Gleamer BoneView in diagnosing fractures on plain X-Rays. The tool uses state-of-the-art deep learning techniques to assess multiple candidate regions within each image. The study will recruit eighteen readers from different professional and experience levels. The trial will randomly divide the 500 X-ray images into two reading groups. In the first session, participants will review images without AI, which will be followed by a four-week washout period. The second session will be with AI and will be conducted in a different randomized order to discourage bias. Reading time, sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy will be measured.

[/INST] The study investigates the link between fine motor function, hand grip strength, and anthropometric characteristics in children with specific learning disorders and healthy participants. The Bruininks-Oseretsky Test of Motor Proficiency, Purdue Pegboard Test, hand dynamometer, and pinch gauge will be used as assessment tools. Additionally, participation and environment factors influenced by fine motor skills will be assessed using the Participation and Environment Measurement for Children and Youth questionnaire and the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory.

[/INST] The IM-ZBULLE Study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel group study that compares two intramuscular injection administration techniques of Haloperidol decanoate: Z-track and Airlock techniques. Primary outcome measure is pain reduction assessed using a visual analog scale 5 minutes after the treatment. Secondary outcomes include drug leakage reduction, the impact of injection on participants, participants' satisfaction, and therapeutic alliance. Intervention in the experimental group is intramuscular injection of Haloperidol decanoate using the Z-track and Airlock techniques, while in the control group it is using standard techniques. The study period lasts for 14 months and will be conducted at five centers in France, including public and privately sponsored facilities.

[/INST] It is a phase I/II study for evaluating the feasibility and effect of preoperative 5-day HFRT (30Gy/5fx once daily over consecutive weekdays) for primary STS of the extremities or trunk. The primary outcome is the feasibility of preoperative 5-day HFRT, defined as the proportion of eligible patients who opt to participate in the trial. The secondary outcomes include the rate of major wound complications within 6 months of surgery, rate of favorable pathologic response, the rate of local recurrence, and acute and late toxicities.

[/INST] Summary: The study aimed to evaluate the uptake of LAIV in England and its impact on HCRU, such as hospitalizations, ER visits, GP visits, and prescription rates. The study collected data from CPRD and HES databases for the 2012-2020 flu seasons. The criteria for participation included patients aged 2-18 years in England within a defined flu season, who were eligible for inclusion in research analysis, and who had not received both QIV and LAIV in the current season. The primary outcome was the uptake of LAIV per season. Secondary outcomes included the rate of APC and A&E episodes associated with ILI per 100,000 person-years, laboratory-confirmed influenza, OOPs, and length of hospital stay.

[/INST] This is a pilot pre-post interventional trial with no controls, with 10-20 South Asian children in primary schools (Grades 1-2, age 6-9) being recruited. In most primary schools, grades 1-2 students have not started learning Tang poems. Students and their parents will be actively approached by Hong Kong Christian Service. An information sheet will be provided to the parents of eligible children, and their contact information will be asked. Parents give written consent if they agree for their children to participate. Parents will be invited to join the intervention sessions to show support for students' participation but they will only sit at the back of the room without active interaction and learning requirements. The intervention comprises three 1.5-hour sessions of Tang poem reciting and one session for participant performances. Experienced instructors from Bestreben Drama Association Limited will lead each session, and adherence to the protocol will be assessed by independent reviewers. The intervention group will participate in three weekly sessions of 1.5-hour Tang poem classes and one session of performance show. Each session lasts for 1.5 hours. Parents can sit in the class. A total of six poems will be taught by two experienced Chinese teachers.
