[/INST] The following is a summary of the clinical trial abstract "Impact of Sex and Age on Non-visual Light Input That Affects Sleep and Circadian Rhythms" by Le-Minh Valada, Center Hospitalier Valais, Switzerland. The study is a randomized single-blinded clinical trial designed to assess the impact of sex and age on non-visual light input that affects sleep and circadian rhythms. The study is currently ongoing and being conducted in Switzerland. The primary objective of the study is to determine whether sex and age differences can affect the body’s ability to perceive and respond to light and dark information. The study will use pupilometry testing (which measures changes in pupil size in response to different light stimuli) and light box exposure to measure pupil size and melatonin levels respectively. The study will also assess participants’ sleep patterns and circadian rhythms through saliva samples collected at regular intervals. To achieve the study goal, the study will randomize adults aged 18–85 years old to one of eight different light stimuli order combinations. The participant’s eye-pupil responses and melatonin levels will be assessed after randomized exposure to different light or dark stimuli. The results of this study are expected to contribute to a better understanding of the effect of age-related conditions on the non-visual impact of light input on sleep and circadian rhythms, thus facilitating the development of more effective light therapies in the future.

[/INST] Improving Parenting Skills Adult ADHD (IPSA) is a new parent training program for parents with ADHD. The program combines structured group-based skills training with individualized support. Participants are randomized to one of two conditions with an equal probability to either the control (i.e., continue routine services) or intervention (i.e., IPSA). The study includes self- and parental report scales to assess parenting, parent-child relations, and child behavior as pre and post measures immediately after six IPSA sessions.

[/INST] SUHRI is a 4-session, self-directed technology-based intervention to address substance use and risky sex practices in justice-involved youth. The intervention is a proximal treatment with problem recognition, decision making, intention to reduce personal risk, and service initiation as the primary outcomes. Substance use and sexual risk behaviors are the distal outcomes. The intervention is conducted via a tablet and is administered as an individualized intervention. The intervention consists of four modules that cover substance use, sexual decision-making, self-efficacy for abstinence, fear of negative consequences, problem solving, and risk avoidance behaviors, etc. The intervention also encourages youth to initiate treatment for substance use and health. The SUHRI also addresses the barriers to implementing evidence-based treatments in juvenile justice settings, such as lack of manpower, limited resources, and budget constraints.

[/INST] This clinical trial is a phase II open-label, single-center, single-arm, futility trial. The primary objective of this trial is to demonstrate non-futility of remote ischemic conditioning (RIC) for reducing progression of disability in people with primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS) by using the timed 25-foot walk (T25FW) as outcome. T25FW is a validated and commonly used measure for evaluating lower limb function in PPMS. The investigators will test if 12 months of RIC treatment can lead to non-futility in treating people with PPMS. The T25FW will be measured at baseline and at 12-months. Non-futility will be defined as a non-increase of T25FW score by 20% or more. Other outcome measures will include brain MRI changes and measures of cognition and arm function.

[/INST] This trial, conducted in 2009, examined the utility of prothrombin time as a predictor of response to corticosteroid treatment in patients admitted with a clinical diagnosis of severe alcoholic hepatitis and eligible for corticosteroid treatment. The primary outcome was response at day 7 assessed by Lille score. Key exclusion criteria were acute or chronic viral hepatitis, nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, and active cocaine use. The sample consisted of severe alcoholic hepatitis patients aged 18–70 years who were admitted to a local hospital in France in 2008 and 2009. The trial included a total of 62 patients. At the time of diagnosis, blood samples were drawn to measure prothrombin and participants received the standard of care medical treatment for severe alcoholic hepatitis, which included supportive care and corticosteroid treatment. Patients were excluded if they were determined to be ineligible according to the study's criteria, refused to participate, withdrew consent during the study, did not receive corticosteroid treatment, or were excluded for medical or logistical reasons. The primary outcome was measured at day 7 and the 28-day mortality and liver survival events were measured at day 28. Secondary outcome measures included death from any cause occurring during hospitalization and early liver transplantation as a failure of medical treatment. No significant association was found between admission prothrombin time and outcome variables in this small underpowered trial.

[/INST] Functional task training versus functional therapy program to assess gross motor function, range of motion, and balance in children with cerebral palsy. The experimental group will undergo functional task training and the control group will receive functional therapy program. The study will measure impairment using goniometer, pediatric balance scale, and gross motor function measure scale. Data will be analyzed by using parametric and nonparametric tests based on the normality of the data.

[/INST] Purpose: To determine the prognostic value of NLR, ALC, and TLR in predicting the outcomes of ToF primary repair. To assess early and late complications and in-hospital mortality. Study design: Retrospective observational study. Study setting: National Cardiovascular Center Harapan Kita. Population: Patients with ToF who underwent primary repair in 2020-2022. Inclusion criteria: Patients undergoing ToF primary repair, including presence of any other associated cardiac anomalies, complete blood test and differential count availability preoperatively. Exclusion criteria: Surgery other than ToF primary repair, an association with other procedures (except PDA ligation, PFO, or ASD closure, or pulmonary artery enlargement), preoperative hemodynamic instability, suspected or confirmed infection, prior antibiotic administration during that hospitalization, or absence of a complete blood count with differential count. Sample size: 56 patients. Intervention: ToF primary repair. Statistical analyzes: Chi square, Fisher's exact test, and Mann Whitney U tests were used for the analysis. Results: Age of the patients ranges from 0.02 to 18.89 years, with a mean of 6.04 years ± 5.82 SD. There were more males than females, with a ratio of 50.5% vs. 49.5% respectively. Preoperative parameters: the NLR ranged from 0.04 to 32.51, with a mean of 2.35 ± 3.6 SD; the ALC ranged from 0.00 to 4.80 mm3, with a mean of 3.11 ± 1.70 SD; and the TLR ranged from 0.02 to 14.78, with a mean of 3.63 ± 4.29 SD. Complications: Severe complications occurred in 3 patients (5.4%), with one fatal outcome (1.8%). In-Hospital Mortality: In-hospital deaths occurred in 1 case (1.8%) Case fatality rate. Postoperative outcomes: There was no significant difference between the preoperative NLR, ALC and the postoperative outcomes. Conclusion: The preoperative neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio was not a valuable predictor of ToF primary repair outcomes, since there was no statistical significance between preoperative NLR, ALC and postoperative outcomes.

[/INST] This randomized double blind clinical trial will evaluate the effectiveness of patient-applied aqueous lidocaine via tampon as a pre-treatment prior to intra-uterine device placement. Subjects will apply the lidocaine or a saline placebo to the end of a standard tampon with a plastic applicator and then place the tampon 1 hour prior to the procedure. The tampon will be removed as the subject prepares for the procedure. A total of 60 healthy participants will be enrolled and divided into two equal groups (experimental and control) and will be randomly assigned into two arms of the study. In the experimental arm, participants will apply aqueous lidocaine to the tampon and in the control arm participants will apply a saline placebo to the tampon. The tampon must be removed within 1 hour of applying the solution. After placement, subjects will wait 1 hour before the IUD is inserted via speculum exam using ultrasound guidance. The primary outcome measures will assess the procedure time and patient-reported pain level. The secondary outcome measures will assess patient-reported satisfaction with the procedure, patient-reported interest in a subsequent procedure, and provider-reported procedural difficulty. Participants who have IUD placement will be asked to return for a follow up visit 1 week and 1 month after procedure. Any adverse events will be reported to the study coordinator within 48 hours.

[/INST] The article described by the author is a clinical study conducted in Milan, Italy. The study is a pilot study, which determines its preliminary character with the aim of assessing the feasibility and acceptability of capillary screening for early staging of the most prevalent chronic metabolic, cardiovascular and autoimmune diseases. The study was conducted on volunteers over 18 years who participated in the study on a voluntary basis, providing written and informed consent. The study protocol was approved by the scientific and ethical committee of the Municipality of Milan. The purpose of the study is to study the feasibility and acceptability of capillary screening for diabetes, cardiovascular disease and autoimmune disease in the general population through surveys and the provision of laboratory tests and the correlation of the study indicators with demographic, anthropometric and clinical data for multivariate assessment of risk. To perform the research, the volunteers agreed to give a capillary blood sample to perform the research tests. The test results will be communicated to the participants and will be collected up to a year after the study and up to one year after the end of the study. The results were obtained in the shortest possible time so that the project could then be expanded to the general population. In order to ensure respect for the privacy data of the participants and to guarantee the correct management and storage of data, the study was conducted in compliance with the provisions of the D.L. of May 18, 1968 No. 95, as amended by D.P. of April 18, 1992 .

[/INST] This study is titled "SMaRT Mom: Smartphone Management and Responsive Time for Breastfeeding Mothers". It focuses on smartphone addiction and its effect on mothers who breastfeed. The study offers an intervention to reduce smartphone use during breastfeeding through positive behavior reinforcement by implementing the SMaRT Mom intervention (Behavioral: SMaRT Mom). Mothers of infant breastfeeders with smartphone addiction are asked to not use their smartphones during breastfeeding for a week. They are also instructed not to use their smartphones while taking care of their infants and not using their smartphones for the rest of the day. The primary outcome measure is self-reported infant temperament, while the secondary measure is self-reported maternal self-efficacy. The study will use the following measures: Infant Behavior Questionnaire - Revised Very Short Form, Maternal Self-Efficacy Questionnaire and Daily Distraction Diary. Secondary outcomes include rewarding experience of breastfeeding, maternal attention towards the infant, changes in neural activity of breastfeeding mothers, and maternal physiological responses. The results are promising for both breastfeeding mothers and their infants.

[/INST] The study title is: "Bridging Gaps in the Neuroimaging Puzzle: New Ways to Image Brain Anatomy and Function in Health and Disease Using Electroencephalography and 7 Tesla Magnetic Resonance Imaging" is a clinical trial that aims to use electroencephalography (EEG) and 7 Tesla magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to study the neural mechanisms of healthy subjects, as well as patients with neurological disorders such as Epilepsy, Psychosis, and Essential Tremor. The study will analyze and compare brain anatomy and function, with the primary study outcomes being the Contrast-to-noise ratio between thalamic nuclei in 7 Tesla structural MRI and Pearson correlation between thalamocortical brain regions in 7 Tesla functional MRI, and microstate duration in EEG acquired concurrently with 7 Tesla functional MRI. The secondary study outcomes are neuroimaging datasets being published in fully anonymized form in suitable public data repositories. The study will recruit participants who are healthy and meet the criteria for the neurological disorders, and all participants will undergo EEG-fMRI and structural MRI at 7 Tesla. The authors believe that the novel combined approach used in this study will provide valuable insights into the mechanisms underlying these neurological disorders and may aid in the development of new diagnostic and therapeutic approaches.

[/INST] The study will involve two phases: Phase 1 will consist of a cross-sectional study, followed by a randomized controlled trial in Phase 2. In Phase 1, participants with or without obesity will be compared based on their hepcidin levels, iron parameters and inflammatory markers. Phase 2 will include subjects with iron deficiency anemia who have obesity, who will be randomly assigned to either a red meat diet or a non-red meat diet. The dietary interventions will last 60 days, and the participants will take iron supplements during the same period. Various biomarkers and dietary recalls will be assessed during this period.

[/INST] Continuous Non-invasive Electrophysiological Monitoring in High Risk Pregnancies is a research study evaluating the effects of using the Nemo Fetal Monitoring System (NFMS) on perinatal mortality and morbidity in women at high risk during their pregnancy. The objective of the study is to collect and compare data from two groups of women. One group receiving standard care of fetal monitoring and intermittent ultrasound monitoring, and a second group receiving continuous fetal electrocardiogram (ECG) monitoring using the NFMS. The study will run for two years with a sample size of 1911 participants, 1400 historical control cases, and 511 cases of the NFMS group. The primary outcome measure of the study is perinatal mortality and major neonatal morbidity, with assessment at discharge of the hospital and up to six weeks after giving birth. The results will provide evidence to justify the use of the NFMS as standard monitoring during pregnancy, particularly in high risk pregnancies.

[/INST] This double-blind, randomized clinical trial investigated the prevalence, type, and risk factors of UI in married women and its impact on their quality of life. UI is involuntary urinary leakage, mainly during physical activity, and it is associated with physical, psycho-social, and economic problems. It can cause UI in women during pregnancy, childbirth, and menopause. It results from factors such as advanced age, diabetes mellitus, chronic urinary infection, hysterectomy, and obesity. UI can cause social phobia, social isolation, reduced self-confidence and self-esteem, embarrassment, psychological problems, as well as financial and societal problems. UI affects the quality of life in more than 40% of women worldwide. The prevalence of UI is around 49% in Turkey, 32% in China, and 18% in Norway. Approximately 23.6% of women over 45 years of age in Brazil have UI. Around 28.4 million women are projected to be affected by UI by 2050 in the United States. Almost half of the women with UI in the United States report delayed seeking medical assistance due to fear, stigmatization, and a lack of information about treatment. As a result, one-fourth of women with UI reported delaying seeking medical assistance. One in five women over 18 years of age in Germany has UI. The majority of women postpone medical care for years and even decades. They do not seek medical care due to fear, stigma, perceived natural consequences of UI, and a lack of information about treatment options. Women with UI who receive effective treatment have a higher quality of life. It is crucial to create an environment in which UI can be openly communicated. The healthcare system must consider UI as part of its regular medical examinations. Healthcare providers should be well-informed about the latest information available for treating the condition and provide individualized treatment options for their patients.

[/INST] Study Overview ================== Biological: Bone Marrow Aspirate Concentrate Treatment for Patients with Symptomatic Knee Osteoarthritis(ID as given by Author) A Biologically Active Treatment Based on Bone Marrow Concentrate Is Proposed for People with Symptomatic Knee Osteoarthritis to Be Used in Italy. Eligible patients will be randomly assigned to either treatment. The Randomized Clinical Trial Will Compare Two Groups of Participants: Those Treated With a Bone Marrow Concentrate and Those Treated With Adipose Tissue . 1) Detailed Description ================== Patients with symptomatic unilateral knee osteoarthritis will be included in a randomized controlled trial in which a group of them will be treated with a single intra-articular injection of bone marrow aspirate concentrate, and a group will be treated with a single intra-articular injection of minimally manipulated adipose tissue. All patients will undergo a follow-up for up to 12 months after the intervention. 2) Participation Criteria ================== Study populations: Patients experiencing symptoms of knee osteoarthritis will be included in the study. Inclusion criteria will be met by patients who have no history of knee injury or surgery and experience significant symptoms that significantly interfere with their daily activities. Exclusion criteria will be applied to patients who have any kind of severe co-morbidities that preclude their ability to perform the clinical and radiological follow-up required by the study, as well as patients who cannot understand, read, and sign the informed consent document. 3) Recruitment Plan ==================== The study will be conducted at the Valida Clinic, Varese, Italy, from January 1, 2023, to December 31, 2027, enrolling patients with OA at the Valida orthopedic clinic until the target number of subjects is reached.

[/INST] This article explains an observational cohort investigation of chronic liver disease patients with intestinal parasitic infections in Sohag, Egypt. The patients were tested for stool analyses to detect the prevalence and pattern of intestinal parasitic infections in cirrhotic patients and compare them to non-cirrhotic patients with no comorbidities. The study aims to determine the most common risk factors for intestinal parasitic infections in patients with liver cirrhosis. Chronic liver disease, intestinal parasitic infections, and cirrhosis were the most used terms throughout the article. The study's primary outcome measures focused on detecting the pattern of intestinal parasitic infections among chronic liver disease patients. The enrollment criteria included cirrhotic patients with and without hepatocellular carcinoma and healthy volunteers. A total of 200 subjects were randomly assigned to two groups (cases group and control group). The cases group consisted of cirrhotic patients with chronic liver disease and GIT complaints (100 patients), and the control group consisted of non-cirrhotic patients with GIT complaints but no comorbidities (100 patients) The researchers conducted a thorough stool analysis of both groups to detect intestinal parasitic infections.

[/INST] The REDOS trial is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD) treatment using traditional vitrectomy, scleral buckle (SB) surgery, and new gas tamponade technique. The trial involves participants diagnosed with symptomatic RRD and enrols in a randomized fashion to one of the treatment groups. The trial duration is 12 months and employs pars plana vitrectomy (PPV), PPV combined with SB surgery, perfluoropropane gas tamponade, and vitrectomy combined with SB surgery and fluoropropane gas. The primary outcome measure evaluates the single-surgery success rate, whereas secondary outcome measures include single-surgery visual acuity outcomes, time to RRD recurrence, number and severity of complications such as postoperative pain, vision-related quality of life questionnaire, and quality of life scores.

[/INST] The Effect of Various Concentrations of Ropivacaine on the Onset and Duration of Ankle Block is a randomized controlled trial that investigates the effects of different concentrations of ropivacaine for ultrasound-guided ankle blocks in adults undergoing forefoot surgery. Participants will be randomly assigned to three groups: 0.25%, 0.5%, and 1% ropivacaine groups. The primary outcome is the duration of sensory block, while the secondary outcomes include the onset time of the sensory block, postoperative analgesia (pain scores), and opioid consumption.

[/INST] Summary: This is a randomized controlled trial aiming to determine the impact of compression stockings on the symptoms, well-being, quality of sleep, and complications of pregnant women with Restless Legs Syndrome. Pregnant women with Restless Legs Syndrome will either receive knee-length compressed stockings, or knee socks, for a period of three weeks. The severity of Restless Legs Syndrome, sleep quality, impact on quality of life, and the impact of the condition on activities of daily living will be measured by the RLS Severity Rating Scale and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index Form.

[/INST] The "Tai-chi Snacking and Strength Snacking (T-SAFE)" study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to examine the effects of exercises on the functional and physical components of older adults. The study will compare a homebased exercise program to usual care over 12 weeks. The homebased exercise program, consisting of exercises based on Tai-chi snacking and strength snacking, will be delivered by tele-video instruction and will follow a 3-week progressive test period design. The outcomes of the study will include physical function tests, 1RM of leg press test, balance function test, strength function test, agility function test, flexibility function test, and health-related quality of life. The results of the study are expected to provide evidence on a new model of home-based exercise snacking and Tai-chi snacking that can help older adults to improve their physical functions and health-related quality of life and reduce their risk of falls.

[/INST] Prospective, randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study to observe the effects of caudal epidural injections with ropivacaine and dexamethasone on postoperative pain, duration of analgesia, and side effects in patients undergoing lumbar spine surgery.

[/INST] The study was a randomized controlled experimental study conducted to determine the effectiveness of care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory on comfort, satisfaction and sleep quality of intensive care patients. The number of patients included in the study was determined as 40 in the experimental group and 40 in the control group, which is the number of participants reached considering data loss. The nursing intervention applied to the experimental group included care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory, administering comfortable clothes, allowing freedom of movement, and encouraging communication and interaction with the patient. Measuring comfort with the General Comfort Scale, comfort behaviours and the Richard Campbell Sleep Scale, it was determined that the patients in the experimental group had more comfort, comfortable behaviours and better sleep quality than the patients in the control group .

[/INST] The P-Kids CARE health systems intervention trial is a multi-faceted approach to improve the treatment of injured children in Tanzania. This clinical trial will evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention in reducing mortality rates in injured children. A comprehensive intervention was developed, which incorporated pre-intervention qualitative data from health care providers and injured children’s families. The intervention includes a basic emergency care course and decision support tool. The intervention will be implemented at health facilities in Moshi, Tanzania, through direct on-site training and follow-up.

[/INST] This study seeks to explore the differences between two pelvic floor rehabilitation approaches, with or without postural re-education, on women with stress urinary incontinence and chronic low back pain. Both are treated for 5 weeks, with 10 sessions each week with spinal mobilization exercise or exercise to stretch the posterior muscle chain and diaphragm. The ICIQ-UI SF, Pain VAS, and MOS scale will be used to test and validate the treatment. The researchers aim to find a better treatment approach to the condition, with a low side effect rate. A total of 24 participants will be included in the study. The data collection will be performed in 4 stages, respectively before treatment, after treatment, and one month after the study.

[/INST] Authors developed a new pharmacodynamic model for propofol using frontal EEG data from older adults undergoing general anesthesia. They compared their model to an existing model based on bispectral index. The study provides a new non-invasive PK/PD model that may be useful in predicting drug concentrations and maintaining anesthesia in older adults. However, the study is small and conducted in a single center, so further validation and testing in larger clinical trials is necessary.

[/INST] Short-course antibiotics versus standard-course antibiotics in patients with cholangitis. Very short-course means one day of antibiotics after endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) that leads to adequate biliary drainage compared to four to seven days of standard-course.

[/INST] This is a prospective, randomized, double-blinded clinical study to compare the efficacy of manual airway pressure release ventilation (MV) with ultrasound-guided lung recruitment maneuver (REC) in patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery. In the MV group, 30 consecutive morbidly obese patients with a body mass index (BMI) greater than 40 will be recruited. In REC group, 30 consecutive morbidly obese patients (body mass index greater than 40) will be included. The study will be performed by shifting patients to 100% high-flow oxygen (HFNO) for 3 minutes and then performing MV manually with a pressure of 30 cmH2O for 30 s and after performing a REC under real-time ultrasonography guidance if a atelectasis is present which is defined as LUS ≥ 2 for any of the 12 regions.

[/INST] LIFE-CLB is a study aiming to investigate the effectiveness of a behavioral weight reduction program in patients with overweight and obesity. The intervention will be provided through physiotherapists, who are educated in LBP and CBT and are trained in providing the intervention within the study. Patients will receive either 4 weeks of PNE combined with CTET or 4 weeks of PNE combined with CTET plus a behavioral weight reduction program. Patients will be followed for 12 months, with measurements at post-treatment, 3 months, 6 month, 9 month, and 12 months after baseline. The main outcome measure, perceived recovery will be assessed both on a global level (i.e., "In the last week, how would you describe your state?) as well as a more specific level (i.e., seven pain-related items such as "The pain in my back has completely disappeared) through the Global Perceived Recovery Status Scale. Secondary outcome measures will explore the effectiveness of the behavioral weight reduction program on other physical, psychosocial and economic indicators. The study will help in determining the clinical effectiveness of behavioral weight reduction programs and CBT as an additional adjunct therapy to exercise therapy.

[/INST] This study was a multi-center study conducted in China and aimed to establish normal values for high-frequency ultrasound measurements of extremity arterial structure and blood flow, and examine the factors that may affect them. The participants were Han adults aged 18 to 79 years, with a body mass index (BMI) of less than 30 kg/m2, who had fasting blood glucose, blood lipid, kidney and liver function, and electrocardiogram values within normal limits. The device used for the high-frequency ultrasound measurements was unspecified. The parameters measured for arterial structure were intima thickness of the dorsalis pedis artery (DPA) and proper palmar digital artery (PDA), while the parameters measured for arterial blood flow were blood flow velocity (BFV) of both arteries. All participants were required to have arterial blood flow signals that could be detected without occlusion. The normal reference values for arterial structure and blood flow were established based on the average of all participants, and sex-based differences in normal reference values were evaluated. In addition, the study investigated the factors that may affect arterial structure and blood flow values, such as age, BMI, systolic blood pressure (SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), resting heart rate, and other demographic and health-related information. The study found that there were significant relationships between arterial structure and blood flow values and age, BMI, and SBP in some cases by regression analysis, but the exact nature of these relationships was not described. The study also found sex-based differences in normal reference values for arterial structure and blood flow and suggested that men be evaluated using higher cut-off values for arterial blood flow thickness measurements, while women be evaluated using higher cut-off values for arterial blood flow BFV measurements. The study concluded that this multi-center study established reliable normal reference values for high-frequency ultrasound measurements of arterial structure and blood flow and the influencing factors of these values. However, the study had limitations, as the study population was limited to adults aged 18 to 79 years and the study did not consider disease groups, such as diabetes or hypertension, which may affect these measurements. Overall, this study provides valuable reference values for non-invasive and reliable arteries measurements.

[/INST] The proposed study will aim to evaluate whether physical and cognitive training will augment hippocampal plasticity induced by HBOT, and further enhance recovery of inaccessible memories in veterans with PTSD. Previous research by the investigators demonstrated that hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT), induced hippocampal neuroplasticity , which enhanced memory recovery, reduced the severity of PTSD symptoms in veterans [12, 13, 19], and ameliorated PTSD symptoms associated with childhood sexual abuse in women [15, 16]. In these studies, the HBOT protocol comprised daily HBOT sessions for 60 consecutive days, with each session lasting 90 minutes. Research shows that HBOT leads to increased synaptic plasticity and increases expression of the β-tubulin isoform III subunit (β-tubulin III) [11, 14], which is essential for healthy brain networks and for encoding and retrieval of memories. Hippocampal neurogenesis in humans is challenging to demonstrate using current methods [20, 21], however, changes in hippocampal neuroplasticity, such as β-tubulin III expression, are correlated with changes in hippocampal volume and neuronal activity, and thus are considered robust biomarkers of hippocampal neurogenesis [11, 14, 15]. In addition to HBOT, physical and cognitive training will be administered, in order to support the effect of HBOT on memory recovery via enhancing hippocampal neuroplasticity, and to further augment the effect of HBOT on hippocampal neurogenesis and brain integration. Exercise has been reported to enhance memory performance and hippocampal neurogenesis . Physical activity in combination with cognitive training has been shown to facilitate brain plasticity, integrate information, and improve the performance of memory retrieval . The physical training used from this protocol will include walking, jogging, running, aerobic dance, muscle circuit training, and breathing exercises, performed in a group format. The training will include 30 minutes of light to moderate aerobic activity, followed by a 5–10 minute warm-down period and stretching. The memory training will use the RSVP method, as developed by Bailey [18, 24], which consists of repeated, random, transverse presentations of printed words, each printed at the rate of three words per second, to subjects in a seated position. The cognitive training will use an integrative training program  to enhance brain integration and improve memory retrieval. The training will consist of 20–30 minutes of integration memory-based training, using repetition of items, associations and spatial environments, through repetitive practice of associating and linking a new set of 300 items.

Participants were grouped into two arms: a mobile app arm and a web-based notification arm. Participants were asked their feedback about platform use, vaccine safety, and vaccine confidence using the user experience survey. User experience survey questions were based on a Likert scale and followed participant responses during the study. Participants had to complete the full protocol, which included the safety survey before moving on to complete the user experience survey. The study used two versions of the influenza vaccine safety survey (paper-based and electronic-based). Participants completed the paper-based version in 2014 and the electronic-based in 2015 (a new version of the electronic-based survey). [/INST] A clinical trial is a research study that evaluates the effectiveness of a medical intervention on human subjects. It is an objective, controlled experiment that involves collecting data from participants before and after being treated with the medical intervention. Clinical trials can test various aspects of an intervention, such as its safety, efficacy or the ideal dosage for patients. The results of a clinical trial can provide important information to inform clinical decision making and the development of new medical treatments.

The aim of the study was to contribute to the development of new prevention strategies and help personalize patient management.

[/INST] This study is a phase 2, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial on the efficacy and safety of tirzepatide used as a single therapeutic agent for the treatment of diabetes mellitus type I in combination with insulin therapy. The study aims to investigate the effects of tirzepatide in addition to current insulin treatment on body weight, A1C, lipid profile, adverse events, etc. Patients with T1DM for at least 12 months and BMI ≥ 30 kg/m2 who are currently receiving insulin therapy are eligible for the study.

[/INST] Clinical Trial Title: Losartan in Taxane-induced Peripheral Neuropathy  (NCT05036268) describes a randomized study involving early-stage breast cancer patients. Losartan (100 mg) was intended as an intervention to prevent chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy. The primary outcome measure was the incidence of the condition over a 24-week follow-up period. Additionally, the patient quality of life was assessed by Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy/Gynecologic Oncology Group - Neurotoxicity (FACT/GOG-NTX), and the nerve growth factor (NGF) level in the serum was measured. The findings showed that Losartan is effective in preventing chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy and improves patient quality of life. In summary, Losartan exhibits potential as an adjunctive therapy to manage chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy among breast cancer patients undergoing paclitaxel chemotherapy.

[/INST] The study is divided into the experimental group and the control group, which compares the therapeutic effects of Ginkgo ketone ester tablets (GKT) alone against those of conventional antidiabetic therapy. The secondary objectives are to evaluate differences in cognitive impairment severity and quality of life between the groups. The study will run for 180 days.

[/INST] The trial is titled "CsA+ATG+AVA vs. CsA+AVA for the Treatment of Newly-diagnosed SAA in the Elderly" and is a comparative study evaluating the efficacy and safety of cyclophosphamide, and ciclosporin with or without antithymocyte globulin and avatrombopag for the treatment of newly diagnosed severe aplastic anemia in the elderly. The trial will recruit patients aged 60 years or older with newly diagnosed severe aplastic anemia who meet the inclusion criteria. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two treatment groups: the cyclophosphamide and ciclosporin with antithymocyte globulin group or the cyclophosphamide and ciclosporin with avatrombopag group. The primary endpoint of the trial is the overall response rate at 6 months after treatment initiation. The secondary endpoint is the complete response rate at 6 months after treatment initiation, relapse rate at 12 months after treatment initiation, and adverse event rate at 3, 6, and 12 months after treatment initiation. The trial is expected to recruit 90 participants and follow them up for 12 months. The trial is being conducted in China.

[/INST] The provided document describes the study protocol for a phase 3, randomized controlled study to determine the prognostic effect of prophylactic central neck dissections (CND) in low-risk PTC. The study involves randomizing patients with low-risk PTC to receive either a prophylactic central neck dissection at the time of surgery or no further dissection. Eligibility criteria include thyroid nodules measuring 11-40 mm on ultrasound, negative central lymph nodes on preoperative ultrasound, and negative frozen section analysis of the thyroid for malignancy. The primary outcome measure is an excellent response at 36 months. Secondary outcomes include recurrence-free survival after 12 and 24 months. The results of this study could help clinicians provide more targeted treatment options for patients with low-risk PTC.

[/INST] The key aspects of this study are that it investigates the efficacy of two next-generation nets containing different combinations of pyrethroids and synergists to control malaria in humans in Cote d'Ivoire. The trial is a cluster-randomized, single-blind, superiority trial with three study arms and is set to run for 12 months in a population of over 45,000 persons. The nets tested are veeralin LLIN, a net combining the synergist PBO and alpha-cypermethrin; Interceptor G2, a mixture LLIN incorporating chlorfenapyr and a pyrethroid; and MAGNET LLIN, the latter being used as an active comparator, containing alpha-cypermethrin only. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of malaria cases in children aged 6 months to 10 years, and the secondary outcome measure is the prevalence of malaria infection in the study population. The study aims to determine if the next-generation nets are more effective in controlling malaria compared to conventional pyrethroid LLINs and to compare the efficacy of the two next-generation nets.

[/INST] Our proposed protocol is a single-arm study with 100 eligible patients randomized 1:1 to receive either stereotactic radiation therapy (SBRT) plus Foley catheter (control group) or SBRT plus a novel continuous tracking catheter (experimental group). The primary endpoint is a composite of early radiotherapy treatment-related grade 2 or worse adverse events as measured by the radiation therapy oncology group and common terminology criteria for adverse events.

[/INST] The study evaluated the effect of continuous wave diode laser on orthodontic movement and root resorption. One group received a continuous wave diode laser with a power output of 250 milliwatts, 808-nm wavelength, and a fluence of 4 joules per cm2 on each point at a time, while the other group did not receive the laser therapy. The results showed that the power output used in the study did not significantly accelerate orthodontic movement in all movements. However, it significantly reduced root resorption in all types of movements.

[/INST] The CoDIG-2 Italian Study is a multicenter cohort study in Italy. It aims to evaluate the extent of lymphadenectomy in right hemicolectomy. [/INST] Effects of Cawthorne Cooksey Exercises on Balance in Children With Hearing Deficits is a clinical trial study that aims to investigate the effects of Cawthorne Cooksey exercises on balance and quality of life in children with hearing impairment. Pediatric Berg Balance Scale and the Four-Step Square Test will be used to measure the balance of the participants.

[/INST] The Psychological Impact on Women Who Completed Chemotherapy Treatment for Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia. They aim to gain insight into what support the patients received and if this support was effective and helpful. The study used a sample of 20 women who underwent chemotherapy for GTN. The interviews were digitalized and a thematic analysis was carried out to interpret the outcomes.

[/INST] The trial titled "Evaluating the Utility of Bone Grafts in Open Wedge Corrective Osteotomy and Plate Fixation in Patients With Malunited Distal Radius Fractures" by Centre Hospitalier Valais (CHV) is a randomized clinical study evaluating open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation in malunited distal radius fractures, which involve fragments of bone that are displaced and misaligned at the wrist. The trial compares the efficacy of including (group with bone grafting) and excluding (group without bone grafting) bone grafts from the intertrochanteric crest region of the hip bone during the open wedge corrective osteotomy and the time to complete bone healing, complications for both groups, quality of life using the EQ-5D-5L questionnaire, the subjective and objective functional outcomes, and cost-effectiveness analysis.

[/INST] The HABILIT-ILE trial is a non-inferiority randomized controlled trial that compares a home-based caregiver-assisted HABIT-ILE delivery to a traditional in-hospital delivery of HABIT-ILE in children with bilateral cerebral palsy. [/INST] Digital vs. Speculum Exams for PPROM is a randomized controlled trial with Speculum Exams as the active comparator for Digital Exams. If the patient requires cervical examination to assess cervical dilation, effacement, and station after PPROM, the Speculum Exams procedure is performed in which a sterile speculum is inserted to visually estimate cervical dilation and effacement. The Digital Exams procedure is also performed in which a provider wears sterile gloves and palpates the cervix with lubricating jelly to assess cervical dilation, effacement, and station. Both procedures are used to measure hospital latencies from admission to delivery, up to 10 weeks, and prenatal diagnosis. Secondary outcomes include chorioamnionitis, endomyometritis, maternal sepsis, wound infections, maternal intensive care unit (ICU) admission, composite neonatal morbidity, length of neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) admission, need for respiratory support, neonatal sepsis, neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage, necrotizing enterocolitis, hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, neonatal pneumonia, patient satisfaction with exam, and neonatal death. The study will be performed at the Centre Hospitalier Valida. The trial currently has a total of 118 enrolled participants, out of a planned sample size of 190.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, single-center, phase II trial. The study is designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of sequential partial adult liver left lateral lobe transplantation (SALT) in the treatment of liver cirrhosis with liver cancer. The primary end point is overall survival (OS) after three years. The second end point is disease-free survival (DFS) within 6 years. From 2015 to 2019, 44 patients with liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma were included in this study. Of these 44 patients, 22 were male and 22 were female. The average age was 48 years old. The diagnosis criteria for liver cancer included histology, imaging and clinical biochemistry. The Milan criteria were used to assess the resectability of liver cancer. 44 patients were enrolled in this study. After the liver graft was judged to be sufficient for transplantation by examining venous flow through the portovenous system before transplantation, transplantation was performed 3 months later after the parenchyma of the left lateral lobe resection had grown to make the remnant liver fully functional. The postoperative diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma was based on the pathological diagnosis of the liver resection specimen and the first hepatocellular carcinoma resection specimen from the second surgery. The postoperative diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma was based on the pathological diagnosis of the liver resection specimen after the first hepatic resection, and the second liver resection specimen was also hepatocellular carcinoma.

[/INST] The objective of this study is to examine the validity and reliability of the Dexterity Assessment Tool in diagnosing dexterity in individuals with degenerative cervical myelopathy (DCM) or in healthy individuals. The study includes two arms: 1. Patients with DCM will have dexterity measured once with the dexterity tool. 2. Healthy individuals will have dexterity measured twice to perform reliability analyses. Dexterity scores will be compared to determine the correlation with the GRASSP-M tool among healthy participants, with the correlation between the Dexterity Assessment Tool and the GRASSP-M tool in patients with DCM. Inter-rater reliability and test-retest reliability will also be assessed among healthy participants. The study will determine the ability of the dexterity tool to reliably assess dexterity in patients with DCM and healthy individuals.

[/INST] The Preoperative Assessment of Pathological Nipple Discharge With Delayed Ductal Imaging of Contrast-enhanced Spectral Mammography is a prospective single-group assignment study designed to evaluate the effectiveness of delayed ductal imaging post iopromide 370 mgI/ml enhanced ductography and safety of radiation exposure in patients with pathological nipple discharge. The protocol included preliminary experiments and a detailed description of the mammary duct structure in the Chinese population. For eligibility, the participants were female aged 18-65 years, had an episode of PND, and had undergone iopromide 370 mgI/ml enhanced ductography with no diagnosis of breast cancer. Participants received contrast-enhanced spectral mammography 4-6 hours post ductography. The primary outcome was the percentage of changes in the imaging diagnosis caused by the delayed ductal imaging results. The results of the study suggest that delayed ductal imaging should be conducted 4-6 hours following routine iopromide 370 mgI/ml enhanced ductography.

[/INST] The provided trial is a "prospective cohort study of women > 18 years of age who present with symptoms of stress urinary incontinence. [/INST] The study Improving Attendance in Community Wise (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT04095686) is a randomized control trial that aims to improve attendance at the Community-Wise intervention and examine intervention attendance and alcohol and substance misuse (ASM) frequency reduction as outcomes. The Community-Wise (CW) intervention is a multi-level, manualized behavioral intervention to decrease ASM frequency, which has previously demonstrated efficacy in reducing ASM frequency among self-reported SUD and incarcerated. However, attendance at the CW intervention was poor. The current study is designed to improve attendance by evaluating three factors, including (1) delivering the CW intervention to supervised vs non-supervised patients, (2) providing a financial incentive vs no financial incentive to attend the CW intervention, and (3) delivering the CW intervention in an open vs closed group format. The primary outcome is to examine whether delivering the CW intervention under the different conditions will increase attendance and engagement in the treatment. The study will test the secondary outcome by evaluating how the conditions will affect ASM frequency reduction. The research will impact public health by increasing attendance at existing programs addressing community health needs by providing evidence that incentives and group formatting can help increase attendance and engagement among participants. The study will also enhance public health knowledge by providing information on the impact of the intervention on a new subpopulation of people with SUD.

[/INST] Study Overview: The study aims to compare the effectiveness of interpectoral area block + serratus anterior plane block with erector spinae block as part of multimodal analgesia in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. For this purpose, the target groups of the study will be randomized and pain scores will be evaluated in the first 48 hours after the intervention, as well as pain scores, opioid consumption and intraoperative and postoperative deviations.

[/INST] The study involves a randomized controlled trial of three groups of participants who have undergone hemorrhoidectomy. The first group received a botulinum toxin injection after hemorrhoidectomy, the second group received internal sphincterotomy after the operation, and the third group received no additional treatment post-hemorrhoidectomy (control group). The primary outcome measure is post-operative pain scored using the visual analogue scale (VAS) from 1 to 10 scores. The secondary outcome measure is time to return to normal daily activities. The duration of the study is two weeks for the primary outcome and at least 4-6 weeks for the secondary outcome. The study was published in 2023, and the official title is "The Effect of Botulinum Toxin Injection After Hemorrhoidectomy in Pain Control: a Randomized Controlled Trial." According to the authors of the study, hemorrhoidectomy causes significant pain that can interfere with daily activities such as sitting and walking. The trial evaluated the effectiveness of botulinum toxin injection and internal sphincterotomy in reducing post-operative pain, decreasing time to return to normal daily activities, and improving quality of life.

[/INST] The study focuses on the use of Fruquintinib to treat CRC liver metastases. The summary explains that the purpose of the study is to evaluate Fruquintinib's clinical efficacy and safety in patients with CRC liver metastases who achieve no evidence of disease (NED) after first-line chemotherapy. The study uses a single-arm, nonrandomized, open label, phase II clinical study design. The study aims to evaluate the 2-year recurrence/metastasis rate of Fruquintinib as a maintenance treatment in CRC patients who achieve NED after first-line chemotherapy, using chest/abdominal and pelvic CT scans, colonoscopy, and CEA/CA129. In addition, the study aims to evaluate the clinical benefits of Fruquintinib, including evaluating the disease-free survival rate, recurrence period, and toxicity of Fruquintinib. The study will provide insight into Fruquintinib's potential for clinical use in treating CRC liver metastases.

[/INST] This study titled "Methylphenidate for the Treatment of PTSD with Associated Neurocognitive Complaints" is a clinical trial that aims to determine the efficacy of methylphenidate as a treatment for PTSD and the associated neurocognitive complaints in Veterans. The trial is randomized and double-blinded, with participants receiving methylphenidate twice daily for four weeks, followed by a placebo for an additional four weeks. The primary outcome measure is the PTSD Symptom Checklist for DSM-5 (PCL-5) and the secondary outcome measure is the Neuro-QoL Cognitive Function short form (NeuroQoL). Overall, the study aims to determine the efficacy of methylphenidate as a treatment for PTSD and associated neurocognitive complaints in Veterans.

[/INST] This is a clinical trial about the study of microvascular function in patients with angina. The patients will undergo invasive procedures to diagnose angina, and the study will evaluate the use of continuous thermodilution flow reserve (CFR) to provide a reference for the diagnosis of microvascular disease. The main objective of the study is to evaluate the accuracy of continuous thermodilution CFR measured by Youden index, while the secondary objective is to assess the quality of life of patients 3 months after diagnosis. The study will be conducted in the cardiology department of Centre Hospitalier Valida. Eligibility criteria are adult patients who are included during the performance of coronary angiography and are clinically indicated for the assessment of microvascular functions. Those with decompensated heart failure or cardiogenic shock will be excluded from the study. The interventions are invasive clinical examinations and diagnostic tests using microvascular function tests. CMR flow reserve, continuous thermodilution measured CFR, and minimal microvascular resistance will be used as measures. The Youden index will be used to assess the accuracy of CFR. The quality of life of the patients will be evaluated using the Seattle Angina Questionnaire at 3 months and 1 year. The study is planned to enroll 50 participants, half of whom will receive microvascular disease diagnosis from continuous thermodilution CFR, and the other half will receive diagnosis based on conventional bolus thermodilution evaluation. The outcomes of the study will be the accuracy of continuous thermodilution CFR diagnosis, quality of life after 3 months, and quality of life after 1 year.

[/INST] The study is a phase 2, open-label, multicenter study conducted in 11 hematology-oncology centers in 10 states across the USA. The study is a collaborative effort between the City of Hope Comprehensive Cancer Center and FORTH HEALTH. Phase II of the study is a single-arm study with data collected from the start of chemotherapy on day -1 or day 0 of transplant until day +100 or day of death, whichever occurs first. The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the feasibility of adding ruxolitinib to tacrolimus and methotrexate. The primary endpoint is the incidence of acute GVHD, and the secondary endpoint is the incidence of aGVHD-free and relapse-free (GRFS) rates. The study is a prospective interventional clinical trial in a specific condition of the pediatric population (Table 1). The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of ruxolitinib when given as part of reduced intensity HCT from a matched related or unrelated donor in patients with AML, ALL, or MDS. The primary statistical analysis is descriptive.

[/INST] Irritable bowel syndrome can be improved by participating in a temple stay experience that includes dietary changes and mindful eating. The main goals of this clinical trial are to observe the dietary intake and symptom improvement of patients with irritable bowel syndrome before, during, and four weeks after a temple stay experience. The primary outcome measure is the symptom score for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS-SSS), and the secondary outcome measure is fecal microbiome, including species composition, proportions, diversity, and comparison of the above measures before and after temple stay participation. The participants are adults aged 20-69 years with diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome. Temple stay participants follow a vegetarian meal plan, focus on mindfulness and non-competitiveness, and follow a daily schedule of monastic practices. The research team aims to investigate whether the gut microbiota of patients can be repopulated by a temple experience based on a vegetarian diet and adherence to a standardized, physically active life for eight days. Further, the team aims to determine whether subjective symptom improvement can lead to a more satisfactory life for patients with irritable bowel syndrome.

[/INST] The aim of this study is to assess the willingness of asthma patients to change their inhaler for environmental reasons, as well as their awareness of the issue. They will also study the willingness of health practitioners to make this change at the patient's request.

[/INST] The summary of this study is that it is a randomized clinical trial to evaluate the durability of endoscopic plications, weight loss outcomes, and improvements in obesity-related co-morbidities for the combined hybrid argon plasma coagulation plus endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (HAPC-ESG) procedure when compared to traditional ESG. The primary outcome is the durability assessed by blinded physicians with expertise in ESG with a priori standardized criteria, and the secondary outcome is the %TBWL and %EWL.

[/INST] This study was a randomized controlled experiment examining the effects of cancer education based on the Health Belief Model to increase awareness of physical disability women and their participation in screening. Participants were randomized to either an intervention group receiving education based on the Health Belief Model or a control group receiving standard cancer education. The intervention consisted of home visits to deliver the education in a booklet format, with follow-up phone calls and text message reminders. The study used questionnaires and scales to measure awareness of gynecological cancers and the efficacy of the Health Belief Model. The findings of the study showed that both groups had a higher level of awareness and knowledge of gynecological cancers post-intervention compared to the control group. The intervention group in particular had a significant increase in awareness, knowledge, and the frequency of screening behaviors. Overall, the study suggests that the Health Belief Model can be used effectively to increase screening participation among physically disabled women.

[/INST] This systematic review assessed the effectiveness of neoadjuvant (pre-surgery) chemotherapy and targeted therapy with Trastuzumab in HER2-positive breast cancer. The researchers analyzed data from nine clinical trials that met their inclusion criteria, including information on the design of the trials, patient characteristics, treatment regimens, and primary/secondary endpoints. The primary outcome of interest was the pCR rate among patients who underwent neoadjuvant therapy. The overall rate of pCR was found to be 42%. The study also provided insights into different aspects of treatment protocols, such as dosage, duration, and chemotherapy regimens. However, some variations in the definition of pCR across the trials were observed.

[/INST] This study is a pilot trial aiming to assess the feasibility of coach-led digital platforms in improving health outcomes among residents in Athy, Kildare, Ireland. Participants will receive coaching from technology partners Empeal and the RCSI Coach Connect team, allowing them to access a variety of educational resources and engage in a community-wide wellness program. The platform's performance will be assessed over six months through surveys, interviews, and focus groups. The study will provide information on the feasibility of implementing digital coaching as a health intervention, utilizing sustainable technology, and incorporating community-based health initiatives.

[/INST] The PMR exercise, which includes the systematic relaxation of the main muscle groups of the body aimed at physical and psychological relaxation, was applied twice a day, every weekday, for eight weeks. Patients are asked to do the 10-minute application at home 3 times a day for 8 weeks. Phone calls were made to the patients once a week to see whether the practice continues and whether they had any difficulties during the exercises. The severity of dyspnea and fatigue symptoms was measured and sleep quality.

[/INST] This study investigates the effects of Balint group on burnout and self-efficacy of nurse leaders in China. The study aims to compare the effectiveness of a Balint group intervention among nurse leaders with that of a control group in addressing emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and personal accomplishment outcomes. Nurse leaders were randomized to participate in either a Balint group or a control group (no intervention). Participants in the Balint group received Balint training for three months, consisting of two lectures and 10 small group discussion sessions during this period. The MBI-EE questionnaire and the General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES) were used to measure emotional exhaustion and general self-efficacy, respectively. These questionnaires were administered at baseline and three months after completing Balint group sessions to participants in both the experimental and control groups. The Balint group showed positive effects on participants' emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, personal accomplishment, and general self-efficacy. These findings demonstrate that Balint group is a promising intervention for nurse leaders experiencing burnout and self-efficacy issues.

[/INST] This study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to test the effectiveness of non-pharmacologic and TCM-based treatments for cognitive impairment in individuals with Long COVID symptoms. Participants are randomized into four groups: Behavioral: Acupuncture and TCM-based lifestyle management, Experimental: Acupuncture, Experimental: TCM-based lifestyle management, No Intervention: Wait-list control. The outcomes consist of measures of global cognitive function, cardiopulmonary function, fatigue, health-related quality-of-life, psychological distress, neurocognitive functions, and neurobiological outcomes. The follow-up assessment is at 12 weeks after baseline. The outcomes will be obtained at baseline, at 4 weeks after baseline, 8 weeks after baseline, and at 12 weeks after baseline. The outcome of interest in this study is the long-term impact of the intervention, which will be measured during the 12-week follow-up.

[/INST] Summary of the clinical trial involves analysis of survey data collected from physicians and molecular tumor board to determine the usability of Cellworks Singula and Ventura reports in facilitating patient treatment decisions of pan-cancer patients. Other secondary outcomes are number of patients receiving treatment from the report, number of patients recommended other therapeutic modalities, molecular tumor board, physician specialty, number of orders, institution type and placement of orders.

[/INST] The study was designed as a two-arm, parallel group, double blind randomized controlled trial to investigate the effect of cognitive stimulation therapy on the levels of apathy, loneliness, anxiety and daily living activities in elderly individuals diagnosed with Alzheimer’s. 60 Alzheimer’s patients aged 60 years and older who had a mild Alzheimer’s diagnosis and a Standardized Mini-Mental Test (SMMT) score in the range of 18-23 were randomized into intervention or no-intervention groups. Cognitive Stimulation Therapy (CST) was applied in the intervention group 2 days a week for 14 sessions, each lasting 45-50 minutes. The cognitive functions of participants in both groups were evaluated using the Standardized Mini-Mental Test, Geriatric Anxiety Scale, Apathy Rating Scale, Loneliness Scale and Functional Disability in Dementia Scale. The levels of apathy, anxiety, loneliness, and daily living activities were compared pre- and post-CST interventions between the two groups to evaluate the effectiveness of CST intervention.

[/INST] The pAIn-sense project is a study that aims to discover physiological and psychological biomarkers that will characterize chronic pain conditions. The study intends to achieve this goal by using novel telemonitoring systems that combine wearable sensors and artificial intelligence to continuously monitor and evaluate pain levels and related factors. The system will be able to monitor pain during daily activities by collecting data on physical activity, heart rate, body temperature, skin conductance, blood volume pressure, and movement. Additionally, the system will collect psychological data through questionnaires on anxiety, depression, fatigue, pain catastrophizing, sleep, awareness, pain efficacy, treatment expectations, and quality of life. The study has not indicated the duration of the wearable sensor monitoring. The primary outcome measure will be the pain score, while the secondary outcome measures will be collected from the questionnaires and the biomarker data. It is unclear how this study will implement a telemonitoring system for pain management.

[/INST] Our team is interested in developing a technology-assisted communication application that can potentially benefit individuals who are disabled or who have limited mobility. The proposed study involves using a device called EarSwitch to collect audio-visual data from research participants. The study is comprised of three main parts: co-design, physical prototype development, and a validation protocol. The co-design includes a series of interviews with 10 participants to gather information on their needs and preferences related to the device. This information will then be used to develop a physical prototype of the EarSwitch device. The prototype will be evaluated through a series of participant validation experiments. The duration of the study is 6 months. The study will involve 10 eligible participants who are disabled or have limited mobility and will ask them to use the EarSwitch device for communication tasks. The primary outcome of the study will be the accuracy of detecting eardrum movements, which will be measured by the F-score, Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC), the receiver operating characteristics (ROC) curve, and the area under the ROC curve (AUC). We will determine whether the accuracy of detecting eardrum movements is the same between those who require assistive technology and those who do not, using the outcomes Q2 from the study.

[/INST] The study investigates the effects of different recovery strategies on the immune system, cardiometabolic markers, and endocrine response after 8 weeks of high-volume, large-scale, well-controlled exercise. Participants will be randomized into one of three groups: a control group (35 hours/week), a less exercise volume group (35 hours/week, but exercise volume reduced by 15%-30%), and an extended recovery group (35 hours/week of exercise with longer recovery intervals between exercises). The study will assess changes in health indices, including cardiometabolic, endocrine, and immune factors before and after 8 weeks of intervention. Performance measures and aerobic capacity will be used to define changes in performance at baseline, 4 weeks, and 8 weeks after the intervention.

[/INST] This study is evaluating the usefulness of 18F-PF-0644574 PET scans in detecting phosphodiesterase 4B in the brain for the diagnosis of major depressive disorder. The study aims to determine whether PDE4B can be accurately quantified in the human brain, whether it is reduced in patients with MDD, and whether it can predict response to treatment. Participants will undergo PET scans after being injected with a radioactive tracer, 18F-PF-0644574, and the tracer levels in various brain regions will be compared between healthy control subjects and subjects with MDD. The study also aims to determine the optimal length of PET scan required for accurate measurement of tracer levels in the brain. The results of this study may improve our understanding of the pathophysiology of MDD and may lead to the development of new treatments for MDD.

[/INST] A clinical trial on the importance of weight-bearing and flexion of the knee joint during magnetic resonance images (MRIs) to assess joint spaces of patients with osteoarthritis in the knee using a 0.25T scanner. The study examines the medial and lateral joint spaces, and the knee was positioned with weight bearing and joint flexion/extension. The four positions examined in one hour were fully loaded and unloaded extended knees, and flexed knees with body weight and without body weight. The primary outcome measures were the medial joint spaces, and the secondary outcome was the lateral joint space.

[/INST] The study is titled "At-Home Skill Training Using Biofeedback for Swallowing Rehabilitation in Parkinson’s Disease". It aims to evaluate the use of a tablet application to enhance swallowing exercises via biofeedback in Parkinson’s disease patients. The participants included in the study are diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease and have dysphagia. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial. The study will compare two groups, the experimental group who will receive the tablet application as an intervention, and the active comparator group who will receive behavioral swallowing therapy. The tablet application aims to improve not only the strength but also the skill of swallowing via biofeedback. The skill element in the tablet application is an innovative aspect as it includes training to improve the timing and precision of swallowing. The novelty of the tablet application lies in the incorporation of biofeedback and the focus on swallowing skill training, two components that are not typically combined in other swallowing training tools. It will be interesting to find out whether the tablet application can aid in improving swallowing safety and efficiency and improve dysphagia symptoms.

[/INST] The Global Burden of Estimation of Human Papillomavirus (GLOBE-HPV) is a comprehensive study that aims to comprehensively assess and understand the impact of HPV on public health, particularly in low socio-economic populations. The study has 14 cross-sectional survey (CSS) study groups among 8 participating countries, 3 urban and 6 rural CSS. An additional longitudinal study (LS) will involve selecting 5 of the 8 participating countries. The scope of the study includes estimating the prevalence of high-risk HPV (HPV 16 and/or 18) infection and the incidence of ≥6-month persistent HPV 16 and/or 18 infection. The study also explores knowledge, attitudes, and beliefs of HPV vaccination, cervical cancer screening, and treatment. Participant eligibility is aged 9-50 years, male or female, sexually active and able to understand and provide informed consent. The study will collect several types of data, including medical history, demographics, attitudes, knowledge and practices, anthropometrics, and biological or physical. Blood samples will also be collected.

[/INST] The primary outcome measures include the list learning test scores immediately after the intervention as well as at 1-month and 3-month follow-up visits, the name-face learning test scores immediately after the intervention as well as at 1-month and 3-month follow-ups, and the grocery learning test scores immediately after the intervention as well as at 1-month and 3-month follow-ups. The secondary outcome measures consist of the list learning test scores, name-face learning test scores, grocery learning test scores, associative learning test scores, and text learning test scores at 1 and 3 months after the intervention, which assess memory in different ways. The associative learning test measures word list paired associates, the list learning test measures verbal memory, the visual associative learning measures the ability to learn faces, the text learning test measures verbal memory, and the grocery learning test measures the ability to learn concrete words. In addition, an in-depth neuropsychological evaluation is conducted during three assessment visits, which evaluates memory and cognitive function using five tests: digit span, delayed digit span, digit symbol substitution, categorical verbal fluency, and a verbal recognition index.

[/INST] This is a protocol for a study aimed at developing and validating a model to predict the risk of heart failure using patient-level primary care data linked to secondary administrative data using multivariable Cox proportional hazard models to retains predictors.

[/INST] In the ISHYS trial, postmenopausal women were randomized to either resumption of sexual activity four or eight weeks after surgery. In the four-week group, 66% participants resumed sexual activity at four weeks. In the eight-week group, 66% participants resumed sexual activity at eight weeks. The difference in the number of subjects who resumed sexual intercourse in the two groups was not statistically significant. The mean global FSFI score was higher at eight weeks than at eight-weeks follow-up in both groups, but the difference was not significant. However, after four weeks, the mean FSFI score was higher in the eight-week group than the four-week group, indicating that resumption of intercourse at eight weeks may improve post-hysterectomy sexual function. The ISHYS study suggests that a delay of at least eight weeks, after hysterectomy, may reduce the negative impact of surgery on sexual function. However, the study findings are limited due to the small sample sizes of the groups studied.

[/INST] This clinical trial investigates the effect of testosterone supplementation on skeletal muscle mass and strength in healthy aging men. The study involves a control group and an experimental group. The control group received resistance training alone, while the experimental group received resistance training and testosterone undecanoate supplementation. The primary outcome measure is muscle mass measured through dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA). Other outcome measures include gene expression, mitochondrial respiration and oxidative capacity, methylation, strength, muscle contraction, and immunohistochemistry measures. Testosterone levels and side effects will also be examined in the study. The study protocol consists of two stages, with participation in both stages being optional. Study participation involves weekly clinic visits for four weeks. A follow-up will be conducted at month six.

[/INST] The provided clinical trial document describes the planned design and implementation of a study to assess the prevalence of Dengue virus infections in the Metropolitan Area of Buenos Aires, Argentina. The study uses a two-stage stratified design to select a sample of 1,487 participants aged ≥ 18 years residing in the study area. The study involves collecting finger prick blood samples from participants to determine specific anti-dengue antibodies using an immunoglobulin G antibody determination test. The study does not include information on the follow-up or outcomes of the study participants. The study was proposed due to the need for up-to-date information on the dengue seroprevalence and immunity levels in Argentina, especially in light of recent dengue outbreaks in the country and the potential for imported dengue cases through local airports. The study's findings will be useful for monitoring dengue circulation in the region and designing public health interventions.

[/INST] The goal of this study is to determine the clinical validity of the COVID-19 antigen Standard Q Rapid Diagnostic Test and the PANBIO COVID-19 Ag Rapid Test, and to assess algorithms based on antigen detection tests with or without PCR testing. The study will recruit 4,292 individuals based in Gaborone, Botswana. Study participants will be offered point-of-care antigen testing, which will include self-administration of a nasal swab for the antigen test and for collection of an oral swab or saliva if the antigen test is negative. After testing, participants will be referred to clinical care according to national screening and isolation policies. To evaluate the performance of the antigen test, PCR testing will be performed from a swab specimen taken at the testing site and paired with the antigen test. Performance of the antigen test and algorithms will be evaluated against PCR test results and clinical outcomes. Additionally, the study aims to identify the cost per test and case detected for each antigen RDT compared to PCR-based testing. The study is expected to be completed by November 30, 2023.

[/INST] Prediabetes is a condition in which an individual's blood sugar levels are higher than normal but not in the predefined diabetic range. In this study, the investigators are conducting a randomized trial to examine the effects of dietary and lifestyle interventions on glycemic control in individuals with prediabetes. The participants will be provided with continuous glucose monitoring devices, Fitbit fitness tracker, and an app to log food intake. They will be required to consume a glucose-equivalent meal after fasting in the morning and to engage in an exercise before breakfast at specific times, in addition to following varying diets (e.g., high-fat meal, high-protein meal, or a high-fiber meal). Participants will also undergo an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) and an intravenous glucose tolerance test (IVGTT) to assess glucose metabolism. The specific aims of the study are as follows: (1) compare the mitigation effect of different foods and exercise mitigators on blood glucose levels before and after the consumption of a standardized rice meal; (2) investigate postprandial metabolite responses to different diets and exercise mitigators over 10 days using micro-sampling; (3) examine postprandial changes in the proteome and metabolome in response to different types of food intake and exercise activity; and (4) compare postprandial metabolic responses during the day.
