[/INST] The study Operant Conditioning of Sensory Brain Responses to Reduce Phantom Limb Pain is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of operant conditioning with peripheral sensory stimulation in reducing phantom limb pain. Participants will undergo three 1-hour sessions per week for 8-9 weeks, participating in a training paradigm of operant conditioning, which aims to strengthen weakened central pathways in post-amputee participants. The study also will analyze various neurophysiological responses to better understand the underlying mechanisms.

[/INST] Axillary vein catheterization is a procedure that involves the insertion of a catheter into the axillary vein for the purpose of drawing blood for laboratory tests, providing fluids or medication, or setting up monitoring. In this study, the procedure's accuracy, safety, efficacy, and complications, as well as patient prognosis, were evaluated. The study population consisted of adult or adolescent trauma patients. Ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization was performed on eligible participants within 24 hours after admission to the intensive care unit. The study's primary outcome was the correct positioning of the tip of a central venous catheter (CVC) between the tracheal carina and within 2cm downward for measuring central venous pressure (CVP) or invasive hemodynamic monitoring. The catheter was used, and the secondary outcome was puncture complications, venous thrombosis events, intensive care unit (TICU) mortality, TICU length of stay, and duration of ventilator support. The patients were categorized according to whether or not any of these outcomes occurred. The results showed that ultrasound-guided catheterization was as accurate as the landmark technique, and it was more likely to be safe than the landmark technique. Ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization can effectively reduce the incidence of accidental catheter tip misposition and venous catheter-related subcutaneous hematoma; compared with catheterization of the upper limb vein, it is more likely to cause damage to the artery, and its use does not affect mortality and duration of mechanical ventilation.

[/INST] Cevostamab Following CAR T Cell Therapy for RRMM was a phase II clinical study at the National Institutes of Health (NIH) that examined the efficacy of cevostamab consolidation therapy after BCMA CAR T cell therapy for relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma (MM). BCMA is a protein that is overexpressed on the surface of MM cells, making it a promising target for CAR T cell therapy. However, despite initial success with CAR T cell therapy against MM, this study found that many patients experienced recurrence of the disease, highlighting the need for additional treatments or consolidation therapies to improve outcomes. Patients who were enrolled in the study received standard of care BCMA CAR T cell therapy, followed by cycles of cevostamab consolidation therapy every three weeks after infusion. The main goal of the study was to assess the efficacy of cevostamab consolidation therapy in patients with relapsed or refractory MM, as measured by the proportion of patients who achieved MRD-negative complete remission at 12 months post-CAR T cell therapy. MRD is defined as the small number of cancer cells that may remain in a patient despite treatment, and complete remission is considered the best possible outcome for MM patients. The authors found that at 12 months, only 8% of patients who received cevostamab consolidation had achieved MRD-negative complete remission. In addition, the study found that cevostamab had limited efficacy in many patients, with over half experiencing disease progression by 100 days post-CAR T cell therapy. Overall, the findings from this study suggest that cevostamab consolidation therapy does not improve outcomes for MM patients when used after standard of care BCMA CAR T cell therapy.

[/INST] This study is a randomized controlled trial examining the effect of ultrasound therapy on core muscles function in patients with visceral adiposity. The treatment consists of two interventions: rehabilitative ultrasonography imaging (RUSI), which is used to visualize the contraction of the diaphragm muscle, and cavitation ultrasonic lipolysis (CUSL), which is used to melt visceral fat. The study compares the RUSI treatment to CUSL, RUSI combined with CUSL treatment, and a control group without treatment. The RUSI and CUSL groups received 2 interventions per week for 10 weeks. The diaphragm excursion and transverse abdominal muscles contraction ratio, as well as visceral fat thickness and waist circumference, were measured at the beginning and end of the study. The study recruited 45 subjects with visceral adiposity aged 25 to 45 years and a BMI of 25 to 29.9 kg/m2. The study found that CUSL decreased waist circumference and visceral fat thickness, while RUSI and combined RUSI/CUSL decreased visceral fat thickness at 10 weeks. Both RUSI-only and RUSI/CUSL-treated patients showed increased diaphragm excursion and transabdominal contraction ratio at 10 weeks.

[/INST] The title of the study is "The impact of atrial fibrosis surface area on atrial fibrillation (AF) in patients with ischemic stroke of undetermined origin". This is a prospective, observational, single-arm study of patients who received cardiac MRI with contrast agent. Patients were included in the study if they had an ischemic stroke, no history of AF, no long-term anticoagulation therapy, and had not underwone cardiac MRI with contrast agent. The primary outcome measure was the occurrence of an AF episode lasting more than 30 s at 3-year follow-up

[/INST] The objective of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the transitional care program (TCP) for reducing hospital admissions and emergency department visits within 30 days after discharge from the hospital or emergency department. The program involved educational and organizational interventions designed to support patients during the transition from hospital to home care and improve their healthcare literacy and access to care. The primary outcome of the study was a reduction in unplanned post-discharge hospital admissions within 30 days of discharge. The secondary outcomes included changes in patients' self-efficacy in managing their health, hospital and emergency department utilization, and patient-perceived quality of care. The study found that the TCP significantly reduced hospital admissions in both the study group and the control group . However, as pointed out by the Centre Hospitalier Valida, there was significant difference in the baseline status of the study group and the control group, which limits the generalizability of the results of the study. The Centre Hospitalier Valida emphasized the importance of a clearly defined patient population and interventions for a rigorous, reliable evaluation of the effectiveness of the TCP.

[/INST] Follitropin delta is a recombinant fusion protein that consists of a modified FSH molecule and IGF-1. This study is a retrospective study that examined high-dose follitropin delta in addition to human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) in a mixed regimen with human menopausal gonadotropin (hMG) in combination with an antagonist cycle. The retrospective study examined 1,192 women who underwent IVF with the first treatment cycle using follitropin delta in a high dose in combination with hCG regimens. The regimen was administered according to anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) and weight. The cycle’s outcomes were assessed, and the results showed that the high-dose follitropin delta regimen demonstrated a significantly increased number of oocytes that were available for fertilization per patient compared to the control group (14.0 vs. 11.7, respectively; p < 0.001) and decreased embryo quality (77.5 vs. 72%, respectively). However, no significant difference was observed in the number of good-quality blastocysts obtained from oocytes (p = 0.4). Further analysis of follitropin delta regimen showed that the dose of follitropin delta and the duration of antagonist cycle were inversely correlated with the number of oocytes collected and the number of embryos transferred. The conclusion is that the follitropin delta in a mixed regimen with hCG or HP-hMG in an antagonist cycle had a significant effect on the outcome of stimulation and the number of oocytes in an IVF cycle but a no significant effect on blastocyst quality. The study highlights the importance of designing the dose of follitropin delta according to the individual characteristics of a patient, such as AMH, body weight, and duration of the antagonist cycle. Further studies are required to study the follitropin delta in different protocols. This could provide a more effective treatment for patients seeking IVF treatment.

[/INST] The clinical trial titled "Penetrating the Classroom Social Network for Children With Language Impairment Via Peer Mediated Intervention" is described. The study involves 25 inclusive preschool classrooms. The study estimates the treatment impact of a peer-mediated pivotal response intervention on the social, behavioral, and linguistic outcomes for focal children with low pragmatic language and with social exclusion. The intervention is delivered to focal children by their classroom peer mediators, children who, as a group, have received training and support from a teacher facilitator to deliver the intervention during the classroom center time. The key components of the intervention are the identification and selection criteria for peer mediators, the training of peer mediators, and the ongoing support of peer mediators delivered by teacher facilitators. Teacher facilitators are trained during a one-on-one 1-h training session after being identified by their teachers and school psychologists. Peer mediators hold four 15-minute training sessions with the teacher facilitator to engage with the target child. Peer mediators receive ongoing support from their teacher facilitator during the remaining period of the study. The target child also receives peer communication coaching by peer mediators from months 3 to 6 of the 9-month intervention period. The intervention will be investigated by collecting language and social communication data from the focal children and peer mediators and conducting a questionnaire to evaluate the views and experiences of the children, teachers, and parents with respect to the intervention. The authors conclude that behavioral indicators, such as social communication and language outcomes, are critical for children with ASD and have potential to be improved by penetrating the social networks of these children and their classmates. The researchers hope that the outcomes will yield an intervention that will affect the social well-being of children with language impairment and have immediate and enduring implications for the classroom inclusion of such children.

[/INST] The study is titled "Cerebral Perfusion Variation During Blood Pressure Changes Under General Anesthesia" and aims to identify a significant linear relationship between the percentage change in the velocity of the blood in the middle cerebral artery, Vm, and the percentage change in the Spectral Frontal Edge Frequency 95, SEF95, during the controlled BP changes performed according to the protocol. The study will be conducted in a single country and patients aged 18 and above who are undergoing surgery will be included. The sample size is estimated to be 64 participants. Blood pressure changes will be performed according to the BP limits set in the current guidelines. Vm and SEF95 will be continuously monitored throughout the procedures and changes in BP. The aim of the study is to understand the cerebral blood flow during changes in BP, identify a significant relationship between Vm and SEF95 and contribute to the knowledge of the effects of BP changes in cerebral blood flow. The use of standard BP targets for all patients is not appropriate because they do not take into account the individual variability in cerebrovascular autoregulation and cardiovascular comorbidity. The results of this study may lead to the definition of individually tailored BP targets which may ensure optimal cerebral perfusion during general anesthesia.

[/INST] The authors of this clinical trial compare the outcomes of natural cycle frozen embryo transfer to substituted cycle FET (frozen embryo transfer) in women up to the age of 40. The trial includes patients who had experienced at least 3 failed embryo transfers, uterine abnormalities, abnormal hormonal profiles, or a history of recurrent miscarriages. The trial randomized patients into 2 groups: FET substituted cycle and FET natural cycle with the outcome of clinical pregnancy rate per embryo transfer. Additionally, the study evaluated the miscarriage rate, multiple pregnancy rates, and the endometrial thickness of each group.

[/INST] The objective of this clinical trial is to evaluate the efficacy of intravenous vs. inhalational anesthesia on the incidence of postoperative delirium and cognitive dysfunction in older adults undergoing noncardiac surgery. The study will use a randomized, double-blinded, and parallel-arm design. Participants aged ≥ 75 years who are scheduled for elective, inpatient, noncardiac surgery will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (propofol-based anesthesia) or control group (sevoflurane-based anesthesia) in ratio 1:1. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of postoperative delirium in both non-intubated patients and intubated patients using the Confusion Assessment Method in the Intensive Care Unit (CAM-ICU) at postoperative PACU and daily for 3 days. The secondary outcome measures are delirium duration and severity, measured by the CAM-ICU-7; incidence of postoperative neurocognitive disorder, measured by Neuropsychiatric Composite Score; 30-day mortality and ICU, hospital, and home discharge; and the incidence of postoperative functional decline using the ADL, FAQ, and FRAIL, and Patient-reported outcome measures (PROMIS-29+2 Profile v2.1). The outcomes will be measured preoperatively, postoperatively in the PACU, and daily from postoperative day 1 to 3 at the post-anesthesia care unit or intensive care unit, and at 3 and 12 months. Blood samples will be obtained for concentrations of biomarkers including p-tau181, GFAP, HMGB1, NfL, S100 β, IL-1β, IL-6, IL-10, and TNF-α preoperatively and postoperatively up to 3 months. Data will be collected by the research team at the appropriate time points. The total duration of the study is 168 months (2019 to 2034).

[/INST] This study titled "Nutritional Assessment in Children with Congenital Heart Disease" is an observational study that aims to assess the nutritional status of children under one month to 18 years of age who have congenital heart disease. The study will measure one outcome measure, specifically assessing the nutritional status of study participants to develop a protocol for avoiding nutritional deficiencies and achieving normal growth in congenital heart disease patients through anthropometric measures such as weight, length, head circumference, mid-arm circumference, BMI, and age of weaning. The study exclusion criteria include conditions such as severe sepsis, endocarditis, empyema, autoimmune diseases, and liver cirrhosis, as well as children receiving immunosuppressive therapy. The study will be conducted over a one-year period.

[/INST] This is a prospective randomized phase II trial of PH CEST guided resection in glioblastoma. Participants will be randomized to PH CEST guided resection or standard of care resection. The follow up schedule is: pre-surgery, post-surgery and 1, 3, 6, 9 months post-surgery. The primary outcomes are PFS and OS. The secondary outcome is QoL.

[/INST] This is a cross-sectional study conducted at Nyala Specialized Hospital in Darfur. All Sudanese patients who live in Darfur and are above the age of 18 years with urinary bladder masses who give consent are included in the study, while patients who do not reside in Darfur are excluded. The primary outcome is the patterns of urinary bladder cancer in Darfur, Sudan, which is an investigation of the clinical outcomes, etiology, histology, and demographic distribution of the disease. Study duration is from 2020 to 2022.

[/INST] The objective of this clinical trial is to investigate the correlation between mental stress and bowel preparation in patients undergoing colonoscopy. The trial will include 1000 patients with an indication for colonoscopy who will be assessed by questionnaire for enrollment based on inclusion/exclusion criteria. Inclusion criteria are patients aged 18-75 years with no history of cancer or inflammatory bowel disease that may be affected by mental stress and are able to communicate and understand the content of the questionnaire. Exclusion criteria are patients who withdraw prior to colonoscopy, with any reason that renders them unable to undergo the study. A comparison of mental stress levels and bowel preparation quality to determine the relationship between them will be conducted using the Boston Bowel Preparation Scale (BPS) by colonoscopists who are trained in using the scale. Withdrawal of consent prior to colonoscopy or due to a health condition that contraindicates colonoscopy will be the main reasons for the potential exclusion of participants.

[/INST] This protocol describes a pilot randomized controlled study designed to investigate the short and long term beneficial effects of playful interactions on psychological and cognitive aspects and explore the relationship between traits, cognitive abilities, and beneficial interactive effects. The study involves both face to face interaction session in addition to an online equivalent within a senior community center, an adult day center and nursing home in Israel. Participants will be randomly assigned to four conditions (experimental and control). It is hypothesized that participants will improve their mood, cognitive performance, social skills, flow state and reduce loneliness regardless they practice face to face and online playful interactions.

[/INST] Skillflix for Parents is a web-based intervention designed to enhance sexual health communication skills in parents of teens with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the Skillflix for Parents intervention by examining changes in parent and teen outcomes in three domains: parent's skill, frequency, and confidence in discussing sexual health with their teen; teens' frequency, confidence in discussing sexual health with their parent; family sexual communication; teens' sexual health knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors.

[/INST] The aim of the study is to investigate the level of DDX17 and GSDMD in sepsis patients and its correlation with disease progression and prognosis. The study is observational and involves patients who are diagnosed with sepsis. Patients are categorized as survival and non-survival group based on the 28-day mortality. Sample collection includes 3 mL of peripheral blood drawn on day 1, day 3 and day 7. Laboratory tests are performed on the plasma, including leukocyte count, procalcitonin (PCT) and high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hs-CRP) on day 1, day 3 and day 7. The clinical significance of the study is to provide a reference for the treatment and prognosis in sepsis patients. Further information on the study can be obtained using the reference #1.

[/INST] "A Single-center Prospective Study of Non-invasive Methods for the Diagnosis of Postoperative Complications in Liver Transplant Recipients will be conducted, assessing Early Allograft dysfunction (EAD), defined as Olthoff criteria: bilirubin ≥10 mg/dL in the 7th post-operative day, international normalized ratio (INR) ≥1.6 in 7th post-operative day 7; ALT or AST> 2000 IU/L during the first 7 days after liver transplantation. Enrolment: patients eligible for liver transplantation following National and International Guidelines. Exclusion: No agreement or inability to give informed consent, Re-transplant patients, liver transplant in fulminant hepatitis. The primary analysis aims to demonstrate the value of non-invasive methods for EAD using Olthoff criteria. The study will include 107 patients who have undergone liver transplantation. The diagnosis of EAD will be based on the Olthoff criteria, and patients who meet these criteria will be considered positive. At the end of the study, findings will be compared with results obtained from conventional tests such as biochemical liver function tests and blood tests, and the applicability of non-invasive methods will be evaluated. The trial is carried out at a single center."

[/INST] The trial is a phase II, multi-center, randomized controlled study in a parallel assignment, with the Stupp protocol plus placebo being the experimental group and the Stupp protocol alone being the comparison group. The investigators aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of the Stupp protocol plus Elemene versus the Stupp protocol alone by using the 12-month overall survival rate (12-mOS) as the primary end point.

[/INST] Prone position in infants/children with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is commonly used to improve oxygenation. This trial investigates whether the sequence of prone position in ARDS patients prior to mechanical ventilation and proning following mechanical ventilation reduces the number of intubations and days from intubation to transfer to the intensive care unit.

[/INST] The study aims to investigate the effects of progressive muscle relaxation training on pain characteristics, attack frequency, activity self-efficacy perceptions, and social participation in female patients with migraine or tension-type headaches. Both intervention groups receive a 6-week course of progressive muscle relaxation training twice a week, with each session lasting 30 minutes.

[/INST] This study is a case- control clinical trial that will examine the relationship between microRNA expression levels and neurodevelopmental outcomes in infants with neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome. Infants with chronic in-utero opioid exposure of at least 1 month gestation will be recruited. Two sets of buccal swab samples of salivary RNA will be taken: one at 24 hours of life and one at discharge. MicroRNAs let-7a, miR-146a, and miR-192 will be measured and compared to one another. A higher incidence of microRNA is expected in children with higher symptoms of neonatal abstinence syndrome and higher neurodevelopmental problem. Neurodevelopmental outcomes will be measured using the Ages and Stages Questionnaire-3 at 6 months of age and the maximum concentration of morphine required will be monitored at 24 hours of life. Overall, this study aims to identify microRNA markers that can predict neurodevelopmental outcomes in children born with opioid withdrawal syndrome and help provide appropriate interventions as early as possible.

[/INST] The aim of this study was to examine the effect of patient education on pain in orthopedic and traumatology patients. This single-center, prospective, randomized controlled trial included 52 patients who underwent orthopedic and surgical operation in the Turkish hospital. Patient education on pain and pain control was given to the intervention group, while the control group did not receive such education. Preoperative pain, fear of pain, and postoperative pain level were assessed. The effect of patient education on pain control was evaluated. The mean age in the intervention group and control group was 46.7 and 51.1 years, respectively. There was no significant difference in preoperative visual/visual analogue pain, fear of pain, and postoperative pain levels between the two groups. Mean preoperative pain and fear of pain levels significantly differed based on group (p < 0.001), unlike postoperative pain and fear of pain levels (p > 0.05). The main limitations of this study were the small sample size and high male majority. Therefore, further studies with larger sample sizes and appropriate statistical power are needed to clarify the role of patient education in pain control in orthopedic and traumatology patients. Further research is also needed to clarify how frequently patient education should be provided and how to best use non-pharmacological approaches to achieve effective pain control in this challenging population.

[/INST] This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial to investigate the effectiveness of the transdermal delivery of buprenorphine for women receiving medication-assisted treatment for opioid use disorder during pregnancy. The primary outcome measure is the severity of induction withdrawal, while the secondary outcome measures are induction success, treatment adherence, and recovery success. Recruitment for the trial is open and enrollment is ongoing, until the target sample size has been reached.

[/INST] The purpose of this study is to evaluate the relationship between TcpO2 (Transcutaneous Oxygen Pressure) values recorded during a dynamic test in patients suspected of a thoracic outlet syndrome. The patients have undergone additional examinations as part of their diagnostic assessment, such as dynamic arteriography and venography, together with venous and arterial Doppler. The DROPmin (TcpO 2 variation regarding a reference) according to the type of damage (arterial, venous, or both arterial and venous) and the degree of arterial stenosis will be evaluated. [/INST] The clinical trial is a feasibility study of a mobile application (Mobile phone app-SmartCP) for symptom monitoring in patients with chronic pancreatitis. The aim is to assess the feasibility of such an app, with regard to recruitment and retention, acceptability and user acceptance. The secondary outcome measures are to identify if the app improves symptoms and quality of life, the number of crisis calls, A&E attendances and admissions, the number of people using the education and communication features that help pancreatic management.

[/INST] Title: Anal Fissure Among Survivors of COVID-19 Virus Infection, Risk Factors and Outcome. A Single Center Experience.Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is an infectious disease caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, fatigue, dyspnea, sore throat, and cough (Ledford, 2020). Approximately 10–20% of COVID-19 patients develop severe illness, including acute respiratory distress syndrome, septic shock, and multiple organ dysfunction or failure, which can be life-threatening. The average incubation period of COVID-19 is about five days, but it can range from two to 14 days (Ledford, 2020).

[/INST] The purpose of this study is to compare the efficacy of two treatments on wound healing following palatal connective tissue harvesting. A total of 20 patients with recession defect were recruited and randomly assigned to the test group (L-PRF application to donor site) or the control group (suture of donor site). Both groups were assessed ultrasonographically in terms of tissue thickness and mucosal pulsatility index at the predetermined time intervals. The results suggested that L-PRF application may improve ultrasonographic parameters associated with healing of palatal connective tissue harvesting site. Further studies are required to corroborate the findings.

[/INST] The ARRC III trial aims to assess the effectiveness of advanced recovery care in patients after surgery, compared to usual ward care. The trial will measure the number of days spent at home at 90 days after surgery (primary outcome), medical emergency response complications, mortality and cost-effectiveness. The trial includes patients age 18 or older who are scheduled for elective or unplanned surgery and are expected to stay in hospital at least one night after surgery. The trial excluded patients undergoing cardiac surgery and those scheduled for postoperative intensive care management. The trial will last up to 18 months. The findings might provide a robust mechanism to ensure outcomes are maintained in the institution, and ideally improve these outcomes, provide a mechanism to allow benchmarking in the future across centers, better identify the subgroups of patients who benefit from the ARRC, and provide an important resource to generate hypotheses on the reasons for the reported benefits.

[/INST] The MOBILe PrEP Implementation Trial is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effectiveness and implementation of oral PrEP and LAI PrEP among men in sub-Saharan Africa. The trial will be conducted in Uganda and South Africa over a period of 24 months. The trial will assess the effectiveness of oral PrEP and LAI PrEP in terms of adherence, retention in care, and coital coverage. Additionally, the trial will compare the adoption, persistence, and effectiveness of oral PrEP and LAI PrEP. The trial aims to provide evidence on the choice of PrEP for men in sub-Saharan Africa.

[/INST] Our research project aims to preform a preliminary evaluation of the psycho-emotional state of patients diagnosed with Temporomandibular Disorder (TMD). A total of 263 patients were recruited, comprising both a study group (130 TMD patients) and a control group (130 patients without TMD symptoms). Participants completed a questionnaire survey which assessed their emotional state over the past four weeks in relation to their TMD disorder. The survey included 30 questions regarding aspects of emotional irritability, lowered mood, and isolation. Responses were scored on a scale of 0-4 for most favorable-least favorable. The primary outcome measure for this study was the result of the questionnaire survey. The questionnaire scores were divided into four sections: A-D. The study was conducted over a four-year period from 2018 through 2023.

[/INST] The study titled "Effects of Touch on Brain Connectivity and Metabolic Biomarkers in Preterm Infants" is a clinical trial with preterm infants between the ages of 32 and 33.6 weeks. The study is designed to be randomized and double-blind. There are three groups of participants: an experimental group that receives therapeutic touch, an active comparator group that receives affective touch, and a placebo comparator group that receives static touch. The primary outcome measure is the change in BOLD levels in various brain areas before and after the intervention. Secondary outcome measures involve the change from baseline in the EEG power in slow delta waves band, 1H NMR, and metabolites from urine samples. The study is conducted at the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit in Santa Clara University.

[/INST] The study will include 63 patients at most between the age of 4 and 100 years, who have sickle cell disease and complication of acute chest syndrome, stroke, pulmonary hypertension or renal injury. The treatment will consist a non-myeloablative haploidentical hematopoietic cell transplantation with briquilimab antibody and abatacept. The patients will be evaluated by a regimen success rate score, engraftment and incidence of acute grade 3 or higher graft-versus-host disease or moderate to severe chronic graft-versus-host disease evaluated at 1 year post- transplant among others.

[/INST] The title of this study is "A Randomized Comparison of Microfluidic Chip vs Density Gradient Centrifugation on the Euploid Rate of Pre-implantation Genetic Testing." The study is comparing two methods of sperm preparation, microfluidic chip and density gradient centrifugation, for the rate of euploid of blastocysts in pre-implantation genetic testing. The study is being conducted in China from 2018-2025 and is being conducted on 1118 pregnant women. The outcomes being reported are the euploid rate of blastocysts, the live birth rate of the first embryo transfer, the positive urine pregnancy test rate per first embryo transfer, the clinical pregnancy rate of the first embryo transfer, the ongoing pregnancy rate, the miscarriage rate of pregnancy, the multiple pregnancy rate, the DNA fragmentation, the ectopic pregnancy rate, and the average blastocyst transferred. The study used a single-blinded randomized design.

[/INST] This study is titled as "Brain derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) gene polymorphism as a risk factor for allergic rhinitis" and is aimed to investigate the association of BDNF gene single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) with allergic rhinitis. The study will measure the level of nerve growth factor (NGF), interleukin-1 (IL-1), and c-reactive protein (CRP). To investigate the association, DNA samples will be extracted from the blood using centrifuge and real-time polymerase chain reaction. The primary measure for the study is that the association between BDNF gene SNP and the risk of allergic rhinitis will be tested through the analysis of variance (ANOVA). The study will be conducted for two months duration with 100 patients from the King Khaled Medical Center, Riyadh, KSA.

[/INST] This study aimed to evaluate the effect of the Mindfulness-Based Intervention (MBI) program on EEG brain activity, cognitive, and psychological well-being in elderly people. Participants were recruited from local organizations and assessed to check their cognitive and psychological status and EEG. The MBI program involved group education sessions that introduced participants to multiple mindfulness practices, and they were requested to also practice these exercises regularly at home. The trial examined changes in dispositional mindfulness, verbal memory, and interoceptive body awareness on the FFM Scale, the California Verbal Learning Test, and the Multidimensional Assessment of Interoceptive Awareness (MAIA) Scale from baseline to 8 weeks post-intervention. Additionally, the Alpha band EEG activity of the participants is also being studied in this trial.

[/INST] The main objective of this trial is to investigate the prevalence of Mycoplasma Genitalium and associated antimicrobial resistance among HIV-infected male individuals in Hong Kong. The trial will enroll 750 HIV-infected male individuals aged 18 years or older who attend a specialist clinic. An online questionnaire will be self-administered, and the participants will provide self-collected urine, rectal, and pharyngeal samples to assess Mycoplasma Genitalium and other sexually transmitted infections. The prevalence of Mycoplasma Genitalium infection and associated macrolide and fluoroquinolone resistance will be evaluated along with other sexually transmitted infections and HIV prevalence.

[/INST] Summary Statement: 18F-FES PET/CT is commonly used to detect high glucose metabolic activity. For breast cancer, it helps detect ER expression in tumors with low or no ER activity. By applying 18F-FES PET/CT, the study aims to identify the clinical efficacy of the combination of Dalpiciclib and endocrine therapy for breast cancer patients who have previously received CDK4/6 inhibitors.

[/INST] FISSION is a prospective, multicenter, single-arm study of XELOX combined with Fruquintinib and Sintilimab in China. The trial includes 30 patients with previously untreated advanced gastric cancer with liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastases. A combination of capecitabine, oxaliplatin, fruquintinib, and sintilimab will be used. The primary endpoint is PFS, and the secondary endpoint is OS. Further outcomes in the trial are ORR, DCR, DOR, and safety. The follow-up is two years.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial with the primary aim to evaluate the short-term and long-term impact of alternative incentives, such as charitable donations, on step count of older adult participants. The investigators aim to evaluate the impact on step count in short-term 8 weeks and long-term using the 2 week follow up data. The study will evaluate the impact of a meal donation and a point donation toward Feeding America with Fitbit Flex step count as outcome. There are two study arms: treatment group (step count reported daily and wear a Fitbit Charge HR). Study participants will be randomized to either group. The treatment group will receive an additional incentive compared to the control group, which will not get the additional incentive. The treatment group will receive a step goal of 7,500 steps per day to be assigned a donated meal to a person in need from Feeding America. A study volunteer will collect the meal donations weekly from Feeding America. The study will recruit 200 participants from grocery stores, pharmacies, medical offices, and via flyers and social media across San Diego, CA, US. To be eligible, participants must be ages 55 and above, own a smartphone, walk independently for fun and/or exercise, and walk at least once a week. They cannot be physically active enough to log 7,500 steps a day at baseline. The study will collect data from the participants' Fitbit Flex step count. Meals will be donated for 5 weeks to the treatment group, which is the period of time where the study participants will receive treatment. The study will collect Fitbit step count data for the last week prior to treatment, and the last week of treatment, as baseline step count. The study will collect post-treatment data for the two weeks after treatment for a follow-up step count. Study participants will not be compensated for their participation in the study. The estimated completion of the trial will be in June 2021. The study will collect data from participants through a website on the study and the study coordinators, including the PI, will collect data through Fitbit Flex. The study will measure change in step count, Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D) scores, and donation information.

[/INST] The interrupted time series study will be conducted at the Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital (MTRH) and will evaluate the effectiveness of wireless vital signs monitoring (neoGuard) in newborn patients. The study will measure the nurse's response time to patients in distress, percentage of actionable alarms, and incidence of patient complications. neoGuard will be installed in 4 sub-units, and 4 sub-units will continue to receive the standard-of-care/current practice (non-wireless monitoring). The study outcome measures will be captured through logs, reviews of patient files, and feedback surveys. The study will include 1000 eligible patients and be completed in 40 weeks. The study aims to evaluate if the neoGuard system is beneficial in terms of patient clinical outcomes, feasibility, and costs. The study will compare the intervention and standard-of-care groups and examine the effectiveness of the neoGuard system. The study will measure the rate of actionable alarms, nurse's response time to patients in distress, and incidence of newborn complications in both groups. The study will be completed by September 2023.

[/INST] Participants are patients with a soft tissue sarcoma of the limbs or trunk who undergo surgery to remove. Patients are assigned for either a neo-adjuvant or adjuvant radiation therapy. The primary outcome is the rate of patients free of major surgical complications evaluated at 6 months. The secondary outcomes are disease-free survival at 3 years, surgical and radiation therapy’s complications, wound disordes, healing time, patients’ quality of life and patient autonomy and geriatric parameters.

[/INST] -The study used data from the medical records of 98 patients with Head and Neck Cancer that was collected over the span of 1 year. The majority of the patients (63%) were between the ages of 50 and 59 at the time of diagnosis, and 94% were male. The data was analyzed using Stastical Package for Social Sciences (SPSS) version 22.

[/INST] The goal of this study is to test the impact of a health communication message, designed to educate and activate parents about their child's risk for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), on whether children receive an OSA referral. Health communication message will inform parents on various symptoms of OSA and encourage them to speak with their child's primary care provider about OSA. The primary outcome will be the rate of completed OSA referral, which refers to those who receive either a sleep study or ENT referral. The hypothesis is that parents receiving an OSA health communication message will increase the rate of completed OSA referral.

[/INST] The UPlift study is a phase 4 clinical trial involving patients with moderate-to-severe Crohn's disease. The trial assesses the speed of onset and duration of effectiveness of upadacitinib, a medication used to manage Crohn's disease, in real-world clinical practice settings. The UPlift study is designed to collect data on clinical outcomes, healthcare resource utilization, quality of life, and the safety of upadacitinib over a 3-year period. Patients who participate in the UPlift study will be prescribed upadacitinib according to the label indications.

[/INST] This study, "Testing of Online Version of QAPS," is a descriptive observational study designed to assess prewriting skills in children as they learn to write letters, copy shapes, and practice scissor skills. The study was conducted with participants aged 3 to 7 years old, and participants completed four functional hand tasks and filled out various surveys. The study's primary outcome measure was the Online QAPS assessment, which measured the children's replication of different shapes on a touch-screen tablet. Other outcome measures included the Beery VMI; functional hand tasks, which measured the children's scissors skills and handwriting; demographics surveys; emotionality assessment; strengths and difficulties questionnaire's inattention/hyperactivity subscale; and the ego resiliency scale. The study also included caregiver surveys that assessed the children's difficulty with prewriting skills, as well as the parents' assessment of their child's development. The study found that children's prewriting skills progressed through the different writing stages, including scribbling, letter formation, prewriting, and writing. Additionally, the study demonstrated the feasibility of using the online QAPS assessment tool and identified areas for further improvement to optimize accuracy, consistency, and efficiency in measuring progress in children's prewriting skills.

[/INST] Critical Time Intervention-Peer Support is a 9-month intervention program for people with serious mental illness discharged from an inpatient psychiatric treatment facility. The program aims to collaborate with recipients to develop durable connections to supports, facilitate autonomous engagement with community services, and expand social networks. The study aims to assess the effectiveness of this program compared to the control group in improving quality of life, assessed by the WHOQOL-BREF.

[/INST] The “Registry for Vascular Trauma and Follow-up Examinations” (RCTFE) is a registry of vascular injuries that aims to evaluate outcomes after interdisciplinary treatments, such as revascularizations and amputations. Participants must be over 18 years old and have vascular trauma as the primary injury. Exclusions include minors, those who have not given consent at the time of enrolment, and those who do not agree to future follow-up examinations.

[/INST] The study aims to determine the impact of implementing tourniquet-based blood flow restriction (BFR) as an adjunct to standard rehabilitation protocol on skeletal outcomes in patients with distal radius fractures. The trial will assess bone mineral density, body composition, grip strength, range of motion and functional outcomes in patients undergoing ORIF surgery. The results suggest that the clinical trial will provide valuable information regarding the efficacy of using BFR therapy in conjunction with standard rehabilitation protocol for distal radius fractures.

[/INST] Workplace Intervention to Reduce Sitting Time: a Randomized Clinical Trial protocol: The aim of this study is to determine the effect of a Stand up for your Health® computer app intervention on reducing office worker sedentary behaviour. Two groups will be randomized to receive either the Stand up for your Health® intervention (intervention condition) or a short leaflet containing advice on workplace sedentary behaviour (control condition) for a 6-month period. All subjects must be healthy, full-time office workers who spend over 60% of their time sitting, and who are willing to be part of the study with minimal follow-up . The protocol has not been registered.

[/INST] This is a randomized, double-blinded study on the chronic effects of low-load blood flow restriction and creatine supplementation in women. Participants will be aged between 18 and 35 years, of recreationally active level, and who are not currently taking creatine supplement and not pregnant. The study will last about 27 visits over a period of 10 weeks. It will include several interventions and comparisons, such as creatine supplementation or no supplementation (control), low-load blood flow restriction during exercise or no blood flow restriction when exercising (active comparator), blood flow restriction during exercise or no blood flow restriction when exercising and creatine (placebo comparator). Participants will perform strength tests, submit blood samples, and complete questionnaires in some of the visits. The study's primary outcome measures are isokinetic strength assessments performed in the upper leg muscles, body composition, neuromuscular function tests, and endothelial function tests. The secondary outcomes include mood state questionnaires. After 10 weeks of the protocol, the researchers will measure the above outcomes again and assess the effects of creatine supplementation and low-load blood flow restriction exercise.

[/INST] This clinical trial protocol outlines proposed research, in order to determine whether Neurofilament light chain (Nfl), Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), and Growth Differentiation Factor-15 (GDF-15) are potential bio- markers for anorexia nervosa. This study will include a number of patients, with anorexia nervosa and of control group, and will undergo blood testing. This paper also provides related terms.

[/INST] The ProSPECT study is a prospective, observational study with the objective of recording the complications and other information related to pleural procedures performed for patients who have pleural fluid. The study is designed to collect data from patients who are aged 18 years or older, undergoing pleural interventions such as chest drains, pleural biopsy, and medical thoracoscopy. The primary outcome measure is to record the complications within 30 days of the intervention, which includes specific complications such as bleeding, infection, pneumothorax, organ injury, pain, re-expansion pulmonary oedema. The secondary outcome measure is patient-reported measures of dyspnoea and chest pain. The majority of data will be collected from tertiary referral centres that conduct pleural interventions and include a combination of district general and tertiary referral centres, which represent best practice but should also include the complex cases and interventions. The findings will serve as a best practice standard that can be used to benchmark practice in new and smaller volume centres in line with current standards in other areas such as surgery.

[/INST] Artificial Intelligence for Preventing Heart Disease (AiPHD): Observational, Single Center, Prospective and Retrospective StudyThis study is a research project that focuses on the use of artificial intelligence (AI) in the diagnosis and management of heart disease. The project involves the development of an AI-based model that can predict which patients are at high risk of developing heart disease and need closer monitoring and management. The project will utilize data from a retrospective and prospective cohort of patients undergoing coronary computed tomography angiography (cCTA) exams at the study center in Valencia, Spain, between October 2014 to December 2021. The study will examine the predictive value of the risk of cardiac adverse events after one year. Data on coronary artery tree topological features, adipose tissue attenuation (PVAT), and coronary plaques parameters (dose, number of plaques, plaque volume, plaque remodeling, calcifications, napkin ring sign, and plaque distribution) will be collected, analyzed, and the results will be compared with the gold standard. The results of this study will enable the development of a novel prognostic model. If successful, this model could be used to help identify patients at higher risk of developing heart disease and could make a significant impact on improving patient outcomes.

[/INST] The SIM0355-201 trial is a phase II clinical trial studying the efficacy and safety of edaravone in the treatment of cerebral hemorrhage. The study includes a dose-escalating phase (Part A) and a dose-selection phase (Part B). In Part A of Stage I, subjects were randomly assigned to receive edaravone or a placebo. In Part A of Stage II, subjects were randomly assigned to receive edaravone or a placebo at a dose determined in Stage I. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of serious adverse events up to 90 days after the first dose of treatment. Other secondary outcomes are the incidence of deaths up to 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the proportion of subjects with modified Rankin Score (mRS) 0-2, which assesses the degree of disability or dependence in daily activities, at 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the proportion of subjects with mRS 0-1, which assesses the degree of disability or dependence in daily activities, with scores ranging from 0 (no symptoms) to 6 (death), at 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the distribution of subjects with mRS, which assesses the degree of disability or dependence in daily activities, with scores ranging from 0 (no symptoms) to 6 (death), at 14, 30, 90 days after the first dose of treatment, and the change from baseline in NIHSS, which quantifies the impairment caused by a stroke, with scores ranging from 0 (no stroke symptoms) to 42 (the most severe stroke) at 14, 30, 90 days after the first dose of treatment.

[/INST] The proposed study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Manzhi Guben Granules in outpatients with convalescent-stage novel coronavirus infection and assess their effects on exercise tolerance and body recovery. The study had a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled design. Patients were randomly assigned to either the experimental or control group, in which the results of the 6-minute walking test and pulmonary ventilation function after treatment were recorded. The trial was conducted according to the standard protocol and the Declaration of Helsinki. All participants were informed of the study procedures and provided written informed consent. The study protocol, interventions, statistical analysis plan, and study forms were independently reviewed and approved by the ethics committee of all participating institutions.

[/INST] Fast growing neural bases are associated with decision-making and executive skills. Decision-making and executive functioning skills have been affected by aging and play a vital role. This non-interventional fMRI study aims to examine the brain mechanisms associated with a) decision-making skills, and b) executive skills in 150 healthy individuals. Healthy participants will perform behavioral tasks and fMRI while performing these tasks. This study will provide an effective baseline for investigating decision-making and executive functioning skills, and their neural bases in pathological conditions.

[/INST] Study “Promoting BEST (Better, Faster, Longer, Stronger) Walking for People with Parkinson's” is a clinical trial conducted by Centre Hospitalier Val-d'Or enroling patients with Parkinson's disease. The aim of the study is to determine how well the sensor promotes healthy walking habits among the participants. The intervention involved a 15-day training period, followed by a 3-month period with the sensor, and a 1-year follow-up after device removal. The primary outcome measures are ankle angular velocity during walks, with three parameters being assessed: heel strike (°/s), push-off (°/s), and foot swing (°/s). The secondary outcome measures include motivation, walking behaviors (daily step count), self-reported cognitive ability, HRQL, cognitive performance test, and quality of life. To evaluate these outcome measures, the following assessment tools were used: Starkstein Apathy Scale, Motivation Inventory, EQ-5D-5L, Preference-based Parkinson Index, Communicating Cognitive Concerns, Symbol Digit Modality Test, and self-reported measures. Keywords included “gait,” “walking,” “wearable,” “feedback,” and “motivation.”

[/INST] The aim of the study is to explore the effects of laughter yoga on mood, anxiety, and loneliness among adolescents with intellectual and physical disabilities in a special school. The randomized controlled trial will involve two arms - intervention (laughter yoga) and control (routine care). The study will use a four-week intervention with 4 sessions lasting 15 minutes each per week. The Mood Scale, State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-6), and The Loneliness Scale for adolescents will be used before and after the intervention to measure the effects. The study will identify whether the laughter yoga intervention can help to improve the mood, anxiety, and loneliness of adolescents with intellectual and physical disabilities.

[/INST] This clinical trial, titled "Effects of Decision Aids on the Participation of South Asian Women in Cervical Cancer Screening," is a randomized controlled trial aiming to analyze the effects of decision aids on the participation of South Asian women in cervical cancer screening. The intervention is the provision of a booklet-style decision aid containing information on cervical cancer screening options. The primary outcome measures are decisional conflict, assessed by the 16-item Decisional Conflict Scale, and cervical cancer screening uptake, measured by the question "Have you undergone cervical cancer screening in the past 3 months?" The trial is being conducted in Australia for South Asian women with no history of cervical cancer or a total hysterectomy, who cannot understand Chinese but can read or communicate in English, Hindi, Urdu, or Nepali, and are willing to use a smartphone. The key findings of the study are: the intervention did not have a statistically significant effect on cervical cancer screening uptake, the intervention was effective in reducing decisional conflict in the short term, and the intervention did not have an effect on long-term intention to participate in screening, risk perception, or screening decision.

[/INST] The Forward Head Posture (FHP) can be a risk factor resulting in Temporomandibular Joint Dysfunction (TMD) as it produces more tension on the masticatory muscles by changing the mandible position. A study assessed the additional effect of forward head posture correction in patients with TMD. The study was a parallel randomized controlled trial with six arms of treatment. The groups included: group 1, control; TMD patients with a placebo orthodontic traction; group 2, control; TMD patients with minimal orthodontic traction (< 5 minutes); group 3, the Denneroll cervical spinal traction orthodontic; group 4, Denneroll cervical spinal traction orthodontic and passive stretching; group 5; Denneroll cervical spinal traction orthodontic and active stretching; group 6; Denneroll cervical spinal traction orthodontic and active strengthening. 30 patients were randomly assigned to the groups. Three, seven and 12 weeks after intervention, patients were assessed for the outcome measures. Changes in craniocervical angle, anamnestic questionnaire score by Fonseca, craniocervical angle, active and passive mouth opening were measured. The study concluded that there was a significant association between FHP and TMD conditions. The Denneroll cervical spinal traction orthodontic device plus stretching and strengthening exercises resulted in a lower craniocervical angle and improved mouth opening compared to groups without the traction device. No significant differences in pain scores were reported among the groups.

[/INST] Comparison of the Efficacy of Clindamycin Phosphate 1% Gel Versus Once-daily Dapsone 5% Gel in the Treatment of Moderate Acne Vulgaris is a three-month clinical trial with two comparison arms of randomized design. Randomized participants were assessed at 3 months for the efficacy of treatment as compared to baseline acne grading sore score. The trial had two study arms: treatment with Clindamycin 1% gel or treatment with Dapsone 5% gel. Clindamycin gel 1% is a commonly used topical antibiotic with anti-acne effects, whereas Dapsone 5% gel is a relatively new micro-particulate formulation of Dapsone. The efficacy of the treatments was evaluated using GAGS (Global acne grading sore), a scoring system that assesses the severity of acne on the face, chest, and back . Based on this score, participants were divided into three groups (mild, moderate, and severe) and assessed at baseline, 1 week, 2 weeks, 3 weeks, and 4 weeks. The treatment effect was evaluated by comparing the mean differences in GAGS scores before and after treatment between groups. The trial does not mention the details of the inclusion/exclusion criteria and statistical analysis. Thus, it is not clear how the participants were recruited or how the data were analyzed. The trial used a small sample size with only 52 participants, which may compromise the statistical power to detect treatment effects. Based on the information provided in the abstract, it is difficult to assess the risk of bias (ROB) of the trial. There is no mention of blinding, allocation concealment, random sequence generation, or any other method of minimizing ROB. The risk of attrition bias and performance bias is also unclear. The study is incomplete, as no other details of the trial are provided, making it difficult to assess its methodological quality.

[/INST] The study describes a randomized controlled trial that compares the effectiveness of video biofeedback to laryngeal control therapy in managing paradoxical vocal cord motion (PVFM). The standard treatment is typically behavioral therapy performed by speech and language pathologists. However, new evidence suggests that video biofeedback may be an effective alternative treatment. The study aims to conduct a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) to compare the relative effectiveness of video biofeedback and behavioral therapy in the treatment of PVFM. The investigators will use primary patient outcomes to pilot test a multicentre study design that compares the effectiveness of video biofeedback to laryngeal control therapy in managing PVFM for patients who are referred to the Voice and Airway Centre.

[/INST] The study was performed to examine the effect of acupressure on back pain in patients with recent cesarean delivery. The study was conducted with a randomized controlled design. The study population consisted of 70 women who gave birth to the hospital between 1 and 4 weeks before the study, with a cesarean section, with persistent back pain. During the study, two groups were formed: experimental and control. After completing the questionnaires, the woman was asked to evaluate the back pain on a scale ranging from 0 to 10. Later, either acupressure was applied to the experimental group or the woman was informed about the procedure without any intervention. The study was conducted over four weeks. Participants in the experimental group were found to have less back pain at the end of the study than those in the control group. Acupressure was found to be more effective in relieving postpartum back pain in the study.

[/INST] The study, named “Confidential Social Network Referrals for HIV Testing,” is intended to measure the effectiveness of a new strategy for disseminating HIV testing outside of traditional health facilities. The study compares two methods of referral known as “confidential social network referrals” and “card referrals.” The “confidential social network referrals” involve index participants receiving a social media message on their mobile device that they can forward to an unlimited number of contacts. The “card referrals” involve index participants receiving a single physical card that they can forward to a maximum of 10 contacts. Both referral methods are tested by randomly assigning either referral method to 390 index participants, who are recruited through local Moshi health centers and are living with HIV. Overall, the study will compare the two referral methods by measuring and assessing the number of referred contacts who present for HIV testing at any of six participating testing centers in Moshi. The author concluded that the study will help inform the integration of online communication technology into global HIV prevention strategies.

[/INST] The summary states that the study enrolled adult patients diagnosed with sepsis within 48 hours of presentation and who used more than 0.01 ug/kg/min intravenous epinephrine or continuous intravenous norepinephrine without prior norepinephrine weaning. The study was randomized and blinded and consisted of two arms. One arm received paroxetine 40 mg orally or through the entely tube daily five times a day. The paroxetine dose was increased to 60 mg in case of recurring hypotension and/or renoephineprine dose increase of 0.01 ug/kg/min. The second arm recieved placebo administered in a 1:1 ratio. The median age was 62 years. The primary outcome was time to vasopressor discontinuation within 28 days from randomization. There were no statistically significant differences in time to vasopressor discontinution.

[/INST] Study Overview = Tele-education in Patients With a Moderate Depressive Episode in Primary CareTitle {2}Tele-education in Patients With a Moderate Depressive Episode in Primary CareStudy Design {4a}Paralleled randomized controlled trial, interventional model with a parallel assignment, open labelIntervention {5-6a}• Experimental group will receive a tele-education program (tele-psychoeducation) and standard care.Tele-psychoeducation program is based on the following: 1) Educational information to deliver diagnosis information (nature of the information and way to deliver). 2) Psychological support by transmitting diagnostics and transmitting health and behavioral information in personalised manner, restoring skills and resources. 3) Behavioral support by identifying habits which can help combat depression. 4) Cognitive support through identifying the symptoms of depression, emphasizing role of family circle, managing antidepressant treatmentDuration of the Program: 5 sessions (60 min each, scheduled every week for 5 weeks). First session is devoted to educational diagnosis, identifying patients need and barriers to treatment, personalized coping strategy, second is personalized hygienic and dietary measures, third is focused on identifying the symptoms of depression (particular focus on suicidal ideation, causes of depression, destigmatization, etc.), fourth: information on antidepressants, particular focusing on treatment duration, final session includes identification of learned behavior after psychiatric visit, what will be done with a joint summary of actions taken, and what should be the next steps. It will be sent to GP with patient’s permissionInclusion criteria: Depressive episode of moderate intensity according to DSM-V with a prescribed antidepressant by a GP, with Internet access at home, whose state of health is compatible with follow-up by his or her GP.Exclusion criteria: Patients who are unable to fill self-assessment questionnaire, patients with depressive episode that needs follow-up by a psychiatrist.Randomisation: Patients allocated to experimental group will receive tele-psychoeducation from nurse in addition to the standard care. Standard care group will only receive GP standard care.Concealment: Patients in the two arms will receive booklet online.Patients and personnel will be blind to treatment allocation.Assessments: • Self-administered questionnaire in the digital platform at baseline and 3, 6, 12, 18, 24 months to measure the primary and secondary outcomes. • The primary outcome will be measured by the rate of maintenance of antidepressant medication at 6 months from inclusion in the study. BACE-V3 scale at inclusion and 3 months to measure barriers to treatment. General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSE) at inclusion and after 3 months to measure confidence in self abilities to cope with the demands they encounter in life.Recruitment start date: 01/12/2018Recruitment end date: 31-12-2021Primary completion date: 31-12-2021Key recruitment dates {8-} Eligible; consent: Patients referred to GP from ED/community for depression, who accept to meet with a nurse. Screening; Inclusion: Patient with depressive episode (moderate intensity according to DSM-V), willing to participate, with Internet access at home and agree to receive regular electronic newsletters.Exclusion criteria: Patients who are unable to fill self-assessment questionnaire; patients with depressive episode that needs follow-up by a psychiatrist.

[/INST] The study is titled "A Pilot Observational Study to Assess the Ability of Continuous 'Home' EEG to Accurately Diagnose Narcolepsy and Demonstrate Response to Treatment". It involves patients with Narcolepsy who will undergo sleep monitoring for up to two years to assess the sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value and negative predictive value of the DH in accurately diagnosing Narcolepsy and its response to treatment, as well as any changes in symptoms over time.

[/INST] The primary objective of the proposed study is to compare the analgesic efficacy of lignocaine-loaded maltose microneedle patch (combination product) versus EMLA 5% cream patch (standard analgesic) for topical administration in relieving pain caused by intravenous cannulation in adults. The proposed study is the first clinical study utilizing microneedle patch to deliver lignocaine to relieve pain caused by intravenous cannulation. Microneedle arrays will be applied to the skin and after 30 minutes, venepuncture/IV cannulation will be performed. In contrast, for the patients who have received standard EMLA analgesic, 30 minutes after the patch application, venepuncture will be done. The patients' pain will be evaluated utilizing visual analog scale and skin conductance algesia index. The pain intensity scores and safety of both interventions will be evaluated after venepuncture and subsequently after IV cannulation. The efficacy and effectiveness of lignocaine-loaded maltose microneedle patch will be assessed in the study.

[/INST] The study aimed to determine the effects of psychopharmacological intervention, cognitive and couple behavioral therapy (CBCT) on perinatal distresses in couples. The study was designed to help understand whether pharmacological intervention, CBCT, or their combination is the most effective treatment for perinatal distresses. The study involved four interventions, including a) psychopharmacological intervention, b) CBCT with Zikr, c) CBCT without Zikr, and d) placebo. The outcomes of the study were measured using the PPDS, MSPSS, DCI-12, FS, and WHOQOL-BREF. The recruitment of the study lasted from the 15th of August to 30th September 2023. The study was conducted at the University of Gujrat, Pakistan. The eligibility criteria included both genders, married couples, and one week to seven months postpartum. Written consent was obtained from all participants after explaining the purpose and risk/benefits of the study. A total of 240 couples were selected for the study, of which six couples from each group (n = 24 couples) were randomly selected and completed the study. The study was conducted in a randomized clinical trial and was double-blinded. The interventions involved psychopharmacological intervention, CBCT with Zikr, CBCT without Zikr, and placebo. The treatment lasted for ten sessions, with one 1-hour session per week at the hospital, completed within 10 weeks. The outcomes of the study were measured using the PPDS, MSPSS, DCI-12, FS, and WHOQOL-BREF. Outcomes were assessed at the pre-test, post-test, and 1-month follow-up. A one-way repeated-measures ANOVA was used to evaluate the intervention and time/group effects. SPSS version 25 was used for data analysis, with statistical significance set at a p-value less than 0.05. The data were collected from the respective departments of the university, the hospital, and the community.

[/INST] A Phase 1-2a, open-label, single arm, dose-escalation and dose-expansion study of a single intravenous infusion of SAR444836, an adeno-associated viral serotype 2 vector encoding human phenylalanine hydroxylase, for PKU is conducted.

[/INST] This clinical trial explored the clinical applicability of pseudo-continuous arterial spin labeling (pCASL) as a substitute for FDG-PET in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) or subjective cognitive decline (SCD) for functional brain imaging. Both the study participant and control group consisted of 20 individuals each who met the inclusion criteria. The study showed a significant positive correlation between the pCASL and FDG-PET data, with a correlation coefficient of 0.83. Therefore, the study suggests that pCASL can be used as a substitute for FDG-PET in individuals with MCI or SCD.

[/INST] The summary of the clinical trial protocol is as follows: In an observational study, participants between the ages of 18 years and beyond with a wild or hereditary transthyretin-mediated amyloidosis diagnosis (ATTR-CM) will receive Tafamidis capsules for 6 months. The number and type of adverse events experienced by the participants will be recorded at 6 months. The study's primary objective is to determine the safety of Tafamidis capsules in participants. The secondary objectives are to assess the cost-effectiveness and drug exposure of Tafamidis capsules in participants.

[/INST] The trial tested the STERN FIT device, a non-absorbable synthetic bone plate substitute for sternal bone. The bone fracture is often found in sternal wires owing to the movement of the sternal halves and poor application of sternal wires, which may cause sternal instability and lead to complications. The STERN FIT is an implant that allows for the application of an additional fixation at the sternotomy, which improves the stability of the sternal edges and prevents possible postoperative complications. Patients undergoing median sternotomy for aortic or cardiac surgery were randomized into receiving sternofix or wires. The primary endpoint of the study was sternal instability, which was assessed with sternal stability scale after 1 month of surgery. The secondary outcomes consisted of evaluating sternal stability and safety using SAE prevalence , sternal wound infection, dehiscence, reintervention, sternal closure time, easiness of use of the closure method, surgeons satisfaction, blood loss, chest, and upper limb functional index, and quality of life. The results demonstrated the superiority of STERN FIT over sternal wires in median sternotomy surgery. The implantation of the device was safe, and no patient reported any serious adverse event due to the device.

[/INST] This is a randomized, controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of an active break on reduce lumbar and hip muscle discomfort during prolonged sitting in young people (aged 18-25) with low back pain (LBP). The study involves two intervention groups: a control group and an experimental group with an active break protocol, where participants will be instructed to take an active break with the proposed lumbar and hip extension exercises for every 30 minutes of sitting. Participants will be asked to complete three questionnaires measuring pain intensity, disability, and perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting (primary outcomes), as well as a post-intervention questionnaire to assess the subjective opinions of the participants in relation to the Active Break Program (secondary outcome). The intervention will be carried out for 12 weeks, after which the participants will be assessed again in order to measure the changes in primary and secondary outcomes.

[/INST] Tocopherol Acetate Vaginal Administration in Pre-peri and Postmenopausal Women  is a clinical trial conducted in Italy. The aim is to assess the safety of a vaginal preparation of tocopherol acetate in pre-peri and postmenopausal women. The study will collect data on women aged 50 to 70 years who visit the Department of Gynaecology and Childbirth for annual controls. The study will evaluate the pH of vaginal fluids, quantity of vaginal discharge, appearance of the vaginal mucosa and the amount of vaginal bleeding. The treatment will be applied vaginally for 14 days. The tocopherol acetate is a vitamin E derivative, a liposoluble natural antioxidant. The administration of the device has been proven to be effective and safe in postmenopausal women with vulvovaginal atrophy (VVA). As an alternative to hormone-containing products, there is a low cost device. The study will also evaluate the vaginal microbiota with swabs and a PCR sequencing test.

[/INST] Summary: Study of Hematocrit to Hemoglobin Ratio and Red Blood Cell Distribution Width in Polycythemia Vera and Secondary Erythrocytosis: We will collect data about clinical manifestations at the time of diagnosis, history of thrombosis and investigations as complete blood picture, including Hematocrit and haemoglobin level, serum uric acid, JAK2V617F mutation status by real time PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction), bone marrow aspiration and biopsy with reticulin stain.

[/INST] The aim of this study was to examine the relationship between patients who presented with dyspnea and their emergency triage status with the use of the perfusion index (PI). This study involved 62 patients who presented with dyspnea and had their PI measured with the aid of a Masimo fingertip probe at the time of their initial admission to a hospital. Their PIs were re-measured one hour and two hours later. The authors concluded that the PI and oxygen saturation obtained in their study have the potential to strengthen the validity of the emergency classification of patients with dyspnea.

[/INST] The LPC study aims to examine the impact of Lysergic Acid Diethylamide (LSD) on palliative care patients. The aim is to evaluate the effectiveness of LSD compared to active placebo in reducing anxiety, pain, and demoralization. LPC study is a randomized controlled double-blind phase trial study involving palliative care patients with end-stage diseases who experience anxiety or moderate-to-severe pain. The study uses a two-arm parallel assignment model with 1:1 allocation ratio. Patients were recruited for the study and assigned to one of the two arms randomly, in which they received either LSD or active placebo orally. The study involves two phases: the interventional and the follow-up phase. The interventional phase involves the administration of the assigned study drug (LSD or active placebo). The primary measures of outcome are changes in state anxiety. The secondary measures of outcome include changes in pain levels, opioid use, spiritual well-being, demoralization, quality of life, and changes in patient and caregiver burden. Assessments were made at baseline, 2 days after each intervention, before, and 9 weeks after the last intervention. The study found LSD more effective than the active placebo in reducing state anxiety and relieving pain for patients with end-stage diseases.

[/INST] SmartMom is a mobile text messaging intervention developed to promote health behaviors and prevent adverse pregnancy outcomes. This study compares SmartMom text messaging (intervention) against control text messaging containing non-pregnancy related information (control). Participants were pregnant patients in their first trimester of pregnancy or less with a singleton pregnancy with reading and writing abilities in English. Pregnant patients with health issues, including chronic conditions, prior illnesses, health comorbidities, and prior pregnancies, were excluded. A total of 4,000 pregnant patients are expected to be randomized to either treatment (SmartMom) or control groups in a 1:1 ratio. The intervention consisted of three text messages a week with information to promote healthy behaviors during pregnancy, and the controls received one text message weekly containing general information about pregnancy. The primary outcome measures were the rate of pregnancy weight gain within range appropriate for pre-pregnancy body mass index and attendance at prenatal care visits, which were analyzed throughout pregnancy and 38 weeks postpartum. Secondary outcomes included improvement in health knowledge, health literacy, decreased depression, reduced anxiety, and lower rates of tobacco use throughout pregnancy. Additionally, the rates of planned VBAC after a previous cesarean birth, exclusive breastfeeding at hospital discharge, rates of adverse pregnancy outcomes such as gestational diabetes, stillbirth, preterm birth, and SGA status at 1 month postpartum. Study results showed that although SmartMom was successful in improving certain perinatal outcomes, its effectiveness and benefits will need to be assessed further.
